PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Concerts
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Concerts
To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of the city of Armidale respectfully showeth:
a. that there is a very limited range of cultural provisions for rural areas;
b. that the provision of ABC Concerts significantly enriches the options available to rural residents;
c. that regional centres permit residents of wide country areas to attend concerts when they would not be able to journey to the metropolitan areas;
d. that the youth of country areas have an equal right to access to visits by outstanding musicians and should not be disadvantaged;
e. that significant savings could be effected without the complete elimination of the country concert program;
f. complete elimination in the Bicentennial year would be a retrograde step.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Broadcasting Commission be asked to continue its provision of country concert tours by leading artists.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they so wish to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent the Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 December 1987, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill proposes a number of very important amendments to the operations of the Family Court and the Opposition will support the Bill in principle. Indeed, it supports the major proposals contained in it. However, the Opposition will propose some amendments which I have asked to be tabled so that they can be considered during the course of the second reading debate. I shall make some further reference to them later in my speech. I should like to speak generally about the problems with the Family Court and the solution, or part solution, which the Government proposes in the Bill. The Family Court was established in the legislation of 1975 known as the Family Law Act and, of course, it was a very important part of the new social and legal experiment which that legislation contained.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court commenced business on 5 January 1976. It has therefore been a prominent feature of the Australian legal system for just over 12 years. Unfortunately, the Family Court has not established itself as a superior court which has been recognised by the public or indeed the legal profession in the same way as other superior courts in Australia. I do not believe that the Family Court should be held responsible for that but many people do believe that.

The Family Court was established as part of the new family law code contained in the Family Law Act 1975, a principal feature of which was the no fault divorce concept. It contained some other major changes in attitude towards the family and the arrangements within the family, both between the parties-the husband and wife-and also in relation to their responsibilities to the children. Some of those concepts have created great problems and have been highly criticised. In the Family Law Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 passed by the Parliament at the end of last year some of those problems were addressed; namely, the lack of responsibility by parents for the care and maintenance of their children and the sloughing off of those responsibilities onto the state, onto the taxpayer. They proved to be very great failings of the Family Law Act. There are other major problems still to be addressed. One in particular is the question of matrimonial property, family property, which has been the subject of a recent major report of the Law Reform Commission. I presume we will hear more about this in the Government's response to that report.

However, it is not our role today in this debate to be discussing those matters. What we are discussing are amendments to the Act to make the Family Court more effective and hopefully a court of greater standing in the community and within the professional community that is concerned with it.

As I said, the Family Court has been blamed by many people for what are not so much the many failings of the Court but rather failings within the Family Law Act itself-and probably more than anything failings of community values and standards which have been to some extent reflected in the Family Law Act. Had the ordinary courts of the land been left with the administration of the Family Law Act or indeed any other legislation which reflected those changes of social and moral values which occurred in the 1960s, and I suppose reached their high point in the 1970s, they would have faced the same problems. Any court administering these laws, any court having to deal with people who have adopted a new set of social and moral values, would have had to grapple with the same problems as the Family Court has had to grapple with. Therefore, I think it is most unfair that the Family Court has been blamed by so many people for failings of laws that we in this Parliament have passed, the breakdown of social and moral values in the community and the lack of responsibility that many parents have been guilty of in these recent decades.

The Family Court, as I said, was part and parcel of the new Family Law Act in 1975. The concept of family court in Australia was certainly a new one, but it was not a new legal concept. Family courts have been established in other places, notably in the United States and, I believe, at about the same time in Canada. The justification for setting up the Family Court was to have a specialised jurisdiction to deal with the very great and sensitive personal issues that arise in this area of the law.

The idea of having specialised courts is not new. I hear a lot of talk these days by people in the highest levels of the legal profession that somehow all courts ought to be courts of general jurisdiction and that there is something wrong with courts of special jurisdiction. That does not in any way reflect the history of the court system under the common law. There have been many precedents in common law over the centuries for the existence of specialised courts. Certainly, in Australian jurisprudence there has always been a place for specialised courts. In fact, the arbitration system originally was administered by what were called arbitration courts. Therefore, the notion that there should be a special court, a specialised jurisdiction in family law matters, was perfectly reasonable from a jurisprudential point of view. There were very solid practical arguments in favour of it. The Family Court has had some very major achievements to its credit over the last 12 years.

The notion behind the setting up of the Family Court was that the judges would have a special interest and qualifications in, sympathy for and understanding of the work, as opposed to Supreme Court judges. They unfortunately, in many cases, regarded family law work as an irritant and a nuisance and did not really bring to bear the sort of sensitivity and concern which this jurisdiction required. I was a member of the Senate when the legislation was considered and played a role in the debates. Indeed, a committee of the Senate of which I was a member looked at the then Family Law Bill. I do not regret the decision which we took then, which I supported-as did many other senators on this side of the chamber-that there should be a specialised Family Court.

The other major feature of the court was the notion of a helping court-a court to which people would have easy access and in which they could be helped by social workers, known as court counsellors, who would assist them to resolve their problems by negotiation and conciliation. Also, registrars of the court-who are officers of the court at a lower level than that of judges-conduct conferences to try to settle the property and financial problems that arise in marriage breakdown. Therefore, it was considered that judges would be involved only as a last resort-that the need for the ordinary type of formal, adversarial proceedings, with counsel and so forth, would be used only as a last resort. That was the concept behind the establishment of the court and the court has been highly successful in achieving that result because, as I think the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in his speech in the other place on this Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill, 94 per cent of the cases that come before the Family Court are resolved by agreement between the parties, either with the assistance of the counsellors or the registrars and no doubt with the co-operation of the legal profession.

Again I think the legal profession has been very harshly dealt with in criticism of the Family Court because by and large lawyers who are doing their job do seek to persuade clients to reasonable settlements. I am sure that the practitioners in the Family Court have also carried on that noble tradition of the legal profession, and the result speaks for itself-94 per cent of the cases that go into the Family Court are resolved. What we see are only the difficult cases that the court has to deal with. I suppose that reflects very much the ordinary work of all courts; they are dealing only with the difficult cases or the very difficult people. Let us not underestimate the difficulty created by some of the people involved in these proceedings. Some people will never be persuaded by anybody that they are not absolutely right. They have no capacity whatsoever for negotiating with their former partner in marriage; they are just exceedingly difficult people to deal with. That is ultimately in most cases the problems the courts are having to deal with, the very difficult element in this area.

As I said, overall the court has got some very great achievements to its credit, and within a short space of time. I do not have the time, in this speech, to go over in detail the problems that that court had in being established. When it was set up in early 1976 under the Chief Judgeship of Elizabeth Evatt and a few of the early judges they had the very gravest difficulty in getting premises. They had to get premises all over Australia for this new court. It was because of the volume of work which was suddenly thrust upon it that they had to get premises quickly and, of course, in many cases the premises were most unsatisfactory. I must say that governments of which I was a member and the present Government have not exactly been generous with making moneys available to the Family Court to overcome the problem of just getting adequate court facilities.

I do not need to remind the Senate of the problems that have been created in the court with some of the really difficult litigants before it who have taken to making threats of violence and indeed, as we know, in two very sad cases murder has been committed. One case concerned a judge and the other a judge's wife. Very grave injury was caused to the second judge who survived the bomb attack in which his wife was so tragically killed. So the court has been dogged with all sorts of problems over its relatively short life. The judges of the court and all those associated with it-and do not forget that a lot of these threats have been made not only to judges but to counsellors and court staff-have had very great problems to cope with. In my view those problems would not have been any different had that jurisdiction been left with the Supreme Courts of the States. Those problems would still have been there. I do not think that the ordinary traditional court structure would have been at all suitable to deal with those problems.

As I have said, there has been an unfortunate attitude towards the Family Court that it somehow is not a proper court, that it is an inferior court, that the judges are not, by and large, of the proper standard for high judicial office and so on. These sorts of criticisms have dogged the Court. One must bear in mind that it is a different sort of court but that does not mean that it is an inferior court. Certainly under the legislation it is a superior court and should be seen to be such. It is our job, as legislators, to react to what I believe and what the Opposition accepts are practical proposals to improve the standing of the Court.

The basic notion of this legislation is to give the Family Court additional jurisdiction in fields other than family law. One of the difficulties for the judges has been a constant diet of family law work. Although it is work of very great importance and sensitivity, nevertheless judges find it a very wearing experience. One can imagine having to make decision after decision about the custody of children or unscrambling a whole lot of tax avoidance trusts when property ownership has to be reorganised after dissolution.

The proposal is that the Family Court should have additional jurisdiction in Federal matters which would otherwise be dealt with by the Federal Court. That will be done only by consultation between the Chief Judge of the Federal Court and the Chief Judge of the Family Court. I am sure that it will not result in work being handed over to the Family Court which a judge of the Family Court cannot handle. Many Family Court judges would be anxious to do this type of work, and well qualified to do it. The only people who will be able to make those decisions are the respective Chief Judges of the two courts concerned. I have full confidence in those two Chief Judges, not only in Sir Nigel Bowen, the Chief Judge of the Federal Court, but also in the new Chief Judge of the Family Court, Mr Justice Nicholson, whom I do not know to the same personal extent as I know Sir Nigel Bowen. However, he is a man of great reputation in the legal profession. This chamber should have the fullest confidence in both these two Chief Judges to select the cases that are suitable for consideration by the Family Court in the additional areas of taxation and trade practices.

Some of the judges of the Family Court may not want this jurisdiction. I am sure that those who feel that they do not have the qualifications for it will not even seek to exercise it. Some cases will arise, no doubt, where any of the judges of the Family Court may be able to get some change of work temporarily which will give them time to refresh their minds and their attitudes somewhat from the constant problems and strain of family law work. As I said, the Opposition supports this idea. It is an experiment. The Government will monitor it. We will monitor it. If it does not work it can be changed. It is important that this experiment should be undertaken. I believe that it will work. But, if it does not work, we can change it at a subsequent time.

In due course the whole nature of the Family Court may change. The Family Court may be brought back into the mainstream of the legal system. One option that no doubt has been considered and will be further considered after this experiment has been tried may be to bring the Family Court back as a division of the Federal Court of Australia. That would mean that judges assigned to that division would still do much the same work as they do now. Judges with a specialised knowledge and understanding of family law work would still be selected for that division of the Federal Court in the same way as they are now for the Family Court. There is no reason why the counselling service should be affected. I believe that is probably the way in which the Family Court will end. Certainly, the jurisdiction conferred on it in this legislation is the first step in that direction, and it is a valuable experiment.

The important thing is that the Family Court be seen as part of the judicial system of Australia. It always has been part, but somehow has not been seen to be such. It is important that it be seen to be part of the system. As I have said, ultimately, it may come back even more directly as part of the Federal Court system.

One thing that I believe would be helpful in that regard-we will propose an amendment to this effect-would be to enable the Family Court judges to robe in the same way as other judges do; in that case, practitioners before the court would also robe. At present there is a prohibition on the robing of Family Court judges. We propose that that should be removed and that the judges should be left to make that decision for themselves. I understand they would be likely to decide to resume the wearing of robes. We will debate that point when the amendment is debated, but it is another way in which the Family Court can be seen to be part of the main traditional judicial system.

The Bill also proposes the creation of an office of judicial registrar to take some of the less important work off the judges of the court, to enable them to concentrate on the major problems of custody and property settlements.

I would like to say something about the tax work in this new jurisdiction. There is great concern amongst the taxation professionals-they call themselves the tax institute; that is, mainly lawyers and accountants practising in this field-about the fact that Family Court judges may deal with some tax cases. It is felt that they will not be qualified to do so. But some judges of the Family Court have had a lot of tax experience in private practice before going onto the Court. They certainly will have had a good deal of further experience in this area as judges of the Court because one of the problems in the family law area has been the consideration of various tax avoidance schemes, complicated trusts and so on and the application of tax law in that regard. Many of the judges of the Family Court will have had a lot of experience in dealing with taxation matters, and I am sure that any judges to whom the tax work is referred will be those who have that qualification. Other aspects of the new jurisdiction may require judges to obtain some further experience, but that should not be difficult. Judges of all courts are called upon to deal with cases or parts of the law in which they may not be an expert, but as part of their judicial capacity they are generally able to cope with those matters. If a mistake is made, of course, appeals are still available. Appeals from the Family Court, in exercising this extended jurisdiction, will go to the Full Court of the Federal Court.

However, we are concerned about one proposal in this legislation: that magistrates should be given the jurisdiction to pronounce a dissolution of the marriage in undefended cases. Admittedly, it is only in undefended cases, but we believe that that is wrong. I shall speak on that amendment in more detail when we are in committee. We believe, however, that it is wrong for the serious matter of divorce to be seen to be down-played in any way by its simply being shunted off to a magistrates court, convenient as it may be in certain cases. The dissolution of marriage is a very solemn matter-the same as entering into a marriage-and it should not be seen to be done lightly or unadvisedly. That responsibility should be retained by the Family Court.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the Family Court deserves a great deal more recognition and certainly a great deal more praise than it has received in its short life. It would have been better had the Family Court been structured on a State basis, as the Family Law Act enabled to be done and which was done in Western Australia. State governments and parliaments were given the option of doing so, but the Western Australian Parliament and Government were the only ones to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —On our amendment.

—We initiated that amendment, as Senator Chaney reminds me, when the Bill went through this Parliament. The Western Australian State Family Court has been the most successful of the Family Courts, largely because of the administration of that court. It would have been easier if it had been a task for each State rather than having to tackle all these problems on a national basis. I have already dealt with what the problems were.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court should not be blamed, in any way, for whatever failings there have been in the Family Law Act. Frankly, I believe that the Family Law Act was correct in establishing a no fault system of divorce. The joint parliamentary committee that reviewed the act after three or four years of its operation came to the same conclusion. I have not had any reason to change the view that I have always held-that the concept of no fault divorce is sensible.

Nevertheless, some grave problems have been found with the Family Law Act, many of which have already been addressed in this Parliament. We ought to be directing our attention to those problems and not spending our time, as so many people do, criticising the Family Court and expecting it to be able to solve problems which have been imposed on it by this Parliament or, in particular, by community values, which have changed so dramatically and which it has had to tackle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987, I want to concentrate my remarks on the part of the Bill that has the effect of tacking on to the Family Court a number of additional jurisdictions-bankruptcy, taxation, and restrictive trade practices, to mention a few-and therefore creates some new form of hybrid.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned and somewhat disappointed about the way that the Government has gone about tackling this matter, bearing in mind the tradition of the development of the Family Court of Australia in this Parliament and the contribution to that progress by the committee system of the Parliament, in particular, in the first instance, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-as it was-which reported in 1974, and then subsequently a joint select committee of the Parliament, which reported some years later on the whole subject of family law and which had the opportunity of reviewing the original establishment of the Court. I believe that these reports made a major contribution to the development of this Court and its functions.

This Bill proposes very major changes to the whole structure of the Family Court. In fact, it is very much a first step towards abandoning the specialised Family Court system. What disappoints me in these circumstances is that this Government has not been prepared to go back to its committee system to have a further in-depth analysis of whether there is just cause for this radical turnaround and an examination of whether, in fact, the Court has failed in such a way that we need to take a step towards abandoning its specialised nature. I am disappointed that the Government has not allowed those people who have strong views on the subject the forum to enable them to put those views to the legislators.

Those of my Party in the other place, in order to facilitate such an in-depth consideration, sought to have the Bill referred to the newly-constituted House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Government refused to do so, although there was no good reason for its refusing. That Committee could have considered the matter over the Christmas break because there was then adequate time. If it had done so we could now have been debating the Bill with the advantage of that detailed consideration by a parliamentary committee.

It will be recalled that when that request was refused we in this place sought to refer the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration. That also was refused by the Government and the Australian Democrats. This is a matter of regret to me. Therefore, we are debating this Bill today and the proposed creation of a hybrid without the advantage of the detailed, in-depth consideration which would have been given to it by the Senate's Committee.

When I look at the Bill I fail to see how the development of the proposed hybrid would improve the situation. There seems to me to be almost an element of desperation in the Bill. When I read the words of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in responding to the debate in the other place that desperation seemed to come through. Nobody is suggesting that it is a logical advance in the Family Court system to add the jurisdictions of taxation, restrictive trade practices and others. No one is suggesting that that is a logical improvement to the system. Rather, what the Attorney-General is saying is, `I am desperate. I need to do something because the judges are unhappy and there have been problems associated with the Court'-Senator Durack referred to the very sad events of a couple of murders associated with the Court-`I need to be seen to be doing something. Therefore, I have come up with the creation of a hybrid'. Of course, the hybrid really has come out of the proposal that the Family Court be fully integrated within the Federal Court of Australia. There were problems associated with that proposal in that some of the judges simply were not suited or were not adequately qualified for that status. That idea was abandoned and the Government came up with this compromise which, like all compromises, has major weaknesses. We should be addressing whether, in fact, now is the time to move away from the specialised nature of the Court. We should be asking: Has the Court failed because of its specialised nature? Should the specialised nature of the Court be the basis of criticism in regard to the unfortunate events that have been associated with it over the years it has been in existence. I certainly have not seen arguments that convince me that it is the specialised nature of the Court that is at fault.

I can reflect upon the days when this jurisdiction was operated under the old Matrimonial Causes Act. In my practice in that field I regarded it as quite horrific-the gathering of evidence to try to prove matrimonial fault; the employment of private investigators to peer through people's windows at night in the gathering of evidence and bringing it to court; and the associated stresses. This was not a human way of dealing with what is a great trauma to many married couples in this country-the breakdown of their marriage. I applauded the establishment of a no fault system and a specialised court with judges who had to be particularly qualified to understand the sensitivities of marriage breakdowns and look to helping the parties through that unfortunate phase of their lives and I still applaud it. I think it was the correct way to go. Certainly there are problems, but the question is: Are the problems to be addressed by abandoning the specialised nature of the court, or are the problems to be addressed in other ways?

I will refer honourable senators to a couple of articles and views which I would have thought would give this Senate cause to progress slowly in this matter. It will enable the Senate to give further consideration to what it will be doing by passing this legislation. I refer, firstly, to a speech that was given by the then Chief Judge of the Family Court, Justice Elizabeth Evatt. It might be said that she had some vested interest in the matter. I will read a couple of paragraphs from a speech which she gave in Adelaide on 10 March last year when she spoke of the Family Court and its problems and benefits. She stated:

The Family Court has been an innovative Court, and has succeeded in establishing close and productive working relationships between Judges, drawn from the traditional legal system, and Court Counsellors whose training and experience is in the area of personal relationships. No one could claim that the system is perfect, but it is continually developing in response to the perceived needs of the community and within the limits of the resources made available to it.
She raises the subject of resources, which I think is critical in this debate. She continued:

The Court is not resistant to change, but it would be a matter of concern if fundamental changes to the Family Law system were introduced which might hinder the Court from pursuing the goals and philosophies for which it had originally been established.
In my view, it is more important to pay attention to the real problems which beset us-
jurisdiction;
resources;
accommodation; and
community education.

I respectfully adopt and applaud the words of Justice Evatt when she suggested `that we direct our minds not so much to the construction of the Court and its specialised nature, but rather to the subjects of its jurisdiction, particularly its resources, the problem of poor accommodation and the continuing need for community education on what are the goals and methods of the Court and particularly its counselling role and its potential to further develop its counselling role.' I would like the Senate in this debate to consider those words. Also a similar sentiment was expressed by Mr Justice Fogarty in an article entitled `Family Court-Possible future directions' which was recorded in the University of New South Wales Law Journal, 1985. I will quote from his article. He was speaking on the same debate as to what happens to the specialised jurisdiction and where we might head in this area in the future. He stated:

A preferable course in my view is to direct our energies towards the improvement of the operation of the Family Court itself. It needs to be remembered that the Court has existed for just on a decade, a very short period of time in the lifetime of most courts. It has been highly successful in some areas and unsuccessful in others. It has also attracted a great deal of controversy and criticism. Some judicial tribunal to deal with family law has to exist in our society as in any other society and the only relevant question is the form and substance of that tribunal. Experience both within Australia over the last several decades and in all overseas countries with comparable social backgrounds demonstrates the extreme difficulty of providing universally acceptable family laws within that society, particularly because of the enormous changes in social patterns in the last two decades and the difficulties which confront any tribunal which has to administer such a fluid and difficult area of social relations.

It is considerations like that that I believe we should be addressing, and recognising the difficulties in this area, including the short period the Court has been in existence. Mr Justice Fogarty went on to say:

The substance of this Paper is that the Family Court concept is a desirable one in our society, that it needs improvements, and that the energies of its critics would be more usefully directed towards improvements to the system rather than engaging in attempts to destroy the present system without providing any serious alternative.

In a very constructive way he then went on to look at some of the subjects for debate in this matter, and at some of the areas that could be improved. He particularly addressed in the paper the Court and court formality, the continued development of the conciliation process, which is something I applaud, the continued and increasing recognition of the separation of the conciliation and judicial process, greater development of marriage counselling at an early stage of marriage crisis and case management by the Court. I again respectfully adopt these words of Mr Justice Fogarty and say that the Senate would be better conducting a detailed consideration of those constructive areas for development and further improvement of our family law system rather than, as it is doing today, forming a new, hybrid jurisdiction-that of a family court which engages in taxation matters, in restrictive trade matters, in bankruptcy matters and so on.

I want briefly to pick out one of those matters that Mr Justice Fogarty referred to-the greater development of marriage counselling at an early stage of marriage crisis. As we all know, this Court has been criticised for not saving marriages-something which is an impossible task because, unfortunately, when the parties have got to the stage of instituting proceedings and coming before family law counsellors, the marriage has broken down and it is too late. I suggest to the Government that rather than engage in this debate today it would be more constructive to look at putting some really worthwhile resources into marriage guidance, including the Marriage Guidance Council and the various church counsellors and others who are prepared to help parties through marriage difficulties, and therefore look, rather than to the remedy of dissolution, to ways in which some marriages could be saved.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the ludicrous position where it is free to break up and you immediately get a pension, while marriage guidance is charged for. The most expensive thing is to seek counselling.

—It is absolutely ludicrous, as Senator Chaney says, and the Marriage Guidance Council and other counsellors are not supported in the way I believe they should be supported by government in this country. Providing resources in that area would be a very simple step that should be taken, and it is a step that we on this side would certainly applaud.

SPEECH.PARA: If I might get back to the principal debate, I simply remind honourable senators that it was the Senate Standing Committee itself which called for a jurisdiction to deal exclusively with family law matters in its report of 1974, and it was a joint committee of this Parliament which in its report of 1980, after very comprehensive consideration of the matter, further endorsed that concept. I remind the Senate that on page 123 of that report the Joint Select Committee, involving all parties of this Parliament, said:

The decision to create a separate court was quite deliberately made . . . It was considered that the qualities and attributes of Family Court judges and the nature of the court over which they were to preside, required the establishment of a specialist court. A court, moreover, which would provide a bridge between jurisdiction previously exercised by the Supreme courts in divorce matters and the State courts of summary jurisdiction.
The Committee regards this policy consideration as still valid and does not support the creation of a Family Court division within the Federal Court structure.

On each occasion that a committee of this Parliament has considered this question in depth, it has come down in support of the concept of a specialised court. Unfortunately, this Government is not prepared to take the matter back for consideration by another committee but, rather, is determined to put it through the Parliament with its numbers and make this very substantial and significant change by creating a hybrid. I believe it is taking the first step towards the destruction of this specialised court and jurisdiction, and I regret that. I do not believe the Government has acted in the best interests of the Australian people in dealing with the matter in that way and I use this opportunity to express my concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987, I find it very difficult not to link my views on this Bill to the ever-increasing number of representations that are presently being made to me and my electorate office. Senators Durack and Hill-and I presume Senators Cooney and Chaney might have something to say about it-no doubt through their legal practices or past legal practices, would have come across and made contact with the poor unfortunate people who are in the throes of divorce, separation or whatever, far more than I would. So I speak on this matter purely as a humble family man, a very new politician, and someone who can base his observations, I suppose, only on people who are friends of mine, on acquaintances and on those who come to my office.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, it is fair to say that over the past few years there has been a veritable plethora of Labor-inspired legislation which has sought to destroy the family unit and degrade the sanctity of marriage and the result of that union-the family. This Bill will, in effect, turn the Family Court into a rubber stamp and make divorce even easier at a time when already 40 per cent of families have experienced the trauma of divorce. Property division is no longer linked to blame, and the courts have proved ineffective in enforcing maintenance provisions, thereby placing an ever-increasing burden on the taxpayer to support the results of these broken marriages.

No other institution can replace the completeness of the family which brings children into the world and surrounds them with love and caring. It is a frightening statistic that second marriages now have a higher rate of divorce than first marriages, with the result that thousands of young Australian children will experience a second divorce while still at school. That does not even account for third marriages. Perhaps, with the way things are going and the way the Bill will make things much easier, we will end up with fourth marriages. We could end up with a country full of people such as Joan Collins and the like.

It is apparent that the vast majority of Australians are feeling very threatened by the line of thinking which became trendy during the late 1970s and early 1980s, and despite its obvious failure it continues to be championed by the present Labor Government of this country. My responsibility and that of my Liberal Party colleagues is to ensure the protection of the family unit within the Parliament. It is a task for which we are very well suited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because we care for families. Within the chaos which has become known as the Family Court of Australia, the Government is now trying to do a patch-up job. It is a patch-up job because it fails to address many of the key problems facing the Family Court and at the same time compounds matters by introducing a number of initiatives which quite clearly have not been thought through properly. This is rushed proposed legislation, which has been devised without due consultation with the appropriate professional bodies. It has received the condemnation of those professionals who are charged with dealing with the Family Court on a daily basis. I am sure that all honourable senators have been lobbied by such professional people.

SPEECH.PARA: This `quickie legislation' is designed to complement the `quickie divorces'-which is what they are, and which it espouses. What a sorry state for Australian families and their children, who will be expected to operate under its guidelines. When my colleague the Hon. Neil Brown spoke in the other place about this matter, he stated the obvious, as did Senator Durack this morning. We have seen assassination attempts; we have seen a murder; we have been deluged with complaints; delays have choked the system; and something is very, very wrong. The Family Court as it exists today is a veritable minefield of problems. It is a daily tragedy of human emotions which is further compounded by the trauma of its judges. The question we must ask is: Will this legislation, prepared as it has been in such haste, make a positive difference or will it merely serve to compound matters. I personally fear that it is the latter.

The Bill in its present form does four things. It increases the scope of work performed by the Family Court of Australia to include decisions under the administration, bankruptcy, trade practices and income tax assessment Acts. It creates the offices of judicial registrar in the Family Court. It enables judges to delegate further duties to registrars. And, finally, it extends the jurisdiction which may be exercised by courts of summary jurisdiction.

When examining the effect that the Bill may have on the operation of the courts, it must be noted that custodial and access matters are able to be dealt with summarily by magistrates already. This power is limited by the financial limitations placed on each court. The Bill extends the limit from $1,000 to $10,000 without the consent of the parties. Where there is consent, the court is not restricted to monetary constraints. It is arguable whether these instances where magistrates already have authority are properly dealt with summarily or whether they ought to be dealt with by the Family Court.

What is important is that in my State practitioners usually petition the Family Court for the matter to be heard by the Family Court. This is a clear indication that those practising the law do not believe it is appropriate for these matters to be dealt with by magistrates. Therefore, any changes to the Family Law Act may be given nominal effect by the practitioners, which again highlights the need to examine the detail before implementation.

The Bill states that matters will be dealt with summarily only where an action is undefended. A case is undefended when both parties agree to the divorce and one party has applied for the divorce and the other has responded. The only criterion necessary is that the couple have lived apart for 12 months, subject to few exceptions such as where there has been an attempt at re-cohabitation which has been unsuccessful.

To fulfil the criteria for a divorce under the Family Law Act is fairly straightforward. The actual granting of a divorce is a right enjoyed by the parties so that, for any court, whether summary or family jurisdiction, it is more a procedural matter than anything else. In this jurisdiction it is almost a matter of rubber stamping. The problems arise when there are disputed cases over property and custody of children. Such contested disputes arise in both defended and undefended cases. The Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, may well be right when he states that 95 per cent of cases are undefended, but problems will still arise as a consequence of divorce proceedings being instituted or following the granting of a divorce. In a practical sense, the problem is not in leaving the matter of granting a divorce to the lower courts but in giving the courts of summary jurisdiction increased power to resolve disputes.

It was only the other day that a young lady came to my office seeking assistance. She has been divorced for some 12 months. Her former husband is now living in a de facto relationship with another lady. The ex-husband and his de facto partner both work. One would think that they would have quite a deal of money in the bank but, because they are clever people, their bank accounts show approximately $6 in one account and $15 in another. The young lady who came to my office seeking assistance has custody of two teenage children. I am sure we would all know the sorts of problems she would be experiencing with them. She receives maintenance, and this is one of the problems that arises. She receives maintenance from her husband but, because she was smart enough to go out and get a reasonable job, work hard, earn a reasonable wage, and manage to have some money in the bank, her ex-husband considered that it was about time that he took her to court and tried to reduce the amount of maintenance he was paying. She had no say in it, of course. Summarily, they went to court and he lost the case. Nevertheless she was required to pay not only legal fees for her defence but also court costs. I believe-we are looking at this in our office at the moment-that this can happen at any time and when he feels fit or nasty about the situation he can bring her back to court at any time he wishes. These are the types of things that are happening and they are the types of things that the Family Court should be looking at.

Senator Hill and Senator Durack referred to the selection of judges for the Family Court of Australia, which is more specific as the tasks they need to perform are readily identifiable and, while complex, do not vary as to the types of legal problems which arise. These judges are picked for their special skills in dealing with families and for their knowledge of the needs of families and the problems with the break-up of families.

It is unrealistic to imagine that magistrates have such skills as well as the more general abilities which they must have to administer the general law. Under this Bill it is likely magistrates would gain only a smattering of family law cases so they would be unable to build up an expertise in such matters. Conversely, family law judges deal with family law matters daily and have the expertise both prior to and during their tenure as judges. As it stands at the present the Family Court is unique as regards other areas of law in the country.

Unlike the common law, which is based on precedent and trial by jury, and statute law, which is derived from the criminal code and the Acts of State and Federal government, the Family Law Act is enacted by the Parliament and the scope for discretion as embodied in the statute is large. The statute gives the judge far-reaching powers to come to an equitable decision with regard to the parties and the law. Provided the judge has followed the statutes, it is difficult for a higher court such as the Full Court of the Family Court or the High Court of Australia to over-rule his or her decision. The responsibility this puts on Family Court judges is great and it is evident in the pressure placed on them and on others dealing with them.

This Bill then, attempts to relieve this pressure by delegating some of these responsibilities to registrars, therefore giving Family Court judges the opportunity to be involved in other work. Without wishing to sound disrespectful, I must admit that I have some difficulty in rationalising whether magistrates in summary jurisdictions should have their powers enhanced to include the discretion which Family Court judges enjoy without the relevant expertise, knowledge and pressures. In addition, the Bill seeks to take the legal costs out of the processes by making them more timely and this would certainly be supported by all. However, will this necessarily be the result when the magistrates courts are already clogged by matters such as driving offences? It is also clear that the application must still be lodged in the Family Court so there will still be costs and time associated with this process before the papers for dissolution of marriage are passed on to a court of summary jurisdiction.

The Bill, in its present format, also raises a number of important social issues. Section 44a inserts into the Act the ability of the applicant to transfer proceedings into a court of summary jurisdiction and section 45 (2) facilitates this where it is convenient for the parties. It can well be argued that this process circumvents the intention of the Family Law Act and especially the amendments made to it in 1983. The 1983 amendments give weight to the counselling role of the Family Court and in certain instances demand that the parties use a mediator to reconcile some of their differences. Unlike the position in the proposed summary jurisdiction, there was at least some sort of discourse between the parties. The intended powers of the magistrates in such circumstances is not entirely clear though it appears likely that in such instances the operation of the system may well cost the applicants more money, aside from the trauma which would flow from such interchange between the courts.

The family unit is the basis of our society, one of which we are all immensely proud. Surely then, giving magistrates the power to end the marriage contract when all avenues may not have been exhausted can only serve to lessen the social fabric of our society. A couple who may already be feeling a profound sense of guilt over their failure to keep a marriage going hardly need to be placed in the situation where they must finalise these matters in a court where they are surrounded by `real' offenders who have allegedly wronged society. Neither is the presence of these hardened criminal offenders likely to help the children of those being divorced who may pre present. Courts of summary jurisdiction have simply not been designed to aid in the smooth transition for children from being in a family unit to being with a single parent.

In 1975 when, largely due to the work of the then Attorney-General, the late Lionel Murphy, the Family Law Act was first enacted, the aim was to facilitate the messy aspects of divorce where the parties chose to part permanently after 12 months of separation. What was integral to the Act and which I believe the late Justice Murphy intended was that prior to the divorce proceedings there was to be counselling to enable the parties to try to find a common ground and if at all possible reconciliation. I am continually dismayed that since 1975 this counselling has received low priority by governments and funding has continually declined, often dramatically, since the first implementation of the Act. It is therefore regrettable that this latest Bill will do nothing to redress the situation. It would appear that counselling is to be used less and less, which will no doubt prove to be a suitable excuse to reduce funding in this area even further. Research in Australia and in the United States has shown many marriages may have been saved by counselling prior to a divorce application being lodged.

Mr Acting Deputy President, what is really needed is a greater community awareness of counselling, both government and church, for couples to solve their problems before reaching the divorce courts Government counselling is contained in the Acts of Parliament, but has all too often been neglected. It is unlikely that the proposed move to courts of summary jurisdiction will give any weight to the need for more awareness of counselling facilities. Indeed, the opposite may well prove to be true as magistrates will be unlikely to be as aware of the existence of such facilities as are Family Court judges. This should not be seen as a criticism or fault of magistrates; it is merely the result of their different functions in the courts.

Family Court judges are often heard to stress the importance of the knowledge and the detail which their highly trained professional support staff are able to devote to every case. This comprehensive case management ensures that each case gets the attention it deserves and is treated on its merits. I find it difficult to see how this change of jurisdiction will serve to benefit a separating couple, except perhaps financially. As I have mentioned previously, the family law area is unique. The welfare of the child is clearly paramount in any decisions involving children and judges have an enormous amount of discretion when deciding cases. I therefore stress that any changes to the existing system without a thorough investigation of the consequences is extremely dangerous because of the delicate nature of the legislation. It is therefore not surprising that family law practitioners throughout Australia have been unanimous in expressing their concern over these changes being made without proper consultation with the groups involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are really debating is whether we ought to continue with a separate specialised family court or not. In looking at this legislation from this point of view it is interesting to look back to the Hansard of 13 December 1973 when the late Justice Lionel Murphy was Attorney-General. Then Senator Murphy said:

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of which court or courts are to exercise this extensive jurisdiction. I have decided against setting up separate, Federal family courts.

That legislation did not come into effect. I think there were two further debates before legislation came into effect. Between that time and the court being set up it was decided to set up a separate Family Court. During all of the debates there has been interest in whether this was the right way in which to proceed. It is not the only area, of course, which has its own court. I suggest, though, that it is different from all of the others.

It is a particularly stressful jurisdiction. I think that has been exhibited by the history that has been recounted this morning by both Senator Durack and Senator Hill. It is certainly my view that it is more stressful than other jurisdictions in which men and women act as judges to administer the judicial system. So the concept of extending their jurisdiction to give them other work opportunities is something that many people have talked about for a long time.

I am somewhat disappointed, though, at the way in which it is being done. I am prepared to go along with it to see whether it works. I do not think it is the ideal way in which to extend the jurisdiction of the Court. It is being extended to deal with areas relating to bankruptcy, income tax appeals, consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act and proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. I wonder whether the notion of giving different and more extensive powers to the Family Court has any meaning, because it does not permit any of these matters to be instituted in the Family Court. They can be dealt with there only if proceedings are transferred to the Family Court from the Federal Court at the request of the parties or by the Federal Court on its own initiative. It seems to me that that is an incredibly complex and therefore expensive way of going about it.

I wonder whether it will ever happen. In what circumstances would two people decide that they would want matters of this kind shifted? In regard to some of the areas in which the Government is one of the parties to the proceedings, what pressure will be put on parties to shift to another court? Which of the judges will hear the matter? The provision as to how this will happen is glib and lacking in real meaning. It is to be decided by the Chief Judges of the two courts. Will they go through the lists every morning and say, `This one will be dealt with by the Family Court and these three will stay in the Federal Court.'? I am not trying to be trite in putting it in those terms, but how will it be done? Will people have to suggest that this be done or, as I say, when the Government is involved, decide what pressure will be put on people to take, for example, their income tax appeals to a Family Court that is a bit short of business at the time? But which of the Family Courts is a bit short of business? Then we could move on to the concept of shoving other matters to the magistrates court. It is all designed to look as though something is actually being done, without analysing the problems of the Family Court, finding proper solutions, restructuring it, giving it additional, meaningful jurisdiction and appointing sufficient judges to enable the work to be done.

It has been recognised for some time that the Court needs to be looked at. The former Chief Judge has questioned whether a separate Family Court was appropriate. The Judicial System Advisory Committee of the Constitutional Commission indicated in February 1987 that a major overhaul was needed. It was not, in my view, being critical of the men and women who are the judges of the Court. It indicated clearly that it was necessary to increase salaries, reduce the work load and improve the resources of the Court. That, of course, includes not only resources for judges but also the resources available for counselling. It also referred to adding variety to the judges' work. It is a pity that those recommendations have not been dealt with in a way which gives some meaning to the function of the Family Court in the future.

For example, what skills do Family Court judges have to review tax? I know a number of Family Court judges. I have had the opportunity to work with them and I have a very high regard for the ones that I know. I have no doubt that most of them could deal with tax and many other matters. Why then is not the Family Court being made a part of the Federal Court? It can only be that somebody thinks that Family Court judges generally are not fit to be Federal Court judges. I do not know which ones it is thought fall into that category. We will find some Federal Court matters being shifted. If we are not careful we will have a two-tiered system of judges in the Family Court. There will be a `them and us' situation-those who are good enough to be Federal Court judges and do some of the Federal Court work and those who are not. I question this proposal. It reads well at first glance. It looks as though something is being done. I think it may create more problems than it solves.

There are at present about 46 Family Court judges. It is very clear that Sydney needs at least three more Family Court judges to cope with the work. An answer to a question on notice was printed in Hansard only this week which indicates the length of time involved in waiting for dissolution proceedings. For the most part it is six to eight weeks. Sydney has the longest waiting time. Sydney, again, has by far the longest waiting time for defended cases which are waiting to be heard. One must wait a number of months to get such a matter heard. Delays in Family Court hearings cause tremendous distress to the parties and to the children involved. They frequently involve money and property matters, but the emotional involvement of the people concerned means that the longer these matters are delayed, the greater stress is placed on parties and on the judge who knows that he is dealing with a matter that has gone on for a very long time.

It is necessary, in my view, to appoint, and keep appointed, the appropriate number of judges to see that the work is able to be done properly. There are other judges in the Family Court system who are not well and who may like to retire. I think that two fall into that category who are not able to deal with much work at present. Other judges have reached the age at which they are eligible to retire. There are some who would like to retire who know that their places will not be filled, or not filled quickly, and that if they retired they would put a greater degree of stress on their brother judges and on those who are running the courts.

The counselling service was set up to deal with some of the emotional problems relating to dissolution of marriage. It ought to be able to fulfil its role. But the counselling service in every registry of the court that I know of is overworked. There are insufficient counsellors to enable it to do the work which needs to be done. It is not just a question of the odd counselling session at the time of the breakdown of a marriage, or of counselling at the time that a divorce or custody settlement is being dealt with by the court. In many instances the parties need the support of counsellors for years in order to make access arrangements work and to sort out a number of other ongoing problems. At the time when one of the former parties to a marriage remarries there may well be a need for counselling so that the parties can sort out the new arrangements, so that the children can understand what is occurring, and to see that it works smoothly.

Another speaker this morning has already referred to the fact that the number of breakdowns of second marriages is considerable. I think that is well known. The stress for children is made even worse when the second marriage breaks down. How many of those problems could be solved if adequate counselling was available? I refer also, of course, to the plea made by the marriage counselling service for adequate funds to enable it more effectively to intervene and help people solve their problems. People tend to go to the marriage counselling service when they have difficulties. They tend more to the Family Court when breakdown has occurred. The money that is being spent on marriage counselling, whilst it may sound a lot, $5.2m, is really not a lot when we look at the cost of $1.5 billion on legal aid, the Family Court, supporting parents' benefits and what is referred to as the divorce industry. It is perhaps time that we re-examined our priorities in this area and made meaningful the words that were spoken about the counselling service when this legislation was initially set up.

It is said that we will have registrars. Many of us know what registrars do. Nothing in this legislation tells us what the registrars in the Family Court will do, nothing at all. I am inclined to think that it is merely a way of avoiding appointing judges and saving funds in that sense. It may be of benefit, but we are not told enough about it, other than to make it look as though it is a solution to take work away from the judges. They would have power to delegate, but it would be a long time before that would become meaningful, before the system would establish exactly what role the registrars can play. Will they be de facto counsellors? What work will they be doing? Will they be doing the arithmetic associated with the information supplied in relation to property and maintenance? We would like to know more about what is envisaged before we can be enthusiastic about whether that means something really new and valuable or whether it is a cost saving measure to avoid appointing judges to the court.

The matter of the wearing of robes has come up in this discussion. I have for many years been of the view that it was a mistake to abolish robes from the Court. The concept of informality in the Family Court is superficially attractive, but it is a court and it is a place where significant decisions are being made about people's lives, about people's property and about the future that children will have, and it is a place where people are frequently upset and frequently very emotional. I have said that several times and it cannot be overstressed. The robes are not a means of aggrandisement or anything of that nature. They are a means of establishing anonymity, and showing that the person making the decision has been judged suitable and capable of doing so; that he is not just one of the boys at the pub, that he is a person chosen for a specific purpose, to play a specific role. Solicitors in the court also come into that category. I think the concept of robes, without going into it in more detail, helps establish that form of anonymity.

I believe that if robes had been part of this Court's tradition right through until now we might have had less violence towards judges because they have been more readily identified by some people who have attacked them. I may be wrong, but I really believe that is the case. It is in fact difficult to recognise a person, unless we know him well, when he is not robed if we have seen him only when he has been robed. It is not a question of hiding behind anything. I just think it is a better way to run the system. We should not carry the concept of informality too far.

As far as the magistrates courts are concerned, some magistrates would deal most suitably with the matters that would come before them, although I cannot accept the concept of dissolution of marriage in the lower court, and I think that argument has been put. Perhaps that is a personal matter, but I see something as important as dissolving a marriage as being something that ought to be done in a superior court. Many of the other matters might be done in a magistrates court, but I do not think that jurisdiction should be given to a magistrate to deal with money in a Family Court matter that is in excess of the amount that he is able to deal with in his normal jurisdiction. That seems to me to be absurd.

The thing that really comes to my mind is where on earth are the magistrates going to get time to deal with this extra jurisdiction? If any other State or Territory has magistrates sitting around with little to do, I would be surprised. The magistrates in the court in my electorate are certainly not sitting around with nothing to do. There are incredible waiting times for the hearing of criminal matters that ought to be dealt with quite promptly. There are long waiting periods for getting all sorts of magistrates court matters dealt with at the present time.

There is no indication whatsoever in the financial impact statement that is given with this legislation that there are going to be funds around for a whole range of extra magistrates. For that reason I certainly would have to reject the concept. But again I think the actual role of the magistrates and the way the magistrates court would be established has not been thought through. Presumably we would have to have a separate section of a magistrates court to deal with the areas of property, custody and maintenance. Those matters could not be mixed up amongst parking fines, traffic offences and street offences. None of this information is presented here, which leads me to think that this is a somewhat cosmetic reaction to the problems of the Family Court that has not been thought through and presented as well as it might. Questions need to be answered.

My concern for finding solutions is such that I will keep an open mind while watching what occurs. I hope that all who have an interest in it will do the same, and that quite soon the Government will establish a mechanism for monitoring the changes which are to take place as a result of these amendments, given that the Government will not allow them to be examined more fully before they come into operation, because it certainly is a most important area of activity and it is something that affects the lives of many people. When two people find themselves in a situation where their marriage has failed, the impact in many terms, not least financially, is quite wide. Of course, the children are very much a part of it. I would hope that in time we will get to a situation where the Family Court really operates in the way most of us would want it to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill has been well discussed by the speakers before me. The various issues they mentioned are very pertinent to the question of how this whole tragic area of family disputes can best be resolved. No matter what laws we have, no matter what regulations we bring in and no matter what structure we set up, they will not work unless the people who operate that structure, who administer the laws and who carry out the provisions of the relevant Act and interpret the law are of the highest quality.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that recently Mr Justice Alastair Nicholson was appointed Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia at the same time as he was appointed a Justice of the Federal Court of Australia, so he holds the two positions. In Mr Justice Alastair Nicholson we have the sort of person who is best equipped to make legislation in this area operate and operate effectively. He has had an outstanding career as a member of the Victorian Bar for a number of years. He has conducted inquiries with great skill and he was appointed a Justice of the Supreme Court in the early part of this decade. He fulfilled his functions there in an outstanding fashion. If we discussed his ability on the bench with anybody at the Bar I think they would have nothing but praise for him. Over the years he has done a great deal of work, and he still does, with the legal branch of the Royal Australian Air Force. He has fulfilled his position there with great skill. He is a man of great charm. I simply say in conclusion that when this Bill becomes an Act, I am sure the new Chief Judge will administer it in as good a fashion as is possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say that I have ever known Senator Cooney to speak for such a short time, even on the weather. I would like to start my comments in this debate on the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987 by complimenting Senator Durack on what I believe was, by and large, an extremely good speech. It was considered, it was essentially sensible and, more importantly, it was non-inflammatory in a debate which could, if some people wished it to, become quite controversial. Dealing with human emotions, with marriage and, in particular, with divorce can sometimes become an issue which excites the imaginings of some people. Senator Durack certainly dealt with this issue in a particularly well-considered way, but I have to admit that I did not agree with everything that he said about the extension of the role of magistrates courts, for example. But by and large I applauded his comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish I could say the same thing about Senator Calvert. Several times he made the comment that something is very wrong in the Family Court and referred to the trauma of judges. Certainly we all agree with that. But would he, I ask, like to go back to a situation where the trauma was on thousands of families in Australia, a situation where women and children were treated violently within the marriage and inequitably outside it? Do we assume from Senator Calvert's comments that something was not very wrong before no fault divorce or before judges occasionally became the targets of abuse by a few idiots whose behaviour, I might add, rather than inducing sympathy ought to confirm the validity of the divorce petition granted against them?

We need to remember that this legislation is the latest in a series of changes to laws relating to divorce that have come before British and Australian parliaments in the past 100 years or so. It may be worth while, given some of the more extreme statements made about marriage, divorce laws, custody and property distribution in letters to editors and so on in recent months, to recollect some of those changes, most of which were met with hysterical responses, as well as more considered responses, from various sectors of the community.

Firstly, as you yourself would well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, in historical terms it is only recently that women have had any rights at all in marriage. Until late last century, under British law a married woman had no right to own property, even that property which she brought into the marriage, and, in the event of a breakdown of the marriage, she lost not only her possessions but also her children if she were the one who was fleeing the home. Changes to the law to give women rights of ownership of property and custody of children were met with outraged comments that the husband's rights were being eschewed and that civilisation as we knew it at the time would crumble.

In Australia earlier this century men were entitled to divorce their wives on the ground of adultery alone. Women were not given that right until much later-a classic example of the law made by men entrenching the sexual double standard that still applies in the minds of many people today. Fault-based divorce was a costly exercise that weighed heavily in favour of the husband. He more easily than she had access to lawyers, to private investigators and, more importantly, to the money to pay for those to collect and present the evidence that was needed for him to dissolve the marriage. The court system, with its preponderance of male lawyers and judges, was likely to, and indeed did, take a dim view of any woman whose behaviour fell outside the usual stereotypes. The church, the law and society generally tacitly supported the right of a husband to beat his wife, to be unfaithful to her whenever he chose and to be a lousy provider, while at the same time expecting a wife to be faithful, obedient and a good wife, mother and housekeeper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Walters sounds amused by this, but I suggest that she go back and have a look at some judicial decisions, talk to some of the women who have been to see their priests or their clergymen and find out just how many of those people regarded it as the sole responsibility of the woman to maintain the marriage, blamed her if the husband was unfaithful, told her to go home and try harder if she were being beaten, and expected her to ignore any abuse of her children because it was the husband's right to chastise not only the wife but also the children.
—A lot of people still think that is the case.

—That is certainly true. Police attitudes to domestic violence, as distinct from any other sort of assault, are still a vestige of this attitude that a good clip on the ear is what will settle most wives down to doing what they are supposed to do-that is, acting dutifully and in obedience to the husband. When the matter reached the court and property was divided, the woman's contribution was often limited and hence the amount that she received was often limited as she had had no opportunity either to bring money or property into the marriage or to earn and acquire it during the marriage. Women and children were, as they often still are, left largely in poverty following fault-based divorce in which the woman was granted custody of the children but no or few assets from the marriage. Sadly, it has been only very recently that the homemaker's contribution has been recognised. That has caused not only a lot of injustice to many women but a lot of concern to a lot of other women. She stayed at home, gave up her opportunities to have independently a career and earn money, brought up the children, helped her husband often in his career, and yet was given by and large very little credit for that when the property distribution decisions were made.

SPEECH.PARA: The stupidity and injustice of this was recognised and partially remedied in the Family Law Act of the 1970s. With it came outraged comments that the husband's rights were being eschewed and, as I said earlier, that civilisation as we know it would crumble and that marriage as an institution was being degraded. Mention was very rarely made of the value of the individuals in the marriage or the rights of both partners and their children to live in a safe, secure and loving environment or be given the opportunity of escaping from misery without finishing up in penury-which is not to say that current divorce laws are perfect or that current attitudes to marriage are ideal; but then, they never have been. It was not ideal when women were classed as non-persons following marriage. It was not ideal when one partner could extricate himself from a marriage and live comfortably ever after but the other partner could not. It was not ideal when a divorce could only be granted after the airing of real or manufactured grievances in a system which really benefited only the lawyers.

By the same token, it is not a good system which puts Family Court judges and their families at risk of death or maiming, and in which women are left in penury anyway following the dissolution of marriage and then become the target of every group in the community that wants to see the Budget deficit reduced by slashing government expenditure on the welfare of those women and their children. Nor is it an adequate system that pays Family Court judges less than their Federal Court counterparts, which denigrates those judges as being less capable than their colleagues because they deal with people rather than property, and which allows aggrieved individuals to take a judicial decision personally because the judgment is delivered in a homely situation quite different from other courts by a judge in street clothes.

It is time we recognised the fact that Family Court judges have a tougher job than judges ruling on tax matters because Family Court judges are dealing with human beings, some of whom, including children, are victims of physical abuse and all of whom are in emotional turmoil. It is time we put Family Court judges back into robes, if not wigs, set them apart quite distinctly from the individuals with whom they are dealing and acknowledged the stresses they face and the difficulties of the work they do by paying them accordingly. That brings me to this Bill, its contents and its deficiencies.

The Bill extends to the Family Court of Australia the capacity to excercise jurisdiction in proceedings other than those relating specifically to the Family Law Act. These include certain proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the Bankruptcy Act, the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act and in taxation appeals under the Income Tax Assessment Act. There have been quite vocal critics of this move from within the legal profession and outside it who argue that the Family Court does not attract a high class of person as judge and that therefore such judges should not be given important or complex legal questions to determine.

We have got ourselves caught up in a vicious circle based very largely on legal prejudice and the massive emphasis on status that seems to prevail within that profession. We certainly fully support the move to extend these matters to Family Court judges.
