It is not fair to pay one group of judges less than their colleagues, fail, therefore, to encourage some of the more money-minded members of the legal profession on to that bench and then argue that Family Court judges are not capable of dealing with matters other than those of human misery because they are not good enough and that the good people go on to deal with property matters, tax matters and so on. We have to break that circle, and now is the time to acknowledge that.

As I have said, we fully support this move, however limited it is, to extend the jurisdiction of Family Court judges. The Australian Democrats believe that the Family Court should be brought back into the Federal Court system. I was pleased to hear Senator Durack commenting favourably on just this factor-on having the Family Court made a division of the Federal Court. We believe that Family Court judges should be paid the same as their Federal Court colleagues rather than at much the same level as District Court judges, as is currently the case. We will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading to this effect. I would like to think it has the universal support of honourable senators in this place.

It had been our intention to move an amendment to put Family Court judges back into robes, with wigs as an option left to each individual judge; but the Opposition has already circulated an amendment which gives judges the right to robe, and we certainly are happy with that. From the conversations I have had with Family Court judges, giving them the right to robe is as good as making it mandatory as it seems that most of them are anxious to go back to robing, if not to wearing wigs. I certainly would not require Kemeri Murray to go into a wig. But it is appropriate that judges of the Family Court go back to robing. We will support Senator Durack's amendment on the grounds that what it does is distance the person of the judge from his or her judicial function. With a bit of luck, that will remove from the minds of some people the belief that the fact that they did not get custody or that property was divided differently from the way they wanted was some personal attack on them by the person they see in the position of judge. Maybe the disguise will not work 100 per cent, but at least it may serve to make the judge seem less accessible to some of the madder people who seem to come before the courts and feel that, if a decision goes against them, it is their right to stake out a judge's home, to attempt or to actually murder judges or their families, and, if all else fails, to kill themselves and their children. We will support the Opposition's amendment in that regard.

We also intend to support the Opposition's amendment to limit the jurisdiction of the magistrates court to property valued up to $10,000. The Government has moved a subsequent amendment to up that ceiling to $20,000. I see little reason for going as high as that and certainly we will support Senator Durack's amendment, unless for some reason the Opposition believes that there are good grounds for arguing for a limit of $20,000. I have not had the opportunity to look closely at the impact of that amendment because it was circulated only this morning. So, I have some reservations about the late amendment from the Government with regard to that $20,000 ceiling. From the quick viewing that I have been able to have of the rest of the amendment, it seems to be unexceptional.

Concerns have been expressed during this debate about those amendments which allow filing and hearing of divorce petitions in magistrates courts. Those concerns seem to be based on the belief that this will somehow disadvantage one or both of the parties or that magistrates should not deal with those issues or, alternatively, that the magistrates court is not the place for people who are involved in a petition for the dissolution of a marriage. With regard to the first point that somehow it will disadvantage one or both of the parties, the amendment applies to non-contested cases only. If one party wants the matter heard by the Family Court, this request must be complied with.

To argue that access to magistrates courts makes divorce easier to get by people who have not thought the thing through is to miss the point-and to miss the point of some very astute comments made by Senator Hill which I fully endorse. The answer is not to stop people going to magistrates courts because it might be easier for them and to make them go to the Family Court because that somehow will have a greater impact on their thinking about the dissolution of the marriage.

We should take up the suggestion made by Senator Hill, by me and by others in this place about funding for marriage guidance counselling-not just when the marriage has got to the stage where the courts are involved, and not even after the marriage has taken place, but prior to that. It is high time we recognised that in modern society the stresses placed on marriages and the individuals within them are increasing. People need to be cautioned about the responsibilities as well as their rights within marriage. Governments, if they are going to accept any of the burden for the cost of marriage dissolution, should act early enough to prevent it happening. I certainly endorse Senator Hill's comments about the Government increasing its funding for marriage guidance, for making it better known within the community that that service is available and for encouraging people to take up that service. It seems to me that early in the rocky period of a marriage-indeed prior to the marriage-young couples, and older ones for that matter, ought to be given better counselling than they currently have.

By and large this Bill goes some way towards making the dissolution of marriage less traumatic for all concerned. I suggest that the fact that many of us with long and happy marriages wished that others could be as fortunate is beside the point. In my case I have been married very happily for almost 21 years, although there seems to be a belief in some quarters that the last 10 have survived only because I have been here as often as I have and that my husband has not had to tolerate some of my less amiable qualities in the last 10 years. There may be something in that, but that may well be an argument for more women going into the Parliament or the work force generally than for anything else. In any event, I have been in the happy position of having a longstanding marriage that has given me a great deal of pleasure and a great deal of support. We have two delightful teenage children who, despite the comments made 10 years ago when I first came to this place, have not yet been made wards of the state. They are a couple of teenagers whom I am very proud to call my daughters. Not everyone is able to put one's mind to working at a marriage and making it as happy and successful.

Those of us who are in this position ought to have some sympathy for those who are not. We ought to recognise that human beings are very frail creatures. Wise governments should accept that fact where the well-being of the community as well as the individual are concerned. In marriage we need to remember that we are dealing not just with rights but also with responsibilities; not just with adults but also with children; not just with the well-off but also with the poor; and not just with the rational but also with the irrational. The law in this area must reflect that.

This legislation goes some additional way to doing so. It is not perfect but it does acknowledge that we are all human beings and are all subject to pressures, whether we are judges or individuals in a marriage, as adults or children of that union. With a bit of goodwill on all sides, the legislation will go some way to removing the excessive trauma and excessive cost, both emotional and financial, of the dissolution of marriages in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that people understand that since the Government has been in power it has introduced in an ad hoc fashion a number of amendments to the Family Law Act. In the past few months the Government has introduced two Bills, the first of which was introduced towards the end of last year and contained amendments that the Opposition had been suggesting for many years. Those amendments, which we suggested and which the Government introduced, said that when considering maintenance judges should not be forced to take into consideration the recipient's entitlement for the supporting parents benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983 Senator Durack attempted to amend the Family Law Act in that fashion but the Government and the Democrats voted against it. In 1985, Senator Durack-pushing again-introduced a private member's Bill to amend the Family Law Act in that fashion. Once again the Government and the Democrats voted against it. Why was it then that towards the close of the session last year the Government suddenly saw the light and introduced amendments in exactly that fashion? The Government then voted for the Bill, naturally, and the Democrats, as usual, saw the light along with the Government and also voted for the legislation that the Opposition had been proposing since 1983.

That was the Bill introduced towards the end of last year but there have been many other amendments. To mention just one, the Government introduced divorce by post, purely as a cost saving exercise and the Opposition opposed that. The Government's priorities about stability of the family and attempts for reconciliation in a family breakdown are non-existent. It does not care; the only exercise it wants is cost saving and again this is coming through very clearly in the amendments before the House today.

When the Bill the House is debating today was introduced, the Opposition pointed out that the matter was very complex; that there was a lot of concern about the Family Law Act and that the Bill should go to a committee of the Senate for investigation. The Government would not permit this to occur and, again, with the support of the Democrats it voted against sending the amendments to a committee of the Senate with the result that over the Christmas break the Government saw that it was indeed more complex than it originally thought and has already-before the House has debated the Bill-introduced amendments that proved that it had never given the Bill enough thought in the beginning. I shall deal with those amendments a little later.

What does the Bill do? It does several things: It broadens the work of the Family Court judges; it is said, to enhance the standing of the Court. I wonder why the Court has come into such disrepute. The Government has said that the broadening of the jurisdiction of the Family Court judges will make it more attractive to the judges and will also give the existing judges some relief from the burdens of the highly emotive family law jurisdiction.

It extends the Court to the jurisdiction and proceedings of bankruptcy, income tax appeals, consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act and proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. To give the judges time to enter into those new areas, it has suggested that the registrars be given additional powers. It will remove the present limitations on the powers of the judges to delegate functions to the registrars. In following this up, I shall be very interested in just how successful that will be because I view with some concern registrars being delegated powers beyond their capabilities. However, according to Senator Tate's second reading speech, this legislation will give the judges more time to concentrate on more major matters and to accept these additional judicial arrangements.

Of most concern to the Opposition-I do not understand how Senator Tate could bring this into the chamber-is the fact that the Bill gives the magistrates a right, in undefended divorce cases, to take over the jurisdiction there. I do not understand how anyone could downgrade the family situation to the extent of taking it out of the Family Court, where it was originally put, so that judges who had a complete understanding of Family Court matters should look at all the cases. This Government is proposing to take out of the jurisdiction of Family Court judges the responsibility for uncontested divorce cases and give it to magistrates courts.

In the course of Senator Calvert's speech, Senator Giles interjected that it would be `only the undefended cases'. However, on many occasions undefended cases involve children. It is a requirement, I remind Senator Tate, for Family Court judges to be satisfied before approving an undefended case that the arrangements made on behalf of the children are to the Court's satisfaction. I think that should be a priority of every Australian. People who want to get divorced for their own convenience will not always-although I believe they will in the majority of cases-make the arrangements for their children the top priority. It is then up to the Family Court judge to do that. Taking some of the matters relating to a divorce case, whether defended or undefended, out of the hands of the Family Court judge stops that occurring. I believe that we are entering into a very dangerous situation in that regard. As a result, we will certainly oppose that. I cannot understand how Senator Tate, of all people, can bring forward such a proposal in this chamber. At the Committee stage of the debate I will be asking questions on that matter.

In the second reading speech to the Bill as it was presented to us last year, before the proposed amendments were drawn up over the Christmas recess, we were told that the magistrates courts could in their jurisdiction in relation to property matters substantially increase the monetary limit to the limit set for the recovery of debt in each State. In New South Wales that is $40,000. Of course, we opposed that and said that it was too large an amount. We propose to move an amendment changing that amount to $10,000. The Government has acknowledged that it was wrong in introducing that in the legislation last year and is now proposing to move an amendment to upgrade, if one likes, that amount to $20,000 but not to do so to the limit set for debt recovery in each State because the levels set in each State are different.
Another amendment the Government proposes to move is designed to limit in some way the magistrates' jurisdiction. The proposed amendment reads:
The regulations may provide that proceedings for a decree of dissolution of marriage may not be instituted in, or transferred to, a court of summary jurisdiction other than a prescribed court.

I presume that the prescribed courts will be magistrates courts with full time magistrates and not just part time magistrates. Once again, there were faults in the original Bill. If the Government had agreed to the Opposition suggestion and set up a committee to look at these things we would not now have this ad hoc, off the top of the head legislation that has had to have amendments even before reaching the Senate for debate. It really is ridiculous that the Government did not agree originally to set up a Senate committee to right the rubbishy Bill the Government originally presented to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just more incompetence.
—It is complete incompetence from a government completely out of touch with reality-a government out of touch with what the people of Australia expect from their courts.

SPEECH.PARA: We propose to move an amendment permitting judges of the Family Court to wear robes. I hope that Senator Haines is correct when she says that acceptance of this amendment would result in its being almost mandatory for Family Court judges to wear robes, because that is what the majority want to do. When the Labor Government first introduced the legislation preventing the wearing of robes by Family Court judges it hoped that it would make the Court more informal and bring it to the people. I can remember the debates on this very clearly. Members of the Labor Government said, `We have too much formality'. This Labor Government, as have all previous Labor governments, has always acted in this way. Indeed, Senator Coates did not want to be called `senator' in this place. He went through the charade of trying to have himself called `Mr Coates'. The Australian Labor Party does not believe in having any recognition of a position.

What has been the result of the derobing of the Family Court judges? The result has been that people going before a judge have thought that it was just a man making decisions on what would happen to their children; that it was just a man taking away the property and giving it to the other partner. Because they think of the judge as just a man they can become very bitter. Indeed, this has resulted not only in extreme bitterness against a particular person but also in considerable violence and hundreds of thousands of dollars being spent on security for Family Court judges in particular. That has been a tragedy. I believe that when judges are robed people do not necessarily think of them as individuals but more as representatives of the law. I was delighted to find that the Australian Democrats will be supporting us in that regard because I believe that with the return of the robes the bitterness can be dissipated. I certainly hope so because it is very difficult for the judges to have to bear this personal animosity resulting from so many of their decisions.

As I said, the Government's introduction of the Bill has little to do with the betterment of the Court or the family situation. The Government has introduced it purely as a cost saving exercise. That has been underlined by the lack of funding for marriage counselling in the last couple of months. At one stage the Government cut the marriage guidance counselling service on the north-west coast of Tasmania. It was only after a tremendous hue and cry that we were able to get that back. If the Government is wanting to save money it should be trying to maintain family stability, not trying to cut costs by introducing divorce by post or by allowing magistrates to take over the very delicate tasks of Family Court judges.

I have great pleasure in supporting the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Durack. I am delighted that the Australian Democrats will be supporting some of those. I believe that the two amendments they have indicated they will support are very important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. It gives me the opportunity of talking about the functions and the criticisms that have been made of the Family Court. Senator Durack referred to a number of those criticisms. He considered that most of them were inappropriate to be directed at the personnel of the Court and that, to a large extent, they ought to be directed to the law which the judges are attempting to administer.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my view and the view of some of the people who have continually made representations to me, and presumably to many other members of parliament, that the judges of the Family Court are attempting to administer an unjust law. Instead of directing their concern against the individual judges and the persons who are involved in the Family Court structure, constituents should be directing their attention, quite justifiably I believe, to the law itself and to the fact that the representatives of the people have not given due consideration to the injustices that are perpetrated because of the inherent injustice of the law itself. It seems to me that the time is certainly overdue for another look at where we are at now 12 or 13 years on from the establishment of the Family Court following the passage through this Parliament of the Family Law Act.

In the other House the Opposition attempted to establish a committee to consider the provisions of this legislation. I would have supported such a proposal because I think it is important to enable persons who are likely to be affected in this jurisdiction to have their say through their committee system. I will deal with that shortly. But I believe that the time is ripe for a further look at the whole of the family law area and the effect that the Family Law Act has had on people's personal lives and, indeed, on the court system itself.

There are some very fine words in the Family Law Act about the meaning of marriage and the need for people, society and government to give support for the institution of marriage. They are very fine words indeed; but much of the fine print of the legislation runs completely counter to those fine words. Indeed, the administration of this legislation by the Government runs counter to those fine words. The Federal Government has failed to give families in crisis realistic support that will help them to stick together. Honourable senators will remember the last election campaign and the theme, `Let's stick together'. What is the fundamental institution of society as stated by the Family Law Act? It is none other than marriage and the family. If the Government cannot provide the wherewithal and the support to enable the fundamental institution of society to stick together, where is its election promise? Where is its election platform? Or is it just meaningless propaganda? This is a tragedy particularly at a time when marriage breakdown is a major cause of poverty in Australia.

The cost of marriage breakdown to Federal taxpayers runs into $2 billion per year, and there is, of course, a greater personal cost in the trauma and grief of those directly involved. The number of divorces in the period 1976-86-I do not have the 1987 figures; I do not think they are available-was 477,381. In the same period the number of children of marriages ending in divorce was 573,517. I understand that is the first time that that figure has been provided to anyone. It is hot off the press from the Statistics Group of the Department of the Parliamentary Library. Since 1976 at least 573,517 children have been affected by marriages that have ended in divorce. That is the sort of trauma and grief that is not reflected in the cash amount, the cost burden, as it were, to the Federal taxpayer of $2 billion a year.

Yet let us look at the sums of money that are made available to reconciliation services and to marriage education services in Australia. They are relatively paltry amounts. In the financial year 1986-87, the Government made a cut of 6 per cent in real terms in the funds for approved marriage counselling organisations. In that year it meant the closure of a number of counselling centres in metropolitan and rural areas, the retrenchment of a number of qualified counsellors trained by marriage counselling organisations, a notable increase in the waiting time for marriage counselling services, and an increase in the operating deficits of approved marriage counselling services. There was a hue and cry about that. I was unashamedly involved in that hue and cry. As Senator Walters said, there was a threat to close down two marriage counselling services on the north-west coast of Tasmania, and a number of marriage counselling services were closed throughout the length and breath of Australia.

Late last year, Senator Peter Walsh opened the conference of marriage counselling services in Western Australia and said, `Oh, there must have been some sort of mistake'. He then gave an undertaking on behalf of the Government-I know that there had been a great fight between the Attorney-General's Department and Finance on the matter-that funds would be made available and the shortfall would be taken up. As a result, additional funds were earmarked for marriage counselling organisations. I had some figures, but I just cannot lay my hands on them. However, the end result is that it still does not deal adequately with this question of money for reconciliation services. The marriage counselling reconciliation services still have shortfalls.

There are still waiting lists of persons who are seeking the services of reconciliation counselling. Furthermore, any expansion by these services is brought about largely by the charging of fees. It is not generally known and, in fact, it is quite disconcerting to me to see that the amount of money that persons who are genuinely seeking to reconcile their differences have to pay per interview in at least one State is $30 a session. In my State of Tasmania, which I believe has the lowest rates for these services, the fee is $12 or $13 a session.

There is something to be said for some nominal contribution being made by the person seeking to obtain the services of reconciliation counsellors, but not to that extent. My concern is for the lower income families where there has been separation or where some difficulty is being experienced in the marriage, because those people sometimes find it difficult to have the wherewithal to go into these reconciliation counselling sessions. I make it clear here that many of the reconciliation counselling services will, in fact, attempt to waive that particular amount, but that makes them further behind in their deficits. All is not rosy in that area and the net result is that the Government is really being kind to the divorce sector, that is, to counselling for divorce, and is not supporting marriage maintenance counselling to the extent that it ought to be supported.

For every $40 of taxpayers' funds spent on picking up the pieces of marriage breakdowns, only one cent is spent on support for reconciliation and marriage counselling services. That is an absolute tragedy. I believe the Government should not feel in any way that it is doing justice to that situation; in particular, the Department of Finance should not feel that way when giving consideration to estimates this year. Not only is the marriage maintenance area being neglected but also pre-marriage education is being neglected. In the last financial year the Federal Government limited its funds for the purpose of pre-marriage education to a paltry $100,000. In my State that meant that $500 was made available for pre-marriage education. What a disgrace! Is that not an indication of the way that people in the Government, or the departments which are handling finance, view these major questions?

The Bill does a number of things, including seeking to transfer to courts of summary jurisdiction, as prescribed, certain areas of divorce. That is an area which I believe trivialises marriage and should be opposed. I hope it will be opposed in this chamber, and I shall say more about that at the committee stage. I have listened with interest to the speakers who have preceded me. I believe it was Senator Reid who said that the work of the Family Court was possibly more stressful than that of other courts. I believe we should understand that, but we should make sure that the blame is placed where it belongs-that is, here, and not on the personnel of the Court. The blame can also be placed on the administration of the counselling area because largely the court counselling service is given over to divorce counselling and not reconciliation counselling.

When the committee stage is reached, further discussion will be held, and I shall leave to that particular stage my comments on the trivialisation of marriage that is inherent in the proposed legislation. In the meantime, I hope the Government does not sit back and say that it has done a good job on the further money that has been granted to reconciliation counselling services because, as I am advised, that is not dealing with the problem in the fashion it deserves to be dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move an amendment foreshadowed by Senator Haines in her speech that was the subject of some discussion and some minor changes from the first draft that was circulated in the chamber. This is a revised draft and I shall read it so that people have the correct one. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate considers-

(a) that the salaries and conditions of service of Family Court judges should more closely approximate those of Federal Court judges, as, in its opinion, the expertise, workload and status of the judges in each court are equivalent; and
(b) that the passage of this Bill should be seen as just one step in a process leading to the possible amalgamation of the Family and Federal Courts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. The Bill is the companion of the Family Law (Amendment) Bill of 1987, which was debated in the Senate in the dying days of the last session of Parliament and which, sadly, did not get the full ventilation that it thoroughly deserved. Debates on family law legislation such as this and, by necessity, divorce always attract subjectivity and are invariably of a fixed and emotional nature. During my last address on this proposed legislation, I touched on the matters that were raised by Senator Harradine, very properly, in a very articulate way today. It appears that the Government seems to spend too much money at the wrong end of the process.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms, the Bill proposes three changes to the Family Law Act of 1975. The first, by clause 9, allows Family Court judges to make rules of court delegating to judicial registrars all the powers of the Court. Next, the Bill extends the jurisdiction of magistrates courts to include undefended applications for dissolution of marriage and increases the level of the value of property for which applications may be instituted directly in such courts of summary jurisdiction. Finally, the legislation seeks to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Family Court by allowing judges to deal with a variety and a collection of subject matters not otherwise within the Court's specialist jurisdiction.

The reasons behind these changes are obvious: the administration of family law by a separate specialist court simply has not worked. The Family Court, by any objective measure, in its present form is simply a failure. That there have been problems in attracting judges to the Family Court cannot be doubted. Mr Justice Kirby, for instance, has commented on a number of occasions that there is within the profession a condescending attitude towards family law practitioners and the standing of the Family Court. Where such an attitude prevails amongst the profession, it is surely asking too much of the ordinary Australian to have any great confidence in the operation of the Court and the family law system. The former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, also commented on the deficiencies of the Family Court in an address to the Australian Legal Convention in 1985. He said that the creation of that Court had made it difficult to maintain high standards in the making of judicial appointments. He added:
Past experience in Australia does not support the view that specialized experience is necessary to render a judge able to deal with matters of family law.

Surely the best solution to the many problems of the Family Court is to transfer the jurisdiction either to the State Supreme Courts, for example, or to a division of the Federal Court. Indeed, the report of the Advisory Committee of the Constitutional Commission on the Australian Judicial System, otherwise known as the Jackson Committee, indicated:
In retrospect, there was much to be said for vesting Federal family law jurisdiction in State family courts on the Western Australian model.

The Family Court of Western Australia, as we all know, is unique in that it is the only State family court established under section 41 of the Family Law Act. By being a State court it has been able conveniently to administer both the State and Commonwealth law and it has avoided many of the judicial and practical problems which have resulted where part of a family court is covered by Federal law and where part is covered by State legislation. To the best of my knowledge there has been no view to the contrary that the Family Court of Western Australia has been a great success. Yet it is interesting to note that, with the exception of the chairman of the judges, all judges in the Family Court of Western Australia are equal in status to the judges of the District Court of Western Australia. In the event, however, the Jackson Committee thought it inappropriate that jurisdiction be transferred to the States. I think that is a view that is held by many, for whatever reason.

Although the Committee did not actually recommend a particular course of action for reconstructing the Family Court, in its final report it did tentatively adopt an option in its statement of preliminary views in February 1987. The Committee suggested that the preferred course would be to renovate, to re-equip and to further staff the Family Court to a level appropriate to that of a Federal superior court so that at some time in the future it could be reborn as a new division of the Federal Court. Whether the jurisdiction of the Family Court is transferred to the States or whether it becomes a part of the Family Court, it is my view that some positive action must be taken, or at least after a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It is certainly pointless to take bandaid, remedial action with the Family Court as it presently stands when proper and urgent reform is clearly necessary. The entire jurisdiction needs re-examining. The better solution, of course, if the Federal Court proposal is to be accepted, is surely to transfer the jurisdiction now and to restructure the Federal Court generally along the lines suggested by the Jackson Committee.

I turn now to the particular changes which are proposed in the Bill. Clause 9 of the Bill proposes the creation of a new office of the judicial registrar, who will be delegated all or any powers of the Court. The judicial registrars will fulfil a role similar to that presently being performed by masters in the State Supreme Courts. In my opinion the use of judicial registrars is basically sound because it will allow speedier resolution of many quite important interlocutory matters which are currently being handled by judges and will leave the judges freer to deal with the more complex litigation. There are, however, some aspects of concern in relation to the appointment of the judicial registrars. The first relates to the fact that they, as I have mentioned, will be delegated all or any powers of the Court. Although the stated aim of the creation of the new office is to enable judges to be free of minor and procedural matters, the wording of the proposed section 26b makes it plain that any matter within the jurisdiction can be delegated to the judicial registrars. Notwithstanding that the rules of the Court delegating these powers are subject to the normal powers of disallowance procedures applicable to statutory regulations, it is quite possible that these judicial registrars could be called upon to determine very complex issues of law which they simply may not be legally qualified-or at least qualified in any measure-to deal with.

Proposed section 26f amplifies the seriousness of the way in which section 26b is drafted in that it proposes that a judicial registrar is not subject to the direction or control of any person or body in the exercise of the power delegated under section 26b (1). I have always held the view that once power is delegated there ought not to be interference in the application of the delegated power. However, I make that point in highlighting the powers that can be transferred to these judicial registrars. It is also of concern to me that under proposed section 26 the judicial registrars are able to be appointed for specified and specific terms not exceeding seven years although, of course, they are eligible for reappointment.

This provision, in my view, has the capacity of casting a shadow over the integrity and independence that these judicial registrars must have if they are to be accorded their proper respect from the profession and the participants, which is so vital if they are to fulfil their functions properly and effectively. For them to be engaged virtually at Her Majesty's pleasure and to be subject to perhaps perceived political appointments is bad in principle and will hinder the success of any Family Court restructuring. It is quite ludicrous that under proposed section 26n judicial registrars shall hold office under such terms and conditions as shall be determined by the Governor-General. The only terms and conditions upon which they are appointed ought to be set out in a clear way in the legislation before us. This is real `trust me' legislation and it is something that in relation to this Government we ought not to be doing.

In relation to that part of the Bill which extends the family law powers of courts of summary jurisdiction, I will comment on the provision contained in new subsection 46 (1) (b). This provision seeks to allow proceedings to be instituted in magistrates courts with respect to property with a value exceeding the amount in relation to which the court has jurisdiction in an action for the recovery of a debt. Currently, of course, proceedings for property can be instituted in courts of summary jurisdiction without consent only when the value of the property does not exceed $1,000. I say at the outset that I am totally opposed to increasing the jurisdiction at present given to State magistrates courts.

It is quite plain-and I think the view is held by most people-that merely because a proceeding involves a relatively small financial amount, that does not mean that the matter may not be complex. For example, under section 79 of the Family Law Act any court making an order in proceedings in respect of property is required to take into account a wide range of matters, including all of those matters considered for maintenance applications under subsection 75 (2). With due respect, and without in any way denigrating courts of summary jurisdiction, I suggest that when magistrates are deciding proceedings for property which does not exceed $1,000 in value, they would be less concerned with the finer points of the Family Law Act and perhaps less reticent to make final orders.

The proposal contained in the present Bill seeks to give magistrates jurisdiction in property matters to the value of the summary court's present debt jurisdiction. That amount can vary. In Queensland it is $5,000 and in Victoria it is $40,000. I will touch on the practical consequences shortly. Pegging the property jurisdiction to the particular magistrates court's debt level is completely arbitrary and totally contradicts the fact that the Family Law Act is by any measure supposed to be a uniform Federal law.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we will move an amendment, Senator. I agree with you.

—Thank you, Senator Tate. On a practical level I have no hesitation in suggesting that, by so tying jurisdiction, the complexity of the Family Law Act will play a far greater role in determining whether a magistrate makes the proper order or whether the proceedings are transferred back to the Family Court. It ought to be noted that the magistrate has an option under subsection 46 (1) (b) to the effect that instead of transferring the proceedings to the Family Court he may send the proceedings back to the Supreme Court of the State or Territory in which he has jurisdiction. I suppose it is a matter for him to judge whether to transfer it back to the Family Court or to the Supreme Court.

SPEECH.PARA: It is plain that magistrates, through no fault of their own, simply do not have the prerequisite experience or knowledge to deal with complex issues which often arise in property proceedings. If this proposal goes ahead, there is no doubt that many more property applications will be transferred back to the Family Court, as magistrates simply will not be willing to take the responsibility of applying what by any measure can be judged to be complex considerations of the Family Law Act when considerably higher money values are at stake. Consequently, the primary purpose for using courts of summary jurisdiction in the first place-that is, to provide for speedier resolution-may have the reverse effect.

I make one final point on this aspect of the Bill. This proposal is quite ludicrous when one considers the circumstances surrounding application of the law in a town such as Albury-Wodonga. I do not know whether anyone has mentioned in the debate that that township is divided by the River Murray. Victoria is on one side and New South Wales is on the other and the jurisdiction varies, depending on which side of the river one lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can gamble on one side but not on the other.

—In this case one is doing more than gambling. Finally, I turn to that part of the Bill which seeks to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Family Court by providing it with jurisdiction to deal with a variety of subject matters that are not otherwise within the family law jurisdiction but have been cobbled together to give it, apparently, some sort of credibility or respectability. Parts IV to VII of the Bill seek to give jurisdiction to the Family Court in income tax appeals, bankruptcy proceedings, proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, and matters in relation to the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act.
—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional orders the debate is interrupted. The Senate will now proceed to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to speak today to respond to some remarks made in the Joint Sitting by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney. I thought the remarks he made were in some ways quite extraordinary and not appropriate for a Joint Sitting, but I think they did indicate the frustration of the Liberal Party. In particular, his remarks related to the fact that the Australian Labor Party is selecting party bureaucrats, namely, State and Federal secretaries, to become senators. He named in particular Senator Richardson, Senator Beahan, myself and of course Senator McMullan, suggesting that this was some extraordinary indication that the Australian Labor Party was out of touch with the public. I think that indicates that Senator Chaney and the Liberal Party have a great sense of frustration that over the last decade or more people such as Senator Richardson, Senator Beahan, Senator McMullan and me have been extremely successful in organising election campaigns that have defeated the Liberal Party. If one went through and counted the number of election campaigns that the four of us have been involved in organising and directing since we became full time officials of the Party in the mid-1970s one would find that our track record is for me personally a very proud one, and it is certainly a record the others would be proud of. I would think between us we have probably won 15 to 20 Federal and State elections and by-elections.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it indicates further that Senator Chaney is rather spooked by the fact that he has to sit opposite and see on the Government benches people who have helped in the demise of the Liberal Party and helped to defeat it. The fact is that not since October 1980 has the Liberal Party won either a State or a Federal election on mainland Australia. It is an indication that Senator Chaney accepts the fact that no longer is the Liberal Party the natural government of Australia or a majority of the States. It was interesting to note the enthusiasm of Liberal Party members during the Joint Sitting because of their success in the Adelaide by-election. That did remind me of what the Labor Party was like in the 1950s and 1960s when we lost election after election and at one stage were not the government of any State, let alone at the Federal level. When we occasionally won a by-election we took it as a great victory. But the thing is, after a by-election, when you wake up next morning with a hangover the other side is still the government. That is the case now. We may have lost the Adelaide by-election but the fundamental position is still that the Australian Labor Party is the Government of Australia.

To me, Senator Chaney made a sort of psychological slip during the Joint Sitting, and in fact he was virtually giving the game away because of the frustration resulting from the fact that the Liberal Party is a long-term Opposition. The Liberals will have momentary successes; politics is like that. But the fundamentals have changed in Australian politics and the Liberal Party's domination again in Australia is a long, long way off-if it happens at all.

One is reminded of the extraordinary events during the last 12 months, when the 78-year-old geriatric Premier of Queensland destroyed the coalition in three days. He ruined any chance it may have had to win the last election, and we had the bizarre spectacle of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, going to Brisbane to plead with this old man, `Please don't attack us, please don't ruin my chances of becoming Prime Minister'. Of course the Premier of Queensland dismissed Mr Howard in a matter of seconds. The fact that a 78-year-old geriatric who could not put more than three sentences together without tripping over himself could destroy the coalition so effectively shows the impotence of the Liberal Party.

The Liberal Party has to face it: it is in an extraordinarily difficult situation. The Liberal Party created by Alfred Deakin 60-odd years ago is not the Liberal Party of today. The Liberal Party of Sir Robert Menzies is not the Liberal Party of today. I think that is sinking into many members of the Liberal Party, not the least being John Elliott, who only recently said that at the last election the Liberal Party was not fit to govern. However, I am not a great advocate of John Elliott. I really do not think the Australian people would see John Elliott as a potential Prime Minister. I think they will draw the line at having a can of Fosters beer representing the leadership of the Liberal Party and particularly the leadership of Australia. But he did have the honesty to state very strongly his opinion about the weakness of the Liberal Party. Though in many ways I am pleased that Senator Chaney took the opportunity, in the historic Joint Sitting, only the second that has taken place, I understand, since Australia's Federation--

TALK.START.PARA: —The third.

—The third; there have been only three in 87 years. I am glad that he took the trouble to mention four former officials of the Labor Party. I take it as a great honour that he believed we needed to be attacked and abused, and he called us, in a pejorative way, apparatchiks. I am proud of the term `apparatchik' because of the success I helped bring to the Labor Party. I noticed Andrew Peacock called Mr McMullan, now Senator McMullan, a kneecapper. The only people Bob McMullan kneecapped were in the Liberal Party. He did it for three Federal elections in a row. We think he did a superb job on behalf of the Labor Party. I know the Liberal Party would not agree with that. Liberal Party members may not think party officials are appropriate, and they may well be right if they look at their own party officials. I look forward to the day when the Liberal Party looks at putting Tony Eggleton in the Senate. Having lost three elections in a row, will he be suitably qualified for this place? Other Liberal State directors have not seemed to make it here, other than, I think, Mr Carlton, who did not have great success as shadow Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, Madam Acting Deputy President, I thought Senator Chaney psychologically gave the game away and I was trying to think of what sort of image he has of people such as Senator Richardson, myself, Senator Beahan and now Senator McMullan. The only thing I could think of was that maybe he sees us as the equivalent of the four horsemen of the apocalypse as far as the Liberal Party is concerned. I am not great on mythology, but as I understand it the four horsemen represent four things. The first horseman represents conquest. I would certainly say that the four former Labor Party party secretaries now in this House have certainly conquered the Liberal Party on more occasions than we have been conquered by them. The second horseman represents war. In the political war, our success has been outstanding. The Liberal Party has lost that war. The third horseman represents famine. Certainly, in the definition of political success, there has been a long famine for the Liberal Party. The final horseman represents death. As I said earlier, the Liberal Party is in its own internal death throes. So I think it is very appropriate to draw the analogy the four horsemen of the apocalypse in relation to the Liberal Party. I hope Senator Chaney enjoys in the years ahead looking across the table at Senator Richardson, Senator Beahan, Senator McMullan and me and being reminded of the success that we have obtained for the Labor Party and the lack of success the Liberal Party has had.
I thank the Senate for the opportunity of putting that position on behalf of what I think is an honourable profession, being a Labor Party apparatchik.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will delay the Senate only a few minutes in order to put on the public record what is a matter of public interest, or at least a matter of interest to one individual who took the trouble to write a short note to Senator Robert Wood and put it in the mail, marked `Personal and confidential'. Senator Wood was kind enough to provide me with a copy of this particular note because it did concern me. I quote from the contents of this particular note:

SPEECH.PARA: Bob: Suggest you make urgent inquiries about citizenship of James Philip McKiernan and that other Scottish member for Western Australia.
There is an imputation in there that I am Scottish, but I resent and reject that. I am not Scottish, never have been and none of my ancestors were either, to the best of my knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say you resented it, Senator?

—Resent and reject. I pride myself with being Celtic in origin but I do not claim to be from the Scottish part of the Celtic race. The fact of the matter, of course, is that I, like the rest of the senators in this chamber, am Australian-as indeed we have to be in order to comply with the laws-and to prove the fact I am lucky enough to have with me in Canberra this week my passport. As we all know from the events and debate that occurred in this chamber earlier this week, one has to have Australian citizenship in order to get an Australian passport. I have that with me and was able to show it to Senator Wood when he undertook those urgent inquiries this anonymous individual had taken the trouble to write to him about. I just make those few brief comments to put the matter on the record and save any other individuals, anonymous or otherwise, who may be interested in my citizenship the trouble of inquiring. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.56 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to a background briefing reported to have been given late last night by a spokesman for the Treasurer who is reported to have stated that the Government would never contemplate changes that would adversely affect accrued superannuation benefits. Can the Minister clarify this commitment?
—No, I cannot. I was not there. I did hear something along those lines this morning on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, but I do not know anything about it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Notwithstanding the answer that the Minister has given-I understand his difficulty in not having been present during the course of this background briefing-will he not agree, from the basis of his knowledge as the Minister representing the Treasurer, that he must have at least some understanding, even if he has not in fact inquired about the matter this morning-which I find surprising-of what was meant by this extremely important statement from the spokesman for the Treasurer?

—I really have nothing to add to what I said before. There is this allegation that a background briefing took place and that certain things were said. I do not know whether there was a background briefing, and if there was one, I do not know what was said.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources in his capacity as Minister for forests. Is the Minister aware that in an article appearing in the Hobart Mercury on 15 February the honourable member for Franklin, Mr Bruce Goodluck, is quoted as having said, `I will not support my party if they are going to give an inch to the conservationists.'? I will end the quote there; I will not be so unkind as to repeat what he said about Senator Puplick. Given that the Tasmanian Liberal Government has adopted in the past a similar attitude to Mr Goodluck's, is the Minister concerned that the current discussions being held with the Tasmanian Government, aimed at protecting National Estate values in the Douglas-Apsley region of Tasmania, will not be approached in a constructive manner? Is the Minister prepared to discuss the matter with the Federal Opposition Leader, John Howard, and the environment spokesman, Senator Puplick, prior to any decision being made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of divisions within the Opposition on the question of balancing the competing demands of conservation and development. Those divisions have lasted a long time and will last a lot longer. Senator Puplick's desperate and cynical attempt to turn the Liberals green will just not wash. No redneck like Bruce Goodluck will ever turn green. No National Party member will ever adhere to the new Puplick line on conservation. The Government is proceeding in good faith to discuss the problems in the Douglas-Apsley area with the Tasmanian Government. We have been considering the final management plan for the Douglas-Apsley region. My comment on that plan will be conveyed to my Tasmanian counterpart. If there are any unresolved problems, I have the right and responsibility to seek a formal consultation with Mr Groom. I reserve my position on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has no wish and no plan to start a confrontation with the Tasmanian Government on this issue. We want to examine the case on its merits. We want to balance competing claims and we want to take the best decision for Tasmania and for all Australians. In this process we would welcome constructive comment from the Opposition, but we have no reason to hope that any such constructive comment will be forthcoming. The Opposition's policy on conservation and development has been to put up for sale to the highest bidder. The Opposition has never developed a coherent or comprehensive policy. It has never addressed the basic principles involved, and it has never thought out the goals it should be pursuing. When it does, and when it wants to make a mature contribution to the debate, we will be prepared to listen.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and it follows the Minister's failure to answer the question from Senator Stone on the basis that he had not heard the statement and so on to which Senator Stone referred. Can the Minister give an undertaking that the Government will not make taxation changes that will adversely affect accrued superannuation benefits?

—There is something in the Standing Orders, about which I am not a great expert, about tedious and repetitious remarks. It is a pity it could not be applied to the Opposition during Question Time. The Opposition asked a question about this yesterday. I answered it yesterday and I have nothing to add to it today.

—I ask the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade about the presence of nuclear weapons in Australia. In asking this question I would point out that a global display at the Jimmy Carter Presidential Library in Atlanta, Georgia, of the known locations of nuclear weapons shows that in 1983 there were nuclear weapons at two sites in Australia, one in the interior of my State of South Australia and one apparently just across the Western Australian border. I believe the display was seen by you, Mr President, and I think also by Senator Bruce Childs and other members of a recent delegation to the United States of America. I also understand that the creators of the display have been unable to reconfirm the Australian map because the United States Government told them that the information was `classified'. My question to Senator Evans is: Does the Hawke Government accept as being accurate the Atlanta presentation showing that there were nuclear weapons in the interior of Australia in 1983? Is it possible that nuclear weapons were acquired or developed by this country in secret in earlier years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The location of a couple of light bulbs in a map in the Jimmy Carter museum does not seem, on the face of it, to count for very much by way of evidence. I can say absolutely and unequivocally that any suggestion that nuclear weapons are located in Western Australia, or indeed anywhere in Australia, is absolutely and totally incorrect. Australia does not, of course, produce nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. We are firmly committed to the Treaty for the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Under the South Pacific Treaty parties undertake, among other things, not to manufacture or otherwise acquire, possess or have control over any nuclear explosive device and to prevent in their territory the stationing of any nuclear explosive device. It is very difficult to know what on earth the map references or light bulbs could possibly be referring to. It is conceivable that they may indicate the sites of nuclear testing in the 1950s, that is to say, the Maralinga site and the Monte Bello islands, and nothing more than that.

ANSWER.PARA: Beyond that, any answer I make as to the reasons for that particular display being as it was would be utterly speculative. Certainly it is not based on any factual information of which I am or the Government is conceivably aware.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE USE AND EFFECTS OF CHEMICAL AGENTS ON AUSTRALIAN PERSONNEL IN VIETNAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the Minister aware that two eminent Swedish physicians, Dr Olav Axelson, Professor of Occupational Medicine at the University of Linhoping, and Dr Lemnart Hardell, Professor of Oncology at the University of Umea, who were eminent scientific witnesses before the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam-the effects of Agent Orange-have protested to the Prime Minister and the Governor-General that their scientific findings were deliberately distorted and misquoted both before the Commission and in the Commission's report? Furthermore, is the Minister aware that the Government has not responded to their objections and that they are now seeking redress for their damaged reputations in the form of a donation of $35,000 towards their research program? What is the Government's response to these objections? Does the Government intend to recompense these eminent scientists in some way?

—I am aware that Dr Axelson and Dr Hardell, in letters to the Governor-General, criticised certain aspects of the report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam, and that Dr Hardell has recently repeated these complaints and asked for $35,000. The complaints by Dr Hardell and Dr Axelson form part of submissions to the Government and the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia. In order to provide a considered Government response to the Royal Commissioner's report, and the submissions from the Vietnam Veterans Association, the previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs, as Senator McLean is well aware, engaged a ministerial consultant to assist in preparing proposals to go forward to Cabinet. That matter is still in process. The Government's response to the Royal Commission report and submissions from the Vietnam Veterans Association will be announced after Cabinet has considered the matter. The implication, I think, is that the issue of the complaints by the two Swedish scientists will be dealt with in that context.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ANTARCTIC PENGUINS: INJECTION WITH RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and Minister responsible for Antarctic matters aware of the allegation by an Independent member of the Tasmanian House of Assembly that Antarctic scientists are injecting penguins with a radioactive sodium isotope for experimental purposes and that this has been confirmed by the Antarctic Division? What is the research program and what is its value? Has the Antarctic Division taken into account the effects that the experimental procedure could have on the environment and on the penguin population generally? Because of the circumstances in Antarctica are the experiments more dangerous or no more dangerous than the usual situation when isotopes are used in research projects involving animals, or is it true that whole penguin rookeries could be threatened by this procedure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the allegations concerning the injection of penguins with radioactive material. It is important to note that it is very dilute radioactive isotopes of which we speak-sodium 22, I am told. They have been used in research on penguins to study the efficiency with which they can convert food to energy. They are widely used for biological, medical and other scientific research purposes around the world. It is hardly a new procedure. It is used in all of Australia, including Antarctica. The current studies are on a small scale. They involve 15 adult penguins and 15 chicks from a rookery of 30,000 Emperor penguins near our Mawson station. There are very low levels of radioactivity present, so low that they cannot be detected against the background of natural radiation after 10 days. I am reliably informed that no harm is being done to the penguins-the penguins have not told me that yet but the scientists involved say so-and that no damage is being done to their rookeries or to the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst I have said that this procedure is not new and is a widely used technique around the world there is public concern about the injection of the penguins. Because of that I have directed that all use of radioactive isotopes for the injection of animals for research purposes be suspended and that the matter be immediately reviewed by the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee. I expect that the review will be able to take place in a matter of only a week or two. I will inform Senator Coates and the Senate of the results, but it will be done quickly. Then we can have a proper answer regarding the procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the Minister's reluctance to identify in the Senate yesterday specific examples of the cosy arrangements which he was prepared to state on the media were damaging Australia's economy. I refer the Minister to reports this morning that the Transport Workers Union (TWU) is threatening major strike action, described in one newspaper as transport chaos, to prevent revised transport arrangements being entered into by Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd which aim to reduce transport costs. Is the Minister prepared to say that this is an example of an attempt to preserve cosy arrangements against the national interest? What action has the Government taken to use its supposed influence with the trade union movement to ensure that the TWU does not carry out its destructive threatened strike action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to say whether the arrangement proposed by Caltex and possibly by other oil companies in respect of transport is in the national interest or otherwise.
—It is certainly more efficient, you would agree, economically?

—Certainly. If it leads to greater efficiency I would agree that it would be in the national interest that the change come about. But I am not in a position to make a judgment about that. Certainly it must be regarded by Caltex and other companies, if other companies are involved at this stage, as being in their interest. But I am not in a position to say that what is good for Caltex is necessarily good for Australia, as the honourable senator would appreciate.
—What is good for economic efficiency is important.

—Yes. I have already answered Senator Chaney's first interjection to the same effect. In a number of industries changes are made on a steady basis in order to try to improve efficiency. If efficiency is improved by those changes I suppose that it is fair to describe the pre-existing arrangements as cosy, if that is the appropriate expression to use.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the Transport Workers Union has threatened industrial action I am quite clearly in a position to say that it would not be in the national interest were it to take place. In so far as the question relates to steps which may or may not have been taken by the Minister at this stage to try to resolve that matter, I will have to take that part of the question on notice and obtain an answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training been drawn to an article in the Adelaide News newspaper of 4 February 1988 reporting Senator Vanstone's release of figures purporting to show, firstly, that South Australian unemployment has risen in every age group under the Labor Government and that, secondly, there are now fewer 15- to 24-year-olds employed than there were under the Fraser Government? Are Senator Vanstone's assertions on these matters accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. The first thing to note about it is that the starting point Senator Vanstone used for the claim was August 1982, when the descredited Fraser-Howard Government still had six or seven months of life left in it--
—Lies?

—Life and lies. She did that very deliberately because if she took the correct starting point for the changes that have occurred during the period of this Government the facts are exactly the reverse of what she claimed them to be. If one takes the most recent unemployment figures, that is, for January this year compared to January of 1983, when the Fraser Government was within two months of its death, employment rose from 534,000 to 596,000, an increase of over 60,000. Unemployment fell from 66,200 to 62,600, a fall of close to 4,000. The unemployment rate came down from 11 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of unemployment in the junior age group, 15 to 19 years, the number of people looking for full time work fell from 18,100 to 12,700, a fall of over 4,000 and of about 30 per cent. The number of people aged 20 and over looking for full time work also fell from 41,700 to 40,500. Having now given the facts, I would be very interested to hear from Senator Vanstone as to whether she set about fabricating the evidence to back up her assertions or whether she negligently allowed her name to be used by somebody else in promulgating this deceit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister or his Government yet taken action to ensure that a police investigation takes place into serious allegations of corruption on the Sydney waterfront relating to the need to bribe people in order to obtain delivery of cargoes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed yesterday in Question Time, I did speak yesterday afternoon to the Minister for Justice and the Attorney-General about the allegations of bribery being involved in achieving the release of cargo from Sydney container depots, which allegations were raised by Senator Chaney. I also spoke to them about some other possibly related matters and I believe appropriate inquiries, to the extent that they have not already been put in process, will be set in train as a result of that. If Opposition members have any further information on allegations of this kind, it is incumbent on them to pass these on to the appropriate law enforcement agencies. Certainly my office will be passing on to the appropriate authorities any information which we may receive regarding these allegations.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say one thing to untangle one element of confusion about this matter; that is, some Press reports do appear to confuse possibly illegal demands for money with additional charges being made by depot operators for weekend and out-of-hours delivery of cargo. However commercially or otherwise reprehensible one may think that some additional charging in that situation is, that is to be distinguished against illegal demands for what is effectively bribe money.

The final thing I want to say about all this is that it is a little disappointing that the Opposition is so obviously focusing its attention on these kinds of allegations rather than on the much more important and larger issue of achieving improvements in the efficiency and reliability of the Australian waterfront. As I said yesterday, and as was outlined in the very detailed Press release from the Prime Minister yesterday following a very extended and effective meeting with him, there is now a firm basis for hope that the Government's strategy will result in industry, trade union and waterfront acceptance of a broad package of measures to achieve substantial improvements in waterfront and port efficiency, productivity and reliability. It is only through appropriate structural reforms of this kind that the underlying causes of the present difficulties at Sydney container depots can be resolved and that these kinds of problems can be avoided in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary, Mr President. The Minister kindly advised us that appropriate inquiries will be taking place. In view of that response, I ask: By whom-Federal or State authorities? If it is to be State authorities, does this mean that New South Wales is the only State where this level of corruption proceeds unhindered by its Labor Government?

—I do not propose to answer that question, on the good advice of my colleague the Minister for Justice. But I will say that it is not only in New South Wales that matters of this kind have been brought to my attention.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen a recent survey of public attitudes to Australia's defence and security, conducted by the Sydney based international market research company Frank Small and Associates Pty Ltd and referred to in the Canberra Times of 11 February? Given the fact that 41 per cent of those polled were against the mining and export of uranium, with only 39 per cent in favour, is this not indicative of the way in which the Labor Government has lost touch with the voters by either changing or ignoring its policies, as it did by exporting uranium to France? Will the Government now make an effort to return to its original principled position and ban the mining and export of uranium altogether, or will the Government at least refuse to give in to pressure from certain elements in the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia who want to alienate further their traditional supporters, as well as Aboriginal people and conservationists, by opening up a third uranium mine at Rudall River?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of phrases in that question which I, as Minister, reject. I have seen the Press report-in fact I have a copy of it here-of the survey to which Senator Vallentine has referred. The first distinction I make is that I have read only the Press report; I have not seen the survey, and I do not propose to base any considerations on what the Press say about a report which I have not seen. I prefer to look at the source material. However, on what we know from the Press report, a number of observations can be made. In considering what is said in the report, there appears to have been some confusion in the minds of the respondents in that on the surface a number of contradictory replies appear to have been given. For example, the Press report cites 67 per cent of the respondents as being in favour of a defence relationship with the United States of America. It also cites 42 per cent of the respondents as approving of United States bases in Australia, while 37 per cent do not. I am not suggesting that those figures are at odds with the figures cited by Senator Vallentine, but they do throw up a number of other considerations relating to what the respondents thought they were responding to.

ANSWER.PARA: This leads me to the second observation from what appeared in the Press; that is, that I do not know what was the phraseology used or the terms of the questions put to the respondents. Until I have that before me, I do not know how it invites a response. But what I do know-this is apparent from the Press-is that the question on uranium exports followed a series of questions dealing with nuclear weapons, foreign bases or French tests. Taken in the context of that series of questions, it sets up a mind set in the respondent to regard exports of Australian uranium overseas as being somehow related to weapons and military use rather than to civil, energy or medical use. If it is being argued here that that mind set ought to apply, we as a government absolutely reject it. We as a government have insisted that Australian uranium exported overseas be used only in civil power generation. In order to enforce that, we have required countries receiving Australian uranium to adopt a comprehensive set of safeguards aimed at preventing the diversion of that uranium into military use. In terms of the way in which those questions were answered, we reject that there is any association between the peaceful use of Australian uranium as a fuel in the energy cycle and the military implications in the series of questions that appeared in the article referred to by Senator Vallentine.

The other aspect of Senator Vallentine's question related to Rudall River, which is a national park in the north-west of Western Australia, and to a uranium deposit known more properly as the Kintyre deposit. She asked what the Government intends to do about that. Senator Vallentine should know that the Government's policy is to develop three uranium mines-Nabarlek, Ranger and Olympic Dam. That is our position, and it should be well known to everyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I remind the Minister that France, to which Australia exports uranium, is not even a member of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. I ask the Government to prove beyond doubt, which I believe it cannot do, that Australia's uranium does not end up in the nuclear weapons industry. It is absolute nonsense for the Government to continue this ridiculous claim that Australian uranium is use only for civil generation.
—Order! What is the question?
—My question is: Will the Government prove that Australian uranium does not end up in the nuclear weapons industry in any nation to which we export uranium?

—Senator Vallentine will know, as it is common knowledge to all of those who have an interest in this debate, that Australian uranium is supplied to France in terms of the safeguards I referred to, that is, on the same basis as it is supplied to other destinations to which we export, and that those safeguards are observed. As to the question of proof, I can say that we are satisfied that that is the case. I do not know on what standard of proof Senator Vallentine wants me to embark, but I am happy for her to go through the procedures for safeguards if she wishes to satisfy herself on that score.

—My question is to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. On what principle is the Government operating in seeking to censor freedom of expression in the advertising industry and not doing so in the visual arts, literature, theatre, cinema and many other areas where the stereotyping of women is to be found? Why is stereotyping of women more offensive in advertising than in those other areas? Is the Government planning more social engineering by censoring or banning the stereotyping of women in literature, for example, and thereby wiping out the Mills and Boon section of the book industry?

—In response to the latter part of Senator Vanstone's question, I might say: Do not tempt me on Mills and Boon. The honourable senator's comment about social engineering is frequently used by members of the Opposition who, like Senator Vanstone, are unable to get progressive policies listed for women in the Australian community and, therefore, become so sensitive about the lack of commitment to women's issues within the ranks of the Opposition that they then talk about social engineering. If Senator Vanstone has read Setting the Agenda, she will know that the issue--
—That is not the bible.

—Senator Vanstone was just asking for the national agenda, but she would know that sex role stereotyping in terms of the portrayal of women in the media is of great concern to Australian women. That was identified clearly in the approach that the Government took in consulting Australian women, and I know that stereotyping of women was raised at more than half of the meetings that I attended.
—It would have been two.

—It happened to be more than 36, if Senator Vanstone wants me to boast about it. On the question the honourable senator asked, the Government is committed to responding in regard to an issue that Australian women view very seriously. I suggest that Senator Vanstone wait until the launch of the national agenda on 29 February and then she will be in a better position to understand the priorities of the Government in its response to the national consultation with Australian women.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has apparently not understood the question. The question was: Why is stereotyping of women more offensive in advertising than in the other areas I listed? In her response, the Minister indicated that the Government is concerned about sex stereotyping of women in the media.
