You, Mr President, and even members of the Government will understand that that is far broader than simply the advertising industry. My question concerns cartoons such as this Leunig cartoon, which informs men that if they want to look up a woman's skirt, they ought to avoid back injury by carrying a mirror on a stick. Is Senator Reynolds a bit blind? I have a bigger copy for her. Why is the Minister not concerned about that cartoon yet concerned about advertising? This is the media. That is the question: Why is the Minister concerned about or trying to do something about sex stereotyping in advertising and not in the rest of the media? Is not the answer: because the Minister knows that she is trying to censor free expression?

—I must admit that I am not quite sure what Senator Vanstone is driving at. If she would like to give me a copy of the cartoon that she finds offensive, I shall certainly take up her question and try to find a response that she finds more acceptable.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to recent publicity that Mr John Elliott, President of the Liberal Party, has appointed a former executive director of the National Farmers Federation (NFF), Andrew Robb, as manager of the Liberal Party's new strategy and campaigning unit on a rumoured six-figure salary. What economic lessons did the Government learn from the selection of issues and campaign of the National Farmers Federation in 22 marginal seats at the last Federal election, a campaign of which Mr Robb was a principal architect? What are the implications of that transfer of intellectual and organisational might from the National Farmers Federation to the Liberal Party for the quality of economic debate and the pace of economic adjustment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware that Mr Elliott or the Liberal party-I am not sure which is more correct-had appointed Andrew Robb to a position. Mr Elliott would like to appoint a few people to other positions in the Liberal Party. Principally, he would like to appoint himself to the Federal leadership. If anyone wishes to delve a bit further into that, and particularly into the triangular shouting match that took place after lunch following the last meeting of the Federal Executive of the Liberal Party, there is an excellent example in yesterday's--

—On a point of order, Mr President: Again we have the technique of a very narrow linkage between a question and matters that have nothing to do with the Minister and his ministerial responsibility. I ask you to ensure that the Minister does not simply engage in a lot of irrelevancies as far as the part of the question that related to his ministerial responsibilities is concerned.

—I thought that the first part of the question was out of order, but clearly the last part of the question, referring to economic stability, did refer to the Minister's portfolio. I remind the Minister that he should reply only to that part of his question which deals with his portfolio.
—Certainly, Mr President. I was asked, among other things, what effect Andrew Robb's transfer to the Liberal Party might have on the quality of economic debate, and so on.
—It is a matter of opinion.
—I suppose it is a matter of opinion, but I shall give Senator Archer a few examples if he will just be patient. In my opinion, it is not likely to enhance the quality of economic debate.
—Mr President, the Minister has just given rise to a further point of order, because he has just said `in my opinion'.
—You are a wimp, Chaney; you really are.

—Abuse from the Minister sits like a flower under my nose. Clearly, Mr President, the Standing Orders prohibit that, and the Minister has put himself outside the Standing Orders. He should be sat down.
—Order! I ask the Minister to answer the last part of Senator Foreman's question, which part was clearly within his area of responsibility.

—Mr President, perhaps I may simply repeat the point of order. I was not making the same point of order. I was referring to the fact that questions shall not ask for an expression of opinion. Clearly, the Minister is not entitled to offer his opinion, which is what he is doing. He is supposed to be giving the House facts. The Minister has described what he was about to say as his `opinion'. Therefore, I ask you, Mr President, to call him to order and to move on to the next question.
—On the point of order, Mr President: I explicitly said that I was about to give Senator Archer some facts.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I shall repeat the ruling that I just gave, and that is that Senator Walsh is entitled to answer that part of the question which was within his portfolio.

—Mr President, may I say that I welcome the appointment of Andrew Robb to the Liberal Party for two reasons. Firstly, he will now be correctly labelled as a Liberal Party apparatchik, whereas formerly he was misleadingly labelled as a representative of the farmers while behaving like a Liberal Party apparatchik. Secondly, he is so incompetent and has such a record of incompetence and error in economic debate that he will assist the Labor Party's chances of being re-elected in his new capacity as a member of the Liberal Party staff, just as he did when he was working for the National Farmers Federation. Andrew Robb was the architect of the brilliant National Farmers Federation strategy on how to get interest rates down by pushing the consumer price index up by 6.5 per cent. That was the formula of the National Farmers Federation for bringing interest rates down-push up the consumer price index by 6.5 per cent!
—You are a hopeless coward, Walshie.

—One of the greatest wimps who ever drew breath has the audacity to call somebody else a coward. I ask him why he was not in the shouting match after the Liberal Party Federal Executive meeting. He left it all to Howard, Elliott and Andrew Peacock while he just ducked right out of the responsibility.
—Order!

—I am sorry, Mr President, but I was provoked. The author of the brilliant National Farmers Federation economic strategy to get interest rates down by pushing up the consumer price index by 6 1/2 per cent has now left the NFF and gone to the Liberal Party where, I presume, he will continue to do the same sort of work. I might add also that there was about the same proportion of serious factual errors in the Robb NFF proposal as there was in the Howard taxing, spending and revenue Budget alternative at election time. Mr Robb is also on the record as saying on 19 February last:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Labor Party's prospects for re-election were falling rapidly.
On the same date, Mr Robb said:
. . . Sir Joh's push also was likely to increase the non-Labor vote.
He also said:
There was no sign that the Government was prepared to take necessary decisions to cut expenditure and curtail wages growth.

That was three months, if I may say so, before the Government introduced a statement which took $4 billion off the Budget deficit and some $1,500m off recurring government outlays. Mr Robb's record as a political soothsayer and economist is of a type to make him very well qualified to be appointed to the Liberal Party's staff.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHRISTMAS ISLAND CASINO: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST MINISTER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. I remind the Minister that during the censure motion against him on Tuesday he referred to the fact that his Senior Private Secretary and a senior officer of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) combined to produce a document which summarised part of Federal Police advice and which he actually tabled during his answer to the question that was put to him on Tuesday. I ask: Does the Minister agree that he, his office and the Federal Police all knew about the existence of this document and yet on two occasions, firstly in answer to Senator Tambling on 14 December and then in response to the Opposition's freedom of information (FOI) request, he did not acknowledge its existence? Even if the Minister asks us to believe that his office did not retain a copy of the document, how can he possibly explain the failure to mention it on these occasions? Is the reason that to acknowledge its existence would have indicated that the Federal Police advice had to be qualified in some way and that would have cast doubt on his definite assertion that the police had never had any reservations about Dr Stanley Ho's connection with Federal Hotels Ltd-in other words, to disclose it would have revealed that he did indeed mislead the Senate on 14 December?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mislead the Senate on 14 December in the way that has been suggested. The fact is that when I came into the Senate chamber on that date I had the brief of 14 September and 30 November, though I must admit that at the time this was raised on 2 and 3 February and right up until 11 February I had no recollection of the form in which I had an additional notation to help me give a full answer, consistent with confidentiality as advised to me, to the Senate. In other words, quite frankly, after the answer on 14 December I thought no more about the matter until it was raised on 2 February.

ANSWER.PARA: It would appear that at the end of the session my particular parliamentary question brief was culled and the note provided for me in order to give that full answer to the Senate was disposed of in the culling. But it appears that the AFP had the brief of 14 September obviously, the brief of 30 November as returned by me with a notation, and the two documents which were aids to me in giving the answer. In fact, had I known of their existence on 2 February I think I would have been helped in the preparation of my defence, if you like to put it that way, in that I could have asserted, as I was able to do during the censure motion, that indeed Chief Superintendent Whiddett and my Senior Private Secretary had composed an answer for me in order to abide by the advice given to me as to confidentiality.

But it was only on Thursday, I think it was, 11 February-possibly late in the day, but I do not suppose that is relevant-that the AFP informed my office that in trying to fulfil an FOI request for documents relating to this matter it had found the 30 November brief with my notation and the two documents which, as I say, were the form of words which I used to the Senate chamber. I was very happy that it had and therefore, of course, when I rose to make my statement in answer to the censure motion, I made them available to the Senate, as I understood them to be being made available to the FOI inquirer. I think that is all I can say. That was the sequence of events.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate that the Minister has retailed to us what he believes to be the sequence of the events, but he has not answered the question, which was in two parts. Why, when he answered Senator Tambling on 14 December, did he not reveal to him that he was reading not only from a brief from the police but also from another document which had been provided to him when he said, in effect, `I have given you the whole of the brief'? That is the first part of the question. The second part is in relation to the freedom of information application which was referred to the police. The Minister acknowledges the police file contained a copy of the other document. In response to the freedom of information application the second document which the Minister used to assist him in his answer of 14 December was not revealed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will know that when Ministers come into the chamber they have their briefs, though mine were not in the form of parliamentary questions, available to them. Quite often I come in with shorthand notes, handwritten notes and little pieces of paper which are an aid to my giving an answer. That is what I had when I gave my answer to Senator Tambling. It is quite clear that, in fact, what I apparently used in the course of that answer was indeed those two additional documents, one of which Chief Superintendent Whiddett had put together and brought over on 10 December, the other of which was put together in the office between Chief Superintendent Whiddett and my Senior Private Secretary. I had them as aids to be able to give an answer. I did not regard them as the briefs which I had from the Office of the Australian Federal Police. They were the primary documents; the others were composed in order to enable me to give the response which I did. I did not regard them in any way as having the same status as those briefs which I had. They were aids to me to give a full answer. As such, they were just available to me and I used them. As to the question of my response to the FOI request, on 20 January 1988 I wrote to Mr Fryar, care of Mr Cowan, MP-I think this must be the relevant freedom of information request-saying the following:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to your request of 14 December 1987 under the Freedom of Information Act to the Australian Federal Police seeking access to documents relating to the Christmas Island Casino, Federal Hotels and Dr Stanley Ho.

Your request was transferred to my Office by the AFP on 23 December 1987. The transfer was in accordance with your request, but, of course, did not apply regarding documents in my possession which originated with the AFP.
A thorough check of my Office-
this was made, obviously, in early January-
has disclosed only two documents relating to this matter: both documents originated with the AFP and both dealt with their investigation into Federal Hotels Limited-
obviously the 14 September and 30 November briefs-
The AFP will have copies of these which will be dealt with in their reply to your request. There are no other documents in my possession that come within the terms of your request.

We had no other documents, they had obviously been either culled from the question file-this supplementary note that I had in order to assist in my answer-or in their original form had been taken back by the AFP after the question, but I think they had their own copy. My Press release states:
. . . Senator Michael Tate, today rejected suggestions that he had not properly complied with the Freedom of Information Act in relation to documents concerning the Christmas Island casino.
My response to the request was correct as to all relevant documents in existence and in my possession at that date.
These were the copies of the official briefs from the Australian Federal Police of 14 September and 30 November.
There is no obligation under the FOI Act to disclose documents which came into my possession subsequent to the response.
I only became aware of them on 11 February.
. . . the other documents which he tabled on February 16 were not held in his office at the time of the FOI request.
Copies of them were provided to Senator Tate on February 11 by the Australian Federal Police for clearance, prior to their release by the AFP to complete the FOI request by Mr Ray Braithwaite, MP.
These two remaining documents were speaking notes, prepared for question time.
When the question had been answered-and because the speaking notes were a summary of the formal AFP brief-they were not retained.
This is entirely in accordance with usual office practice.

I think that the campaign of distortion on this matter trying to suggest that I have set out to mislead the Senate in relation to the documents available to the Opposition under the FOI is completely unfounded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. My question relates to the recently announced New Zealand reform package. Has the Minister any information on how Australian companies would be affected if the same types of tax changes were introduced here?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, for about a week, been trying to get information about particular Australian companies that would shed light on the effects on those specific companies of the changes proposed for New Zealand as against the system in Australia. I have not yet been able to get information relating to particular companies, but there is enough information available to draw some conclusions.

ANSWER.PARA: Before going on to that, the whole question of international comparisons in tax rates is a complex one. The Australia-New Zealand comparison is no exception to that. The question of the tax rate applying in any country is only one of the factors which would be taken into account by potential investors in making a decision as to where to locate investment if they have that choice, demonstrated by the fact that the tax rate is irrelevant with profits of zero. At a level of profit twice as high in one country as it is or it could be in another country and a tax rate twice as high is a question that is irrelevant and, assuming again that the rate is irrelevant, other factors such as the rates of inflation, wage increases, interest rates and expectation as to where all those things are going in the future would also be taken into account.

What I do want to give some information on here is the fact that some people who have looked at the proposed New Zealand changes have ignored the changes to the taxation base and there are many of them, but I want to mention one in particular. The New Zealand package includes the imposition of a fringe benefits tax (FBT) at the rate of 24 per cent on employer contributions to superannuation funds, a de facto payroll tax which will vary in accordance with the percentage of salary paid by employers into superannuation funds. For example, if an employer paid 10 per cent of salary into a superannuation fund, the de facto payroll tax is almost 2 1/2 per cent and contributions of 10 per cent and even higher are not all that uncommon. Therefore, that is a factor which would be taken into account by any rational investor. The degree to which that FBT on superannuation contributions was a deterrent to investment in New Zealand would be a function of the ratio of wages to the capital base of a company and also of the level of superannuation contributions as a percentage of wages.

I have been provided with information which shows that if the company tax rate in Australia had been 20 percentage points lower in 1984-85-the reductions proposed in New Zealand are reductions of 15 per cent or 20 per cent, depending upon whether the investor is a domestic resident or not-and companies had had to pay the 24 per cent fringe benefits tax on their contributions to superannuation funds, just over 18 per cent of all Australian companies, public and private, would have paid more tax than they did without that broadening of the base of the FBT on superannuation contributions and the lower rate.

Given that the provision of superannuation has almost certainly significantly increased since 1984-85 we can be reasonably certain that at least that number of Australian companies would actually be worse off if the proposed New Zealand regime were to apply here.

The final point I want to make is that a number of knee jerk and woolly thinkers responded immediately to the New Zealand announcement by saying that the financial services-such as banking, consultancy and that sort of thing; industries where geographic location is not particularly important-can easily be transferred across international borders and we would all pack up and leave Australia for New Zealand.

As I said, I have not been able to get specific information about companies yet, but some of the attributes of the financial services of that industry are a relatively narrow equity base because capital investment is not particularly high, a fairly high wages base or a wage bill relative to that and relatively generous superannuation arrangements; in other words, the very type of business most likely to be deterred from locating in New Zealand because of the FBT on employer superannuation contributions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and follows the question asked by Senator Lewis. I ask the Minister: Has he had any discussion with the Prime Minister about the possibility of resignation from the ministry?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In the light of the Australian Labor Party Federal Platform Resolutions and Rules, which state in section 11.37.c that the ALP will oppose `mining or any other activity in national parks which adversely affects the prime function of the park, ie nature conservation' and will, as stated in section 11.54, `use Federal constitutional powers to achieve environmental legislation in all states . . . compatible with Federal legislation', and in the light of a report in the West Australian of 11 February 1988 headed `Ministers set to launch park mining policy', what steps will the Government take to prevent access to national parks in Western Australia being granted by the Western Australian State Government for the purpose of mineral exploration and mining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I can recall at one meeting with some Western Australian colleagues last year Senator Jenkins reading out some of the words she read out just then. I think the work on the Bailey report began in 1985. It reported last year and, in the lead-up to the Western Australian Government announcing its decisions on it, a number of ministerial colleagues and I had discussions with Premier Burke and some of his Ministers. At all of those meetings I have made sure that I stressed some of those words Senator Jenkins read out from the Australian Labor Party platform and I shall continue to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the report in the West Australian which talks about an imminent announcement on this question. I must say that that surprised me and, because of it, I have asked for another urgent meeting with the Western Australians, hopefully, prior to the time when they make an announcement.

In so far as what the Commonwealth Government will do to enforce its view or at least to enforce the ALP platform, I think there are constitutional difficulties that rear their ugly heads in the Commonwealth Government preventing Western Australia. At this stage of the game, short of World Heritage listing of all of Western Australia, I am not sure what else I could do-although I hasten to add that I am not proposing to World Heritage list all of Western Australia; some parts of it perhaps, but not all of it. I shall have to inform Senator Jenkins and the Senate of whatever the results are of the discussions that I have, not only with Western Australian Ministers but also with the new Premier, Mr Dowding, when he takes office, which I think will be in only a week's time. I have yet to discuss the issue at all with him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked by Senator Harradine a series of questions about the drug RU 38-486 and I have obtained some detailed answers to the questions of the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: He asked if the Roussel company had announced that because of possible adverse medical-legal consequences in the United States of America it would not market the drug in that country. Neither the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, nor his Department is aware of such an announcement. Roussel Australia was contacted and is not aware of such an announcement.

It is advised that the drug RU 38-486 is not marketed in the US. However, Roussel Paris has instigated clinical trials in the US in the first trimester abortion. Both these studies are in New York. Roussel also advises that clinical studies are currently under way in more than twenty countries, including the USA, Canada, France, Holland, Spain, Hungary, Scandinavian countries, Switzerland and China.

Australia has a very strict system of drug evaluation involving thorough scientific and medical scrutiny. There is no requirement for parliamentary approval for any specific drug and all approvals must be within the law. Any senator has the opportunity of raising issues within the forum of the Senate.

I respect Senator Harradine's personal attitude in relation to abortion. However, I point out that any trial of this drug would have to be within the law of the relevant State or Territory and would also be subject to approval by the ethics committee of the institutions where the trials were being conducted. The Secretary of the Department of Community Services and Health and the Minister, Dr Blewett, have informed me that an early decision will not be taken on the application for clinical trials of the drug for the purposes of legal early termination of pregnancy. In considering the application for clinical trials all data, including overseas evidence, will be carefully considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time, Senator Newman asked me a question relating to an answer I gave on 26 October 1987. Understandably, I could not recollect the exact terms of my answer on that date and I undertook to give Senator Newman a fuller answer after I had read the relevant part of Hansard. The question asked of me by Senator Newman on 26 October 1987 invited me to recollect an interview on the Four Corners program on 21 September 1987.

ANSWER.PARA: The transcript of that interview reveals that my contribution dealt with Mr Parker in particular and the role of National Crime Authority liaison officers and commissioners of police generally. Senator Newman then purported to quote my words from the interview, amongst others, in the following terms:
. . . when the stench of corruption reaches so high that the work the National Crime Authority may have been compromised.

Although Senator Newman has allowed the Hansard to be published with her attributing this quotation to me, they are not, of course, the exact words I used on the Four Corners program. To that extent it is Senator Newman who, in purporting to quote, presumably having the transcript of the interview, deliberately, knowingly or mischievously misled the Senate. What I actually said on that program was:

Well it does fill me with some foreboding and naturally I share the concern of all citizens when the stench of corruption reaches so high, but particularly in this particular instance where you have Mr Parker as liaison officer attending three operational conferences conducted by the National Crime Authority over the space of a year, my fears I think are well grounded, and for that reason I have asked Mr Justice Stewart to carry out an investigation to examine whether indeed the operations of the National Crime Authority were compromised.

I emphasise the words `so high' in the clause, `when the stench of corruption reaches so high'. That was my immediate response to Andrew Olle's question to me as follows, `Senator Tate in Canberra'-that was his first question:
I imagine you must be very concerned about this because of course the man in Queensland, Assistant Commissioner Parker, was the liaison officer for the National Crime Authority.

So Senator Newman's question that had a preamble which purported to quote me out of the Four Corners interview did not exactly quote and give the full context of that clause. Nevertheless, obviously it triggered the memory of the question and answer in my mind.

There is no doubt that the first part of the question put to me by Senator Newman on 26 October 1987 related to Mr Parker. I therefore answered in terms of Mr Parker's role as liaison officer in these terms:

In general I can assure the chamber and, indeed, those who are listening, that the National Crime Authority's operations and the protection of its witnesses-a point particularly raised by Senator Hill in a question a couple of weeks ago-has, as far as one can judge and on advice available to me from Mr Justice Stewart, not been compromised by the events surrounding, in particular, Mr Parker in his role as liaison officer with the National Crime Authority over several years.

In my answer on 26 October 1987 I went on to indicate the steps I had taken to try to ensure no repetition of this vulnerable situation for the National Crime Authority. Although Senator Newman in her question of 17 November 1987 sought to belittle those proposals, the National Crime Authority, police commissioners and the committee of Ministers thought otherwise. I can report to the Senate that those foreshadowed changes were adopted by the National Crime Authority Inter-governmental Committee on 25 November 1987. The answer I gave was therefore in direct response to the questions posed to me by Senator Newman. Her implication yesterday that she had not asked about Mr Parker is simply not correct in terms of the Four Corners interview which she chose to quote, or purported to quote. I could interpret her question no other way and I resent the inference that I had misled the Senate in my answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During Question Time, Senator Michael Baume asked Senator Gareth Evans a question which followed up a question I asked yesterday about the Sydney waterfront and the very serious backlogs which are being experienced in Sydney and which are affecting individual businesses and industries throughout Australia. Senator Evans said during his answer that I had asked this question yesterday and he also said that it was `unfortunate that the Opposition was concentrating on the issue of corruption' or words to that effect. The reality of the situation is that the question which I addressed to Senator Evans yesterday raised a series of concerns relating to the delays on the waterfront. The question related to the fact that there was a nine-week backlog which was putting small companies out of business. I referred to the fact that the backlog appeared to be getting progressively worse. I referred to allegations about bribes and I asked whether they had been investigated. I asked about industrial disputes and restrictive union work practices, particularly in relation to working hours and limits on the number of unpacks, which I stated were greatly exacerbating efforts to move the backlog, and I asked generally what action the Government has taken or whether it is a matter within the responsibility of the Unsworth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wanted to make the point, Mr President, that it was quite clear from my question that the Opposition has a wide range of concerns, I have a wide range of concerns, and I believe all those issues which I have raised are relevant to the quite serious problems which we face in Sydney. The reason for a follow-up question today on the narrower issue of corruption was that the Minister totally failed to address himself to that part of my question in his original answer and I had to ask a supplementary question, at which point the Minister advised us that he would that afternoon consult with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). It seemed in those circumstances to the Opposition and to Senator Michael Baume in particular that it was desir- able to find out what had transpired from the matters which the Minister indicated yesterday. I want to make it quite clear that, contrary to what was said by Senator Evans, the concerns which I raised yesterday were not on the narrow question-important as it is-of corruption on the waterfront--

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, the Press only alluded to that, which is a pity.

—It was on the broader issues. I do not wish to appear to be quibbling about a minor point but the reality is that this is a major problem which has been around for some time. Unfortunately, the Minister's answer referred to months: he talked about reports in March and later this year. I simply express my personal concern that this situation requires immediate action as well as the longer term action which has been indicated by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point of misrepresentation I would not have risen on were it a sole point, but I think the two together help to illustrate the difficulties of an Opposition in responding to matters raised by Ministers in Question Time. In response to some very rowdy interjections by me as to whether Senator Walsh was a coward, he made the point that I was a wimp because I had refused to take certain action in Adelaide at our last federal executive meeting. The simple reality is that I was in New Zealand on the day of our last federal executive meeting and was therefore unable to take part. I would not normally have made a personal explanation on this point, given that I was being extremely rude, and intentionally so, to Senator Walsh in response to what I felt was his quite unpardonable behaviour, but I make the point that it is difficult, Mr President, when your rulings, which are consistent with previous Presidents' rulings-that it is not for you to say in what manner Ministers will answer questions-leave oppositions in a difficult position when misrepresentations of fact are contained in Ministers' answers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to respond very briefly. I accept the first part of Senator Chaney's personal explanation concerning Senator Gareth Evans. In the second part Senator Chaney only widened the area of debate to consideration of the degree of his wimpishness. It is very difficult to say anything about that. Clearly, he should not have been in New Zealand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the new Parliament House, to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
This is the first opportunity I have had during our Bicentenary to provide honourable senators with a progress report on a significant bicentennial project-the new Parliament House.

I am pleased to report that the project is on schedule for the official opening by Her Majesty the Queen on 9 May 1988. The first in a series of major handovers of parts of the building took place, as planned, on 18 January when significant areas of the northern and central zones were consigned to the care and custody of the Parliament. Together they represent about one third of the total floorspace and include the Foyer, the Great Hall, the Members' Hall, the Queen's Terrace, some parliamentary offices on the ground floor, the public circulation areas, some Members' suites and the main kitchens and security accommodation.

At the same time as the handover, tests started on lighting around the entrance and along the curved and sloping walls at the northern end of the building. Work on the project is proceeding in accordance with the timetable for the handover of other areas from early March.
As in the past I will also provide a budget update for the project for the three months period from June to August 1987.
The revised building budget for the three months to August 1987 now stands at $879.22 million, with another $168.58 million for non building items.
The total project budget is therefore increased from $1026.9 million at May 1987 prices to $1047.8 million at August 1987 prices.
This updating includes $7.91 million for the effects of inflation in the three months period.

Additional components have been an allowance to cover the cost of industrial disputes, insolvencies of contractors and reinstatement of previously deferred or deleted works such as landscaping-costs outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority, i.e., $4.05m, $1.74m and $7.2m respectively, a total of $12.99m.

I mentioned in my previous report to you that we are looking to unions and contractors for their full co-operation and commitment to achieve substantial completion on target for the May opening and for the building to be operational in August.

As honourable senators can see from the report, some 11 short weeks before Her Majesty opens the new Parliament House, there can be no doubt about its readiness for the event. This could only have happened with the co-operation and commitment that the Minister asked for and which has so obviously been given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report to which the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has referred is a progress report on behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) on the new Parliament House and a budget update for the three months ending August 1987. I note in particular that point: it is a budget update for the period only to the end of August 1987. Therefore, the financial side of the report is almost six months out of date. I find that strange and worrying with such a short period to go before the completion of the building and, as is said in the report, with only 11 weeks to the official opening of it by Her Majesty the Queen. I will come back to that a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I welcome the progress report. This report is part of a regular series of reports that the Minister for Administrative Services has been making to the Parliament on the progress of the new Parliament House. I welcome the Minister saying in his statement that the project is `on schedule for the official opening by Her Majesty the Queen on 9 May'. Later in the report-I will come back to this in slightly different words later-it states that the building will be operational in August. All senators who have seen the new Parliament House in recent times would agree that it is starting to look a magnificent building. I am sure that is going to be the case when we see it completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't agree, but I don't want my dissent recorded.
—Let's recognise that as a weighty contribution.
—It is. I thank the Minister very much for that telling contribution on behalf of the Government, by the Leader of the Government, the third most senior--
—That is my personal view, which you will find expressed in Hansard going back to 1978, Senator.
—I would not accuse the Minister of inconsistency.
—You would be the only one.

—It would be one of the few things on which I would not accuse him of inconsistency. I personally think the building will look magnificent. Although many times in the past we have queried the cost and size of the project, I say to the Minister that we on the Opposition side are pleased that the project is on schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several matters of concern in the statement. As I said, the financial aspect in relation to the budgetary side of the project is almost six months out of date. It relates only to the period ending August. The other thing I note is that once again there has been a further blowout in the budget. The total project cost in the three months to August 1987 increased by a further $20.9m to an estimated figure of $1,047.8m. The increase of a further $20.9m in that three-month period is made up of $7.91m due to the inflation factor, $4.05m due to continuing industrial disputes, $1.74m due to insolvency of contractors, and $7.2m due to the reinstatement of previously deleted works such as landscaping. When the last progress report was made to this chamber on 9 October 1987 the Minister talked very loudly about the Government not being prepared to put up with any further industrial disputation and about the fact that the opening would go ahead regardless and that contractors and unions should note the Government's firmness of intent in relation to completing the building.

The implication was that the Government would be tough and, as a result, industrial disputation would not be a problem to the same degree that it had been. That statement was made in October 1987. It related to the report of budgetary figures to the end of May. We now have figures for the three months to the end of August, which is still earlier than the time at which the last report was given. In that three-month period to August 1987 there was an additional cost to the taxpayer of $4.05m due to industrial disputes.

The previous report, the October 1987 report, which dealt in budgetary terms with the nine months to the end of May 1987, showed the cost of industrial disputes for those nine months to be $9.9m. So we are comparing $9.9m for a nine-month period with $4.05m for the ensuing three-month period. In other words there has been a cost blow-out due to industrial disputes of $13.14m in the year to the end of August 1987. The equally serious-if not more serious-concern is that those figures reveal an escalation in the cost of industrial disputes in the latest three-month period for which figures are available. Indeed, they reveal an increase in industrial disputation costs from an average monthly figure of $1.1m to an average monthly figure of $1.35m.

The Government must very quickly give figures to this Parliament for the period since the end of August 1987 as to what has happened in that period because that has been the period about which the Government and everyone else has been most concerned regarding the likely possible outbreak of industrial disputation as we come closer to the completion date of the building. The figures that we have available to us today are figures of concern. I seek an explanation from the Government as to the reason for them and as to what has happened since August 1987.

I draw to the Senate's attention the excellent report which has been released by a committee chaired by my colleague Senator Parer on rorts in the building industry. That report brought to light many rorts that were occurring, particularly those associated with the construction of the new Parliament House. There were an enormous variety of them which added up to an enormous cost to the taxpayer. For example, employees were known to stay away for two days simply because of a missing handrail. Employees went on strike because there was no water in the urn for morning tea and they had to walk 50 yards to get the water, and so on. That report brought matters of great concern to our attention. Again, there is no mention in this latest progress report by the Minister of what has happened in that area. I think that is a major omission from the report.

The report also mentions, without any explanation, an escalation of other costs which it states are outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority. For example, they include almost $1.75m over a three-month period for the insolvency of contractors. The preceding nine-month period to the end of May 1987 showed a figure of $4.6m for the same item of insolvency of contractors. So, there has been an increase in the monthly average cost to the taxpayer of the insolvency of contractors. The three-month figure is $1.74m, compared with a figure which, on a monthly basis probably would have been somewhat less, but not much less, over the ensuing nine-month period. Again, there is no explanation for those insolvencies. I think that the Parliament deserves a better explanation than the bland statement that we have had.

They are some of the matters that concern me about the report. I welcome the fact that the Parliament has been brought more up to date than we were before the receipt of this report, but it is a very superficial report. There is such a short period before the official opening of the building and its occupancy by us in August. I ask the Government and the responsible Minister-the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West-through Senator Robert Ray who represents him here, to ensure that the Parliament and, through the Parliament, the public, are much better informed very shortly, as to the real situation concerning the progress of the Parliament House building than is reflected by this superficial and very skinny statement that we have received today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some concerns about this statement regarding the new Parliament House, as does my friend and colleague Senator Short. Senator Short said that this report relates to a period that ended last August. I suppose that we should congratulate the Government on coming out with a statement so quickly, as so far it has been unable to present the report of the Parliament House Construction Authority for the year ended 30 June last year. At least this statement only relates to August last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose a lowered degree of incompetence is expressed regarding the date of this one page report. I ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) to do whatever is appropriate to encourage the Parliament House Construction Authority to release the report for the year to 30 June, particularly in view of the disputation which has existed between the Auditor-General and the Authority. Surely this would impose upon that Authority a particular discipline to explain to this Parliament and to the people what on earth is going on in a $1 billion project involving taxpayers' money, which has been exposed in many areas as a mixture of incompetence and rip-offs. Of course, this is apart from having being revealed by a very detailed Auditor-General's inquiry as having many unsatisfactory elements involved in its cost control and other accounting areas. Frankly, it is scandalous that after so many months the annual report of the Construction Authority has not been presented.

I remember last year I got what I understood to be some kind of assurance, during a Senate Estimates committee hearing, that the report would be presented when Parliament resumed. Parliament has resumed. We are approaching the end of the first week. We still have not seen the annual report of the Construction Authority. The same thing happened last year when the report to 30 June 1986 was not presented to this Parliament until March 1987. Frankly, I think that this Parliament, and certainly this Government, ought to take severe measures against those instrumentalities, those authorities, which fail to meet the minimum reporting standards that are required under penal sanction by the law and, of course, by the stock exchange authorities when they relate to public companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any company which fails to present its annual report by a certain date should be subject to delisting and a fine.
—I think Senator Stone has made a very sound point, although I may say that the value of the present proposition is so low that it may as well be delisted anyway.
—The shares are falling in the market.

—A dramatic fall of status in the market, as evidenced in Adelaide so very recently. As I said, here we have a quarterly progress report to August of enormous detail, one page, while we have not got the annual report which is, of course, a matter of far greater substance and which no doubt will be adorned by a report from the Auditor-General, which all of us on this side of the House in particular, are eager to see. After all, we do have some sense of responsibility about the spending of taxpayers' money. If the Government does not share that sense of responsibility, I presume that is the reason it has done so little to ensure that this Parliament has received the annual report.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the substance of this one page progress report. There is very little to enthuse about. Senator Short quite rightly pointed out the cost of industrial disputation and how it appears to have accelerated on a quarterly basis from the time of the last report. But I am concerned about the inflation rate. This report refers to the updating by $20.9m, in other words the further blow-out of $20.9m in the cost of Parliament House-and that is, of course, in August 1987 dollars, so it will be more than that now. What is quite interesting in that is the inflation factor, because the inflation rate in that period, as measured by the consumer price index (CPI), according to the Australian Statistician, was 1.7 per cent. If 1.7 per cent equals $7.9m, that means about $460m is still to be spent on that project as of August last year. That is, of course, ludicrous. I do not know what remained to be spent at the end of August last year, the period to which this preliminary report relates, because it is not in this report. We do not know how much was outstanding, so we do not know what incredible inflation rate clearly applies to costs. But it is obviously far greater than the inflation rate of 1.7 per cent in that quarter according to the CPI figures.

I think it is reasonable to ask in the circumstances whether the Government could kindly provide us with what was the cost escalation rate which resulted in $7.9m in increased costs due to `inflation'. What was the index that brought about this kind of adjustment? Was it in fact due to specific circumstances which are not shared by the rest of the community? In other words, is there a special inflation rate that applies to Parliament House construction that does not apply to the rest of Australia? Of course the answer is yes, there is. The increase in costs, on the Construction Authority's own figures, that has taken place due to cost escalation and inflation seems to me far greater-something like twice as much according to my rough calculations-than the rate of inflation that has existed throughout the rest of Australia. It may well be that the building industry is subject to far greater inflationary pressures than other industries. All I can say is that I believe the Government, being the client in this case, had a special responsibility to ensure that, as it was such a significant client in such a significant building having such an enormous impact on building activity in this area, the inflationary costs in the building industry were not exacerbated by this project.

I also want to inquire about the content of this $20.9m blow-out on top of the inflationary element, which I have already said seems extraordinarily large. The other elements are listed in this one page quarterly report as a series of costs outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority involving industrial disputes of $4.05m, insolvencies of contractors, $1.74m, and reinstatement of previously deferred or deleted works such as landscaping, $7.2m. That is a total of $12.99m. That makes up the total of $20.9m revealed as a blow-out in this quarterly statement.

In other words, we have more blow-outs to come, because this statement to the end of August quaintly excludes the clear and presumably substantial cost involved in creating three new ministerial suites in that building to account for the increase in the size of the Hawke Ministry, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to placate various sections of various factions after the election in July. By the way, how much that would be I am afraid is a matter which I do not feel at liberty to discuss because I was recently appointed to the committee of this Parliament that deals with those matters. As I understand it, even though I am privy to the amount involved, it would not be right for me to reveal that without the approval of that committee. All I can say is that it seems to me that it would be decent of this Government to admit what the cost of three new ministerial suites in the new Parliament House would be. How many millions of dollars will be involved? I think it would also be decent for this Government to explain why, by the end of August, this additional cost was not revealed in this statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want a statement about benefits too?

—There may be incredible benefits as far as Senator Cook is concerned. He has benefited from the bringing of the mediocrity that was on the back bench onto the front bench at a cost of how many millions of dollars a year, and at a capital cost of how many millions of dollars at the new Parliament House. Of course Senator Cook says there is a benefit. It is a benefit to him.
—He was one of the factional conveners that led to this.

—As Senator Short says, Senator Cook can claim the credit for this expenditure. He was one of those who did the deal with the Prime Minister, no doubt recognising that, given what one could almost call a respectable delay, he would then be directly on the receiving end of the benefits. He did that sordid deal with the Prime Minister shortly after the last election. I wonder whether he declared his interest when doing the deal with the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that this kind of additional expenditure imposed on the Parliament House Construction Authority by this Government, as a result of actions taken in July and August, is not revealed in this quarterly report. In the next quarterly report, if the Government has got around to it and when we eventually get it, presumably we will see what the cost of these further additions has been. Let us recognise that during the construction of the new Parliament House there have been many instances, some enormous and some minor, of additional costs being imposed on the Construction Authority because this Government has changed its mind. It decided after the building was under way to increase the size of the Parliament. That cost upwards of $50m. Who knows? The real cost seems to me not to equate to the figures we have been officially handed out. I believe that it was more than the $41m listed in the statement we received, I think, last October or November. If one considers the changes of mind and the consequences of deals, like the three new ministerial suites, one sees this Government continually making alterations which are costly.

Let us consider the question of the Speaker's chair. A decision was taken almost two years ago to take that significant and historically important Speaker's chair from the House of Representatives into the new House of Representatives chamber. That decision, having been taken, was then reversed late last year. That decision involves the waste of $50,000, because that will be the cost of designing and installing a new, incredibly boring--

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally dull.

—As Senator Stone says, it is totally dull, which befits the style of this Government in the other House. It has certainly lost any gloss it may have had. That incredible waste of money has taken place because of yet another change of mind by this Government relating to the new Parliament House. It is easy-let us face it, I have done it-to blame the Parliament House Construction Authority for everything but it simply must be recognised that, while the Parliament House Construction Authority has quite rightly been directly subject to a great deal of criticism, particularly for its lack of cost control and its inability to report in anything like a reasonable amount of time, this Government stands to be blamed for many of the cost rises.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with another cost rise which I find difficult to identify within the headings that are in this quarterly report. Last year I asked Senator Button whether the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations had noted reports that the pace-setting severance pay agreement, now ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, for approximately 1,000 building workers on the new Parliament House would add a further $1m to the cost of the project. As I asked this question in December, I do not expect its consequences to be reported to this Parliament probably until December of next year, judging by the rate of progress we have had so far and the delays that have been involved in getting information to this chamber. I asked:

Did the Government make any submissions to the Arbitration Commission on this matter before the determination was handed down? If so, was it in support of or in opposition to the proposal, particularly in view of the fact that previous opposition-
that is, by the Government-

had led to a 12-week strike over this issue, costing multi-millions of dollars? Does the determination `conform to the Government's social security, taxation and wage fixing principles' which were stated by the Minister here on 7 October as a requirement for favourable consideration as a severance pay scheme and which at that time he said required substantial amendment if it was to either meet its intended objectives or satisfy Government wages policy or conciliation and arbitration principles? I ask the Minister: What substantial changes have taken place since 7 October to make this scheme acceptable, if it is now acceptable, and what will the costs and other consequences be of this decision being spread through the building industry?
The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) provided me with a reply which I received on 11 January this year, stating:
The Government is aware that Commissioner Baird on 15 December 1987 ratified a consent agreement providing redundancy pay for certain employees on the Parliament House project.

This decision is site specific and is an extension of a matter previously before the Commission. Major union and employers put submissions before the Commission. Whilst Commissioner Baird has not yet published his reasons he has indicated that the agreement is consistent with the Commission's termination change and redundancy (TCR) guidelines. Having been decided we must assume the decision is consistent with the Commission's wage fixing principles.

The Government did not intervene in this matter. As the Commission has determined that the agreement complies with the TCR principles, the Government accepts that the agreement is a genuine redundancy scheme and previous concerns expressed to the parties would not apply to this scheme. Accordingly, I would not expect there to be any problems in regard to the requirements of social security or taxation legislation.

The reality is that even though Commissioner Baird had not published his reasons the Government was quite happy to withdraw the objections it had held previously to a redundancy scheme which had caused a strike some time before because the Government at that stage was sticking to its so-called principles. Clearly, a couple of questions emerge from that. Has Commissioner Baird yet published his reasons and has the Government considered them, or is the Government determined not to consider them so that it will not have to undergo the intellectual rigour of finding out whether this agreement will add who knows how much to the cost of the new Parliament House in the face of the Government's so-called strongly held principles about redundancy pay?

I want to make only a couple more points about this matter. They relate to the response by people involved in the project to the quite proper concerns raised by the Waste Watch Committee when I chaired it. Most of the very sound points of criticism that were raised by the Waste Watch Committee have been endorsed by the Auditor-General's report. The complaints about the lack of cost control have been underlined by the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the criticism the Government has been leaning on the Auditor-General to strip him of resources.
—Exactly.
—And the Public Accounts Committee likewise.

—Both those points are very cogent. The Auditor-General retired early on this very issue, as I understand it, of being stripped of adequate staff. He was certainly upset about the matter and raised it in his report. I find the response of people involved at a very high level in the project to that criticism, which has been endorsed and which has never effectively been countered-there was an attempt to counter it by having a schedule at the back of a document provided for us which was totally inadequate in endeavouring to demolish the burden of criticism by the Waste Watch Committee-to be ludicrous. For example, there was the response in the Courier-Mail earlier this year by Mr Chandler, the project manager, I think, of Concrete-Holland, to attacks by the Waste Watch Committee and by me on the project. Mr Chandler was prompted to indulge in crude and offensive personal criticism of me and fellow senators and anyone who dared to criticise the waste of money-in my estimate about $200m-that has taken place because of practices that have occurred on the new Parliament House site. For example, Mr Chandler's response was reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: ``It is all right for the likes of Senators Baume and Parer to be grizzling about it, but I notice they fly first class all the time and may fly to their places of origin several times a week in some cases,'' he said.
``And I would also like to know the real cost of buying Senator Baume the dinner he has in Parliament House.''

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—It was Mr Chandler of Concrete Holland-a fellow who, I might add, I thought I had got on very well with in the past. I thought I had dealt with him honestly and directly and I am astounded by this kind of response. The article also stated:

SPEECH.PARA: His main complaint is that much of the criticism is based on inaccurate information and seeks only to score political points.

For Mr Chandler's benefit, what we are seeking to do is to stop the incredible waste which has cost $200m because of the inactivity of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has done sweet nothing to bring under control this waste of money, despite the fact that his Department is supposed to take an overall view of the accounting practices of government authorities. His incompetence in this matter is underlined by the $200m of public money wasted on this project. The Minister is as competent in the matter of the Parliament House Construction Authority and its lack of cost control as he was in understanding how the Australian Broadcasting Corporation was robbed of $12m because he and his Department would not allow the ABC to take out forward exchange cover. He did not understand how the forward exchange contract system worked. He tried to smart alec his way through at Question Time, revealing further his monumental incompetence--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not incompetent; he is protecting his mates.
—No, not in this case. He has no mates. That is impossible as an explanation; he is simply incompetent.
—I have to say, Senator, that you have a great deal of difficulty in raising any sympathy for the ABC in this chamber.

—Senator Stone may be right: The reality is that the ABC wanted to hedge against foreign exchange losses because of its commitments in external currencies and was prevented from doing so by this highly intelligent and well-beloved Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making is that I regret that, after what I had thought were sensible and rational discussions that I had with him, Mr Chandler chose to lower himself to that kind of personal criticism. This is a serious matter involving the waste of money on the new Parliament House site. Serious matters are also involved in the way that this Government has continued to add to the ballooning cost of this project.

I conclude by simply saying to the Minister that it would be in his best interests, apart from in the best interests of the Parliament and the people of Australia, if he would use what could be described as his good offices-if he has any-to ensure that the annual report of the Parliament House Construction Authority for the year to 30 June 1987 is produced to the Parliament as quickly as possible and that an explanation is given to the Parliament as to why it has not yet appeared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has a number of concerns relating to the construction of the new and permanent Parliament House, particularly issues raised in and associated with the Auditor- General's report. I remind the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that, despite its depleted resources, the Public Accounts Committee will be proceeding with an inquiry, despite protestations from certain quarters, and is currently in the process of collecting information. The Minister's interjections support the feeling within the community about the Government's sensitivity to any independent evaluation of the management of its administration and its programs. It is not surprising that the staffing resource issue, which was raised in September last year, remains unresolved and that the Government, the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker have remained unmoved to date, despite the fact that we are told that negotiations are continuing.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems quite incongruous that the Government's chequebook is unlimited when it relates to extravagances for its Ministry, yet the resources of the Parliament are being checked and limited. Independent scrutiny of the Government by any agency or by the Parliament is being hampered by the Minister. The whole question of the sovereignty of Parliament arises. It is at risk. Democracy is at risk in Australia. While the Queensland Parliament moves towards the establishment of a public accounts committee, this Government of the Australian Labor Party, which is so proud about freedom of information and about independent checks, is now systematically and deliberately doing everything in its power to curtail any independent inquiry. It has done so not only in relation to the Public Accounts Committee but also in relation to the Ombudsman, freedom of information and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. It is replacing them with advisory boards-with people prepared just to give advice to Ministers. The Government does not want any independent assessment because it is running scared about what is actually happening.

As the Minister is so keen to invite me to debate him, I ask him-this follows his interjection in Senator Baume's speech-to tell the Senate what the Auditor-General did tell him when he announced his retirement from that office. Perhaps he may also like to tell the Senate what the Auditor-General said to him, by reports and directly, about the resources available to the Public Accounts Committee and the effect of their reduction. Perhaps the Minister will be brave enough to give the Senate those two answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address the matter raised by Senator Watson about the duty and responsibility of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to deal with the Auditor-General's report as it deals with the Parliament House Construction Authority. As Senator Watson has pointed out, the ability of the Public Accounts Committee to deal with the efficiency audit has been held up because of the cutting back of resources to that Committee. It may be a flippant matter to raise, but one of the things that concern me, having made an inspection of the new Parliament House, is the relative sum that is being expended on parts of the building which it will be most interesting to look at when the matter is scrutinised. The item that springs readily to mind is the amount of money being spent on the rather opulent swimming pool-a swimming pool which is waveless, which has next to it a jacuzzi, and which has an opulence which I dare say would have satisfied Caligula and, indeed, Caligula's horse.
—Nothing like the money that was wasted by cancelling the rainforest timber panels for the chambers.

—Indeed. Senator MacGibbon has brought up an important point relevant to the mismanagement of the project. Evidence is coming out to show that the Parliament House Construction Authority has much to answer for. Of great interest to me will be a comparison of the figures, when we are able to see them, to see whether the amount of money that has been spent on that opulent swimming pool is greater than that which has been spent on the chambers where the business of the Parliament is conducted. I can say only that, when I walked into the chambers in the new building, I was seized with a feeling that I can describe only as profound disappointment. The public spaces are magnificent as, indeed, the swimming pool is magnificent but my feeling of disappointment related to the complete breach and lack of following of any tradition in the colours in which the chambers have now been decorated. I used the word `decorated' advisedly because I feel that the colours that have been used and the way in which they have been treated with fabric and wood is a question of decoration rather than a question of traditional furnishing of a chamber where tradition is important.

SPEECH.PARA: As I walked into this muddy brown-grey chamber, as distinct from the rich red chamber we have here, I looked at the seats or benches on which we will be seated, which reminded me of the front bench of a Holden vehicle, circa 1959, and with about as much comfort, and I looked at the narrowness of the desks at which we will have to sit that will take only an A4 folder and not a foolscap folder. I entered into a discussion with one of the people responsible for the design of the chamber and we almost got into an argument in which he asserted that his taste was better than my taste. I could not help concluding that in terms of the purposes for which the Parliament House was built, that is the conducting of the business of the nation in the chambers of the Senate and the House of Representatives, that Parliament House is about as successful as the Sydney Opera House is for the production of opera. They are both magnificent buildings, both are very grand, and both will be historic and important buildings, but it is the attention to the parts of tradition in that building that disappoints me most. That is why I want to support the remarks of Senator Watson.

When the Public Accounts Committee comes to examine how well that building has been built, I think there is much to be disclosed. It is a pity that the cutting back of resources has postponed this inquiry. Senator Watson said `delayed', which is perhaps suiting some people's agendas so we do not have the answers to the questions that I think are relevant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson asked me a couple of questions. As accurately as I can recall, the Auditor-General came to see me and he told me that he was retiring. I have received letters from the Auditor-General about the resources that are available to him.

—Senator Watson said that the Auditor-General had written to me. I do not read his reports either. So far as I can recall, the Auditor-General has not written to me about that subject. —Arrogance of government.

—What about your own left wing?

—Is Senator Watson going into alliance with the Socialist Left now? Senator Watson changes his spots as often as Billy Hughes did. As I recall the situation, the Presiding Officers made the decisions on staff allocations and I do not think there was any overall cut, but I will check that.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a couple of other points. In coalition with the Democrats, the Opposition is threatening now to set up a Senate committee of inquiry into residues from agricultural chemicals. This inquiry will provide a forum for every crank and ratbag in the country to make any wild allegation that they feel like making-Senator Stone agrees with all of this, I will guarantee-and this will then be republished overseas in a misleading way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Yes, Senator Panizza agrees with me, too. The honourable senator's proposal has the same effect of providing a forum for every crank and ratbag. The results could be republished overseas and misrepresented to the extent that they will be claimed as the view of a committee of the Australian Parliament and/or the Senate which does not have much prestige but at least has more prestige and deserves more prestige than the cranks and ratbags who are likely to make submissions to that inquiry if staff is provided for it.
