SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly about the new Parliament House statement. I wonder whether it really is a ministerial statement and how much of the statement can be trusted because past information given both to this Parliament and by the Minister has been found to be false by the Auditor-General and subsequently in questions raised in the Estimates Committee. The latest ministerial statement states-I think this was pointed out by Senator Michael Baume-that the figure goes only to August last year. I am unsure, as I am sure the Minister is unsure, because of the looseness of the statement, as to what the final cost will really be.

SPEECH.PARA: One should have thought that at this stage an almost final completion date would have been known and provision could have been made for the contingencies or cost escalation by way of inflation or whatever so that the final figure would be known. Will it be the figure of $1,047.8m, or will it be something like $1.2 billion or $1.4 billion? I do not know, and no indication is given in this. One reason given for the escalations over the three months period from September to August 1987 is inflation of $7.91m. No breakdown of where that is has been provided. Industrial disputation seems to be extraordinarily high, although it is worth reminding the House that on 28 October last year I asked this question during an Estimates Committee inquiry:
Is it possible to obtain the number of working days lost through industrial disputation from September 1985 to the present?

The extraordinary thing is that in the past I have said that the things that went on in Parliament House were not too different from the rest of Australia, but suddenly we find that there are some differences. The answer I got to that question was:
The site has not been closed down since the 14 week dispute in 1984.
So they kicked off with the good news! It continues:
Records are not kept in a manner that would provide a direct answer to this question.
That is a good bureaucratic reply. It continues:

However, in order to assess the costs to the project of industrial disputes, after 1984 a formula was agreed between the Authority, the Departments of Finance and Administrative Services (then Housing and Construction). Part of that formula provides an assessment of ``project days'' lost through disputes.
Having told us all that waffle, the Department then came to the point and said:
In the period September 1985 to September 1987-two years-
the assessed project days lost was 133.5, or an average of 5.6 days per month.

One week in every month was lost over the two-year period from 1985 to 1987, during the construction of the new Parliament House. By way of explanation, it was pointed out that the figures included time lost for stoppages for industrial health and safety issues. At the same Estimates Committee hearing it was asked:
Is it possible to provide the updated Budget estimates in common base year as well as current costs and to disclose the inflation index?
The reply stated:
The Estimates Committee agreed that the response to this question would be dealt with in the Authority's annual report. This is currently being prepared-
this is on 28 October 1987-
and will be tabled in the Parliament as soon as it is available.

We are now well into February 1988. Another reason for increased costs given in the ministerial statement is the insolvency of contractors which had cost $1.74m. No explanation is given but it is possible that some of these insolvencies might represent, although I am not sure to what extent, a flow-on from some of the industrial disputation that occurred on site. The statement also referred to the reinstatement of deleted work such as landscaping.

I issued a report on the restrictive work practices as they applied to the construction industry, and part of that report-I believe some six pages out of about 32 pages-referred to the new Parliament House. Some of those examples have been well canvassed so I will not go through them. However, the sorts of things that happened were as described by Senator Michael Baume. We were subject to all sorts of castigation by the people who are up to their necks in this. For instance, one of the examples concerns a deal that had been made on climbing time for crane drivers. Crane drivers were paid two hours overtime every day to climb into their cranes. In fact, the estimate of the crane drivers who reported this matter to us was that it took them in the order of 45 seconds to do that little exercise. Even worse, a deal was made that the crane drivers who were no longer to operate cranes, as they had been put onto fork lifts, were to retain the climbing allowance for the cranes.

Honourable senators would probably say if this occurs in the private sector that it is a monopoly business involving the trade union movement and that the unions can force the private contractors to pay. Of course, at the other end of it somebody picks up the tab-either a future leaseholder or the owner of the building. However, we are talking about the Parliament House. We are talking about taxpayers' money. This should have been given much more serious attention than it was.

The other interesting point made to me by the construction manager when trying to justify this was that a lot of the additional costs were not their fault. To some extent that is right. If we look at the figures given last year we see there was an amount of about $41m-it is probably double that-associated with the extensions to the new Parliament House as a result of the increase in the number of senators and members introduced into this Parliament by the Labor Government. Simply increasing the number of senators and members has increased the cost of the new Parliament House by $41m.

Of course today we heard that we have three new ministerial suites. According to Senator Michael Baume, the additional cost of those is not included in the figure provided in the ministerial statement. Hence my questions at the beginning of my comments in regard to this matter were: where is it going to end and when will it be substantially finished? None of us know the answers to those questions. I think that we and the people of Australia are entitled to know the answers. The other point is that if the militant unions behind the problems at the new Parliament House continue in the way they have in the past, and know that there is an opening date and a final completion date, it is inevitable, as sure as the sun gets up in the morning and goes down at night, that they will pull on disputes. They know that there are dates that are vital. If that happens, it is absolutely imperative that this Government stands up and says, `Enough is enough. This is taxpayers' money and you have wasted enough already. We are not going to continue to buy peace'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the Senate about the resolution of a dispute that has been going on for over a decade about the export of alumina from the Gove project in the Northern Territory at prices which the Government regarded as unacceptably low. While the commercial details of the arrangements jointly agreed with the company must remain confidential, the settlement is a good one for Australia-there will be an immediate price increase. The agreement will also be beneficial to the Gove Joint Venture-not least in removing uncertainties created by the protracted dispute with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has a long history. It has not only been of concern to my Government; it was an issue which the coalition sought to redress when in Government. In 1981, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources made a recommendation about renegotiating the contracts relating to alumina exports from Gove; the outcome I am presenting today is consistent with the Committee's recommendation. Before going further, I should briefly explain the structure of the Gove joint venture. The principal partner is Swiss Aluminium Ltd-Alusuisse, which is one of the world's six major integrated aluminium producers. This Zurich-based company holds 70 per cent of the Gove project through a wholly-owned subsidiary, Swiss Aluminium Australia, or Austraswiss. The 30 per cent Australian side of the venture is held by Gove Aluminium Ltd (GAL) in which CSR Ltd holds the major share.

The important point in respect of the situation which developed over pricing was that, at the outset of the project, Alusuisse entered into long-term sales agreements to purchase alumina from Gove for 20 years, and to do so under specific pricing formulas. Those pricing arrangements have produced prices which the Government regarded as out of line with fair and reasonable world market prices, even though there were some good prices particularly in the initial years. Over the last decade, Governments sought on many occasions to persuade the companies to bring exports from Gove into line with market prices received for other exports from Australia. The management of Alusuisse at that time would not agree to renegotiation. They argued that approvals given by the Commonwealth when the project was being developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s placed a contractual obligation on the Commonwealth to give export approval at prices derived under the sales agreements until those agreements expire in 1992.

I will not here go into the rights and wrongs of decisions taken almost 20 years ago; nor do I want to debate the validity of the legal view of the contracts which the company has taken. I must say, however, that, taken together with developments in the international market, the legacy of those decisions for the subsequent Governments was a complex contractual situation and a protracted dispute over pricing. Successive Ministers, including Mr Anthony as Minister for Trade and Resources, raised the matter with the companies. While there was some movement on bauxite, Alusuisse would not shift on the main alumina agreement. In 1986, following unproductive meetings with Austraswiss and Alusuisse in Sydney and in Zurich, the then Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, commissioned Mr Spigelman, QC, to undertake an investigation of Gove pricing. That initiative was a turning point.

It is important to remember that bauxite/alumina production has been a very closed industry-less so now than in the past, but it is still probably the least transparent of the mineral markets. Details of pricing and sales are not publicly disclosed. Spigelman's extensive investigation was able to throw considerable light on the Gove transactions. It presented the Government with a comprehensive review of the legal position and outlined a number of options.

The main elements of the report were provided to the companies; needless to say, they contested many of the report's findings. The settlement today will mean that the Spigelman report will remain confidential to the Government and to the parties. I can say, however, that Spigelman recommended that a further attempt be made to secure a change in the alumina sales agreement through negotiation. This is the course the Government took and, while it has not been without difficulties, it was the course which produced the result I present today.

My colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, met in August last year with the Executive Vice President of Alusuisse, Mr Hermann Haerri. Further negotiations followed at the official level. The breakthrough came late last year when Mr Haerri indicated that Alusuisse was prepared to work towards an overall package which reflected the interests of both the Government and the companies and, for the first time, agreed that this could include a new pricing arrangement. After several months of detailed negotiations with my Department and with the Australian Taxation Office, I have finalised that package today with Mr Haerri. I would like to acknowledge here the contribution that Mr Hermann Haerri has made to the successful outcome reached today. I indicate that Mr Haerri and his colleagues are in the gallery. Mr Haerri's strong personal commitment played an important part in the achievement of the settlement.

Alusuisse has put to me today an amendment to the 1969 alumina sales agreement between Alusuisse and Austraswiss. These new provisions will apply as from 1 January 1988 until the agreement expires in almost five years time-in August 1992. In an exchange of letters today, I have confirmed the Government's acceptance of the terms of the settlement. The formal amendment to the agreement will be put to the boards of both companies for ratification in March. A number of related taxation matters have been concluded concurrently with this settlement. These arrangements apply to the 70 per cent of Gove alumina exported by Austraswiss. The other partner, Gove Aluminium, initially exported its 30 per cent of the output to Alusuisse but, under the terms of the original contract, this has been reduced over recent years and will be phased out shortly. These revised provisions for alumina exports follow the agreement on satisfactory prices for bauxite exports from Gove which the then Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, settled in 1986, and which have subsequently been renewed.

Taken together, these new arrangements represent a very good outcome for Australia. From my discussions with Mr Haerri today, it is clear that the company also regards the settlement as beneficial to its interests. The negotiations were conducted in a manner which reflected the wish of both the Government and the company to see this difficult issue settled by negotiation on mutually acceptable terms.

Gove is an important project for Australia, and particularly for the Northern Territory. It is a major investment for the Alusuisse group which relies on it for a high proportion of its alumina supplies. It is an efficient project by world standards and has a long term future. The agreement we have reached today will, I hope, enables us to look to that future in a way which will maximise the contribution that Gove and Alusuisse can make to the future growth and development of Australia. With the dispute now settled, I hope it will be possible for Alusuisse to resume an active role in that development, particularly as a base for meeting the growing opportunities in the aluminium industry in the Asian-Pacific region. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments on the ministerial statement which has just been made by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook). In doing so, I take the opportunity of thanking the Minister for his courtesy earlier today of providing me in advance with a copy of the statement he has just made to the Senate in accordance with what ought to be the normal courtesies in this place. The Gove project is a very important one to the economy of the Northern Territory. I think I am right in saying that alumina exports from Gove constitute about one-quarter of total Northern Territory mineral exports and amount to something in the order of $300m per annum.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed that the Minister referred to the presence in the President's gallery of a number of gentlemen from Swiss Aluminium Ltd-Alusuisse. I have just had the pleasure of being introduced to them by the Minister. Again, I thank the Minister for his courtesy. I regret having my back turned to these gentlemen while I make my remarks. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you are aware it is necessary to address the Chair in this place and one cannot do both from this side of the chamber at least, otherwise one would be like the character in Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress, a Mr Facing Both Ways, or rather like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when answering questions on taxation and superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you will be in a more satisfactory situation after a subsequent election.
—I thank the Chair for its prophesy.
—The impartiality of its comment.

—Yes, indeed, Senator. As the Minister said, this matter has a long history; indeed, it is one with which, in a previous capacity, I had some personal acquaintance and not, I hasten to add, of any detailed kind. Quite naturally and quite properly, the affairs of individual taxpayers in this country remain confidential to the Australian Taxation Office. As I say, I did have some personal acquaintance of what one might call a general policy character.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister said, the matter has a long history. It was an issue which the coalition sought to redress-I think that was the word he used-when in government. That, of course, is perfectly true. Over the course of that long history I think it is fair to say that a certain amount of public approbrium has been brought to bear upon Alusuisse because, among other things, of various allegations made about what some saw as the unfairness, or in some cases worse, of the pricing arrangements involved in the exports of both bauxite and alumina from the Gove project. I think it is therefore fair to point out, as the Minister quite properly stated in his speech a moment ago, that at the outset of the project Alusuisse entered into long term sales agreements to purchase alumina from Gove for 20 years and to do so under specific pricing formulas.

The Government's position on this aspect of the matter-in recent years at any rate-has been clearly stated by the Minister; namely, that those pricing arrangements, which were set out in what the company certainly saw as contractual arrangements, have produced prices which the Government regarded as being out of line with fair and reasonable world market prices-that may very well have been the case-even though there were some good prices, particularly in the initial years. As we all know from our own personal lives, it is perfectly possible to enter into contracts which, many years later, one finds will work against one's interests, but that does not necessarily mean, and ought not usually to mean, that the contract should in any way be regarded as invalid unless it has been entered into initially under duress or in some other way which in a sense, from a legal point of view, would in any case render the contract void. I do not believe that there has been any suggestion of that in this case.

As the Minister acknowledged in his statement, there was a very different view of the nature of those contracts as to whether they were indeed unfair or unreasonable, or the prices resulting from them were unfair or unreasonable. That view was, not surprisingly, held by the company. I think it is fair, therefore, that that view also should be emphasised in this place when this matter is being recorded. I will quote the words of the Minister:
They-
that is the company-

argued that approvals given by the Commonwealth when the project was being developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s placed a contractual obligation on the Commonwealth to give export approval . . .

I pause on those words, `to give export approval', because I think that in recent times we have seen some very disturbing suggestions from Commonwealth Ministers for Resources that in some sense export approval might be withheld for exports of resource companies, particularly, but not merely resource companies, unless the company concerned is prepared to bow the knee to Canberra on some perhaps quite unrelated matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether it was threatened in this case?

—Senator Parer quite rightly points out that there were indeed threats to that effect in this case uttered by the previous Minister for Trade, I think, Mr Dawkins. I was going to refer to those most unfortunate remarks.
—Would that Minister utter threats?

—I do not want to be diverted from my remarks, but Senator Durack has queried whether Mr Dawkins is the sort of man who would utter threats. I would have to say, with the spirit of frankness and truthfulness to which naturally we are bound in this chamber and I hope, indeed, elsewhere, that Mr Dawkins is indeed the kind of man who would make such threats, and he has done so in this case, as Senator Parer said.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to my more general point before the particularity was raised, I was about to say that this is a disturbing development from a constitutional viewpoint, because the export power which was accorded, quite properly-I am not questioning that-to the Commonwealth by the framers of the Constitution, I am quite sure, was not in any way intended to place in the hands of Commonwealth Ministers a bludgeon, which could then be held over the heads of companies or other citizens going about their proper and legally constituted business but over whose affairs the government of the day and the Minister of the day wish to obtain a hold.

As I say, I think that has been a very disturbing development. We have seen further examples of that kind of approach to the matter coming forward in the case of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, who has invoked that kind of threat in the case of the north Queensland tropical rainforest controversy; but, again, I do not want to get into that.

To return to the view of the company on the contractual arrangements concerned, the view of the company as stated by the Minister was that those arrangements placed a contractual obligation on the Commonwealth to give export approval at prices derived under the sales agreements until those agreements expire in 1992. Be all that as it may, the Government and the company have now, it seems, been able to settle their differences. Of course, the detailed nature of those differences remains obscure. We know the general nature of the differences, but the detailed nature of them remains obscure. There have been, it appears, extensive investigations of those details commissioned by the previous Minister for Trade and conducted by a Mr James Spigelman, QC, who I believe I recall having met in a previous incumbency, as the then private secretary to the then Prime Minister, Mr Edward Gough Whitlam.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very good one at that.

—There were differences of opinion upon that view, but I do not wish in any way to detract from what is, I am sure, Mr Spigelman's growing reputation in the legal profession and fraternity in Sydney. I simply refer to the point that he was known to me and, I am sure, to many others in this place in his previous incumbency. I am glad to see the Government not forgetting some of its old mates in these areas as in others.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that, as the Minister has pointed out, the settlement today will mean that what he calls the Spigelman report will remain confidential to the Government and to the parties; so, as a consequence of that the Senate will not have available to it the details of the differences between the Government and the company and will, therefore, not be able to arrive at an independent and fully informed judgment as to the pros and cons of those differences and, therefore, as to the fairness or, as the case may be, unfairness of the settlement that appears to have been arrived at. One problem that such confidentiality produces is that it is not really possible to determine now whether this agreement has been arrived at in a genuine spirit of co-operation or whether one of the parties to it has had its arm rather strongly twisted up behind its back.

At this point, in fact, I had proposed to refer to the utterances of the previous Minister for Trade, Mr John Dawkins, in this area-and it has already been referred to in interjection, quite proper interjection, by Senator Parer and Senator Durack. The fact is that Mr Dawkins did at that time utter some remarks which I think can be described only as clearly strongly intimidatory remarks bearing upon the company's prospective capacity to continue to receive approval for export contracts. I would have to say that, although I would wish to be assured to the contrary-and I think the Minister's statement seeks to give an assurance to the contrary-against that kind of background, a negotiation of this kind must at least commence under something of a cloud.

Of course, that is not the only kind of possible concern that might arise where one does not have available to one the full details of the matters under dispute or under negotiation because, to take the other possibility, one does not know whether perhaps the Government has entered into some other related understanding with the company; for example, purely to speculate-I do not in any way suggest this is the case; it is purely to speculate-in relation perhaps to the granting of further leases or perhaps even entirely new leases on some other entirely unrelated area for future mining operations. I do not suggest that either of these two hypothetical situations to which I have referred has occurred. I merely note that such speculations are inevitable when confidentiality, for however good reasons-and I accept that there are, naturally, some good reasons-is imposed.

The Gove project is, of course, of great importance not only to Australians generally and not only to the residents of the Northern Territory, as I have already said, but most particularly, I would suggest, to those Australians, particularly those of Aboriginal descent, who reside in the close vicinity of the town of Nhulunbuy. That town is totally dependent on this project, as is the nearby Yirrkala community, which receives substantial royalty income from the mining operation and, I suppose, possibly-at least in my opinion-almost more important, substantial job opportunities.

Finally, to end on perhaps a note of greater particularity, I just refer to one particular matter which, because of events over recent days, I think has acquired some topicality. My understanding is that the company in question has among its employees some 40 or 50 senior management or senior technical personnel and that there is a good deal of concern, among those people themselves in the first instance, but also, of course, on the part of the company at chief executive level and so on, as to the possible consequences for the company over the months immediately ahead as a direct result of the mooted changes in the taxation treatment of superannuation.

The company is not singular in that respect. I am sure that honourable senators opposite just as honourable senators on this side of the House are receiving a great many communications, both written and telephonic, from extremely concerned citizens in this country who are wondering what this Government has in mind in that area. Of course, this is a matter which has been given even greater prominence in recent days by the initiative, if I can call it that, of Mr Unsworth, the Premier of New South Wales, in asking the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to make a clear declaratory statement on the topic, which he has so far refused to do. I put that on the table before concluding my remarks. Clearly, for an operation of this kind in any extremely isolated locality, which depends for its continued good health upon the retention of key executive personnel, it would be nothing short of a disaster if any, but particularly a sizeable number, of the people concerned were to feel that, so to speak, it was a case of safety first on this matter. I certainly trust that the Government will take the opportunity which the Opposition has been seeking to give it at Question Time in this place and elsewhere in recent days to say more clearly than it has so far been prepared to what it has in mind in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The mining industry in Australia relies entirely on confidence. The report which the new Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, has brought down today deals specifically with one of the most important expressions of mining confidence in Australia in recent years. Just on 20 years ago Alusuisse took a giant step in confidence in looking at the bauxite deposits at Gove in northern Australia and subsequently developed the town of Nhulunbuy. It injected at that time, in mid-1960s prices, capital of about $400m in what was a very remote and isolated part of Australia. That great step in confidence between Alusuisse and its Australian partners provided the catalyst, I believe, for many of the other great mining projects that then happened throughout the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Queensland. We rely very heavily on special arrangements that must be made from time to time between government and principal mining contractors. The fact that we have now reached the stage of negotiations where Alusuisse has been able to reach a new accord with the Government is timely. The history has just been outlined by Senator Cook and Senator Stone.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to dwell for a few moments on the very particular things that do flow from confidence, particularly when one creates an absolutely new community. A town of some 4,000 people now exists at Nhulunbuy. This community comprises traditional Aboriginals, the mine related staff, their families and the various contractors and public servants and the private sector support in health, education, municipal functions or commercial activities that have sprung up in that 20-year period. All of this has happened because of the confidence in this project. What we must now guarantee is that that community, the Northern Territory community and the Australian community, can rely on the Government's intentions for the future and that the policies and actions that it has in place and is planning for the future will support the Nhulunbuy community, the Yirrkala community, the Northern Territory and other areas of Australia.

The economic importance of the Gove project to the Northern Territory is very easy to state. The value of the bauxite and alumina production for 1987 was somewhere between $300m and $350m, and that is in today's dollar terms. This represents 25 per cent of the total Northern Territory mineral production, which is estimated at some $1.2 billion. Mining is a most important industry in the very narrow-based economy of the Northern Territory. As I said, mining provides some $1.2 billion; the next important industry is tourism with $250m; and the pastoral industry follows that with $120m. So the mining industry carries the Northern Territory. It is the only catalyst for the long term and sustained economic development of the Northern Territory. Mining represents the only way in which the Northern Territory can cut its tie and dependency and stand on its own two feet.

There are, of course, other important partners in mining in the Northern Territory-the various uranium projects, the manganese on Groote Eylandt and the gold developments that are happening. It is terribly important that we link this economic development to the strategic and defence importance of alumina as a product and what it contributes and to the fact that there now exists this important township in the north-eastern corner of the Northern Territory. As the future takes the Northern Territory fully forward into statehood, Nhulunbuy is going to play an increasing, important strategic and defence role. Similarly, I would like to see tourism developed in that community because it would be an important addition to its economy.

We have argued in this place about the importance of Aboriginal land rights. There are benefits, there are liabilities and there are constraints imposed by Aboriginal land rights legislation. The homeland communities of the Aboriginal people of Yirrkala and the out- stations that now depend so heavily on the Gove project for employment, for royalties and for all the other associated support that they have come to enjoy I believe would attract the attention of many people throughout Australia. The executives of Alusuisse, in the 20 years they have been visiting Gove, have grown to know and appreciate the Aboriginal people of Arnhem Land. I am sure they had many fine negotiating times with Roy Marika and the other leaders. They have probably been just as tough as any Minister of the Commonwealth Government.

As Senator Stone said, the way in which government policies can often undermine confidence is surprising. The current uncertainty with regard to the superannuation initiatives of the Hawke Government is providing a problem in a major resource project that needs to be highlighted. This vital industry of the Northern Territory, with $300m in production a year, could have major problems unless the degree of certainty for superannuation is determined, because any major project depends on key personnel and management people who must have the confidence to want to remain. While their superannuation entitlements are under threat and barrage and subject to open warfare from the Australian Labor Party (ALP) it undermines this very great project.

I welcome the report that has been brought down by the Minister. It is obviously the culmination of a long saga and history, debate and controversy, but at least we now know that there is certainty. Alusuisse has given us the confidence we can rely on; let us only hope we can rely on the ALP to honour its part of the bargain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly lest it be considered that the Gove partners, Alusuisse, were in some way in the past acting in some way which was not in the interests of Australia. I do that because of the criticisms I heard from irresponsible, irrational people about this matter. I do it with the knowledge of and some experience in things such as resource development and long term contracts. One must remember that back in the late 1960s and early 1970s the Gove project was breaking new ground; it was pioneer work. I am grateful to Senator Tambling for giving me the figure of $400m, in mid-1960s prices, because if we were to take inflation into account that figure, in today's terms, would be between $1.5 billion and $2 billion. I think it is important to realise that in those days there was not as much money around. Finance was not as easy to get. In order to put finance packages together it was critically important to obtain a resource that could be developed and measured, to get some security of tenure over that resource and then enter into agreements with the relevant governments that one could take to a financial institution, put on the table and say, `This is an honourable document from an honourable country and it will be honoured for its duration'.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is easy for people to be wise in retrospect, but that was done in good faith. I note, for instance, that in the early years particularly good prices were achieved. The assumption one would make from that-and I do not know the details-is that the price then being paid was higher than the world market price. Everyone was very happy with that. Subsequently, as we know, things changed. We had massive inflation and the oil crises of the 1970s. There was an antagonistic government that used resource diplomacy to force companies-mine was one-to go to buyers in an effort to break contracts. That is the coarse way of putting it, but it is the right way. Other language was used. I see that the same sort of language is used in this document. It is similar to saying, `Let's do something that will be in our mutual interests', or words to that effect. What happens is that one's arm is squeezed. The document states:
From my discussions . . . it is clear that the company also regards the settlement as beneficial to its interests.

That is magnificent language-`beneficial to its interests'. It is like saying, `We are just going to charge you more but it will be tremendously beneficial to your interests'. The only thing I can assume is that there was a threat that, unless they agreed, went halfway or settled the negotiation, we would withdraw export licences. The Government is expert at doing this. Most members of the Government have been involved in the industrial relations field, and that is how they operate. They come along and say `We have a dispute'. A dispute, to me, means that there are two parties but it is started by one. I am sure that Alusuisse did not say to the Government `We are in dispute'. I am absolutely convinced of that.

The Government would have said, `There is this criticism, there is this nasty thing called transfer pricing and you are not paying the world market price'. I am sure that Alusuisse said, `Well, you're quite right'. But back in those days it was not easy to get this operation off the ground. Anyone who has not been through this would have no idea of how difficult it was. In those days we had to have these agreements in place in order to develop. This was one of the great developments in Australia-one that gave impetus, as Senator Tambling said, to the large-scale commodity investments in the rest of Australia. It attracted people to Australia. After that, for example, we had the major coal developments in the Bowen Basin with which I was associated. Yet it is all made to look so easy. Then someone comes back-I have heard particularly the Australian Democrats do this-and criticises these people as if they are evil people who are doing something awful to Australia, when in fact they have provided the impetus for massive exports, for developments in areas that would never have been developed without them.

I am not critical of the statement of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), but it must be put in perspective. Agreements were entered into in good faith 20 years ago. I note from the ministerial statement that the agreement would have expired in 1992. Having got to 1988, why did we not do the honourable thing and say, `Let's honour something that expires in four years time'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the statement by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook). I am very pleased with the way in which the negotiations have been carried out. —I think that is insulting and I ask for a withdrawal of that remark.

—The question of the contract as it was established goes to the question of agreed prices at that time. DEBATE.TITLE: SIMULTANEOUS DISSOLUTION OF THE SENATE AND THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES-5 JUNE 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I say first of all how disgraceful I believe it is that the Senate is confronted with 112 Government Papers to discuss and the time we are allotted for this item is one hour. I accept the point that those not dealt with will be carried over; but this is just another example of the absolute maladministration that the Government side of the Senate has fallen into in recent times. I never thought I would ever believe that I would say, `Bring back Don Grimes', but, given Senator Gareth Evans's performance since he took over this field, I would have to say that.

Paper No. 4 is entitled Simultaneous Dissolution of the Senate and the House of Representatives-5 June 1987, and it contains the correspondence between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Governor-General relating to the dissolution of both Houses of Parliament on 5 June 1987. The Prime Minister's letter to the Governor-General of 27 May 1987, which is the key trigger letter for this report, has as the whole basis for requesting the double dissolution election the Senate's rejection twice of the Australia Card Bill. The Prime Minister, in his letter advising the Governor-General that there ought to be a double dissolution of the Parliament, said:
The Australia Card Bill 1986 is an integral part of the Government's tax reform package . . .
In another part of his letter to the Governor-General, the Prime Minister said:

The Australia Card Bill which has been obstructed by the Senate is a fundamental part of the Government's legislative program both in terms of its economic impact and in terms of the principle of equity it represents.

I will come back to those words a little later. I want to put the proposition that the Prime Minister went to the Governor-General seeking a double dissolution on the basis of the Australia Card legislation, knowing first of all that the Senate, as then constituted, would not allow the regulations under the legislation which would be necessary for its ongoing operation and, secondly, that a double dissolution election would almost certainly ensure the continued existence in the Senate of the Australian Democrats. So the Prime Minister's advice to the Governor-General that a double dissolution election was necessary in order to bring in an operable ID card scheme was quite wrongly based from the outset.

Of course, that is only part of the story because, as history has now recorded, the Government was unbelievably maladroit in its handling of the whole ID card issue. Its incompetence was of a magnitude that absolutely boggles the imagination even of those of us on this side of the House who are living day by day with ever increasing examples of ineptitude by the Government. That is really saying something because, as we all know now, so badly was the Australia Card Bill drafted, so incompetent was the Government, that it required the support of the Senate to trigger its operation, and the Government knew that the Senate would not give that trigger. So not only was the Government incompetent; it also appears in my view that the Prime Minister misled the Governor-General in his advice of 27 May 1987 to dissolve the Parliament because of the Australia Card Bill. At the very least it shows what a contrived, totally unnecessary and extremely costly exercise the Government's cynical, opportunistic calling of the 1987 election was.

The cost to the taxpayer of the 1987 election was of the order of $50m. The Government said earlier that the trigger for the double dissolution, the ID Card Bill, was, and I quote again, `an integral part of the Government's tax reform package'. It has now changed its tune on that one. It also said that the ID card was a fundamental part of the Government's legislative program both in terms of its economic impact and the principle of equity. On that basis then, on its own admission, its present legislative program is defective, which is something we have been telling the Government since the outset.

As someone whose home is in the country on a farm and who has a son on a cattle property in central Queensland--

TALK.START.PARA: —We know about him.

—Yes, Senator Walsh keeps talking about him and the Clayton's road that is supposed to be up there. Naturally I am very interested in the annual report of the Department of Primary Industry. I realise the many difficulties that confront families on the land. Some of those difficulties are caused by drought, flood and other natural disasters. SPEECH.PARA: As one who looks after the farm accounts at home I have long since realised that it is difficult to make much of a profit on the land. The 1986-87 annual report of the Australian Electoral Commission was prepared after the 1987 election but deals with the period ending 30 June 1987. The material in the report and, more importantly, other material relating to the electoral process shows not only that the calling of the 1987 election was a pragmatic and cynical decision made by the Australian Labor Party (ALP), as I said in earlier comments on another paper, but also that the claim that the election was called because of the Senate's refusal to block the ID card Bill was absolute bunkum. We now know to what lengths the Australian Labor Party will go to secure a victory. We have seen that in particular in the last couple of weeks when the ALP diverted a donation of $10,000 from the woodchip company Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd, which was given for the ALP's election campaign fund, into its administration account in New South Wales so as to avoid the disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act such as are discussed in the Australian Electoral Commission report and other Commission documents. As we all know now, the reason that disclosure provision was breached was to enable the ALP to keep secret from the environmentalists and conservationists that it had received money from a woodchip company at the same time as it received support from the major environmental groups. Some of the key conservation organisations, such as the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Australian Wilderness Society which had been the recipients of vast sums of money from the Hawke Government, came out openly and financially in support of the ALP at the last election. So, of course, a decision was made by the Labor Party apparatchiks to hide the Harris-Daishowa donation.

One of the fundamental functions of the Electoral Commission is to ensure that election returns and statistics are valid and accurate. Indeed, it is fundamental to the democratic process that they be so. That being the case, I am extremely disturbed to have received today from the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Hughes, a copy of Staff Circular 1988/11, dated 16 February, only two days ago, which he has sent to all members of the staff of the Electoral Commission. I seek leave to have the circular incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The circular read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL COMMISSION
Minute Paper
Staff Circular 1988/11
Election Returns and Statistics

As many Commission officers already know, a number of substantial defects have been identified in the Returns and Statistics relating to the 1987 election. The problem began when answers were sought to questions put to the Commission by Senator Jim Short, the Shadow Minister for Home Affairs; when those answers were pursued, further difficulties were uncovered.

2. It now appears possible that the existing Returns and Statistics cannot be relied upon with any certainty. It has been established that in the areas where inquiries have already taken place, far too many figures are defective and that in some instances failure to carry out procedures properly is responsible. What is not known is the degree of accuracy of figures in the many areas which have not yet been tested.

3. In April, or at latest May, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters is expected to start its inquiry into the conduct of the 1987 election. It is essential that the Commission be in a position to give full and frank evidence on the accuracy of Returns and Statistics and, where deficiencies have been identified, their likely causes and the remedial steps which are proposed.

4. Accordingly a working party is being set up to recheck and recount the ballot-papers and declarations from a sample of Divisions. The working party will operate in Canberra at premises close to Central Office. It is hoped work will start on 29 February and run for 5-6 weeks so that findings are available to the Joint Standing Committee at its hearings. The working party will include Mr Lionel Sampford, formerly Director of Operations, Queensland, and principal author of the Elections Manual, Mr Ian Johnston, Director of Industrial Elections, New South Wales, Mr Shawn O'Brien, Operations, Central Office, Mr Martin Johnson, DRO Eden-Monaro, and Mr Bob Patching, DRO Rankin.

5. The inquiries that have already been taking place concerning Returns and Statistics have led to accusations of ``witch-hunting'' being tossed about. Nothing is further from the truth. The Commission's performance is subject to close scrutiny by the parliamentary process and under FOI legislation. It is accountable to the Government and the Parliament and to the electorate for that performance. When its performance is less than satisfactory, everyone in the Commission is adversely affected. When electors are disfranchised by administrative errors, when parties or candidates are denied public funding payments to which they were entitled, or when records required to be kept so that election results may be challenged are lost, it is clear that better performance is necessary and it is in everyone's interest that this be achieved as quickly as possible.
Colin A. Hughes
Electoral Commissioner
16 February 1988

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a very full report of the activities for the year of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. There is a substantial overview at the start of the report which describes initially how the year 1986-87 was a year of substantial progress in implementing a gradually increasing immigration program with emphasis on skilled and business migration, family reunion and Australia's international humanitarian obligations in assisting a record number of temporary entrants and of refugees into our country. Of course, as everyone knows, the FitzGerald inquiry-not the Queensland one, but the one taking place here in Canberra-that is, the Committee to advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, is looking into our immigration policies and I am sure that, when that report comes out, everyone will be very interested in what it has to say.

A lot has been said of late, and there has been a lot of public discussion both in the newspapers and here in the Senate, about the value of our adult migrant English program. There are some very interesting statistics on page 114 of this report, which may be of interest to the Senate, on those who participate in the adult migrant education program. They show that those who have been here up to six months comprise 28 per cent of the participants; those who have been here from between six months to two years comprise some 26 per cent of the participants; those who have been here from two years to 10 years comprise more than 28 per cent of participants; and those who have been here more than 10 years comprise over 14 per cent of participants.

What these figures reveal to us all is that, whatever our views may be on immigration and on who should or should not be allowed to migrate here, if the level of English of migrants once they arrive here is not sufficient for their requirements, they are entitled to adult migrant education programs. These programs must be ongoing because people have different needs at different stages of their lives. This is borne out in the report and it is what these figures reveal. It seemed to be very neat and tidy to state that people should have a certain level of English before the get here. But, as they progress within our society and as they perhaps improve their employment and move into areas of employment where a more sophisticated level of English is required, it is up to us under our equal opportunity legislation to be sure that these people have these programs available. These statistics reveal that that is what is happening. It would be very disadvantageous to Australian society as a whole if there were any break in these programs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report has shown some improvements in the rural position in Australia and, as a result, the average farm income has been put at $16,400, a 30 per cent increase. In addition, but more importantly, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that 25 per cent of all family farms were debt free in 1986-87, 50 per cent had debts of less than $82,500, and only 12 per cent had debts of $163,000 or more.

The most important aspect of the new rural adjustment scheme is the provision of money in three parts. Part A is provided when carry-on finance is needed because the farmer's liquidity has suffered as a result of a downturn in the economy yet the farm is still a viable concern. Part B of the scheme provides assistance in short-term market downturns when farmers face a one-off problem caused by drought or fire. Part C of the scheme is for the farmers who cannot carry on and assistance is provided for their rehabilitation elsewhere.

The most worrying aspect of the report was what it did not show rather than what it showed. For example, Western Australia was allocated approximately $3.1m in interest subsidy and half the interest subsidy is given to provide leverage to borrow from a commercial lender. That allowed for approximately $31m to be borrowed but only half of that was used in Western Australia, the other half was returned to Canberra. The reason for this was that the guidelines set down by the rural adjustment scheme-fair though they may be-are being interpreted too strictly by the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation (RAFCOR), which is the agency that operates in Western Australia. Some of the bureaucrats who have been appointed to it are not doing their jobs correctly.

As I have said before, one must borrow money from private enterprise and the person who wishes to borrow the money is carefully considered. Before a decision is made to lend the money, private enterprise must be sure of its security. Therefore, I cannot see the reason for RAFCOR having so many bureaucrats in Perth to examine the budgets that the private lender has already considered. The time of the bureaucrats would be much better spent in other ways. I suggest to the Federal Government that the guidelines be altered to allow the farmer to accept the money that a commercial lender has agreed to lend to him without any further hold-ups by RAFCOR. The other amendment Western Australia put to the Federal Government was to change the guidelines on viability. I understand the difference between being placed in a viable category and a category of need is only $9,000. That amount is also provided each year for up to three years through household support, if one cannot continue farming. Western Australia asked the Government to consider increasing the limit placed on the amount of the loan that places one in a viable category. The Government could consider giving the farmers $27,000 so that they could leave the farm immediately rather than giving the farmers three years on household support of $9,000 each year and waiting for them to sell their farms. If that were done the farmers' creditors would not be dragged down the line as well. I urge the Government to carefully consider that and to put forward a proposition next year because during the past few years this scheme has provided adequate carry-on finance for farmers all over Australia but it may be further improved because agriculture is on the move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT (STAFF) ACT 1984-CONSULTANTS ENGAGED UNDER SECTION 4

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking to the motion, I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate a particular consultant who is set out in this report as having been appointed and still appointed to the staff of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). Last year by way of a question without notice I drew the attention of the Senate to the appointment of Mr Alan Asher to the Trade Practices Commission and to the fact that he is largely an anti-business appointee. I questioned his suitability for that appointment. This matter is relevant to the annual report because it is stated on page 4 of the annual report of the Department of Administrative Services on the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 that Mr Crough would be employed by the Attorney-General to:
Provide advice on consumer affairs and trade practices matters, and other issues as may arise. Research and drafting of speeches.
More particularly, it was his job to:
Represent the Attorney-General at, or attend with him as adviser, Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers.
Further, he was to:
Liaise with National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council and advise generally concerning authorities and bodies in consumer affairs and trade practices areas.

It was the same Mr Crough who had a major say in the appointment of Mr Alan Asher. I think it is appropriate that we put on the record just who Mr Crough is because there is speculation in the marketplace at present that with the retirement of Mr McComas this Government may choose to appointment Mr Alan Asher as Chairman of that Commission. Quite frankly, in the eyes of the business community as a whole, that would be totally unacceptable. I think it is of interest to record the history of Mr Crough. He was the original deputy to Professor Ted Wheelwright at the Transnational Corporations Research Project, which was established in 1975. He is indeed a protege of Professor Wheelwright, who is well known as an economist with neo-Marxist tendencies. The attitude of the body I just mentioned is best illustrated by Ted Wheelwright's statement to the World Congress of Consumerists, when he said:
What we are saying is that modern capitalism is frightfully undemocratic, whether transnational or local. Let's get it clear, the capitalist system is the cause of the problem.

In the late 1970s and early 1980s Mr Crough was a frequent contributor to the Communist Party of Australia newspaper, the Tribune. In 1981 Mr Crough went to the Soviet Union with Professor Wheelwright-bearing in mind that Professor Wheelwright was then in his sixties-as a delegate to an international seminar of youth researchers. Indeed, Mr Crough was a delegate at that time together with a representative from the Young Socialist League of Australia.

In 1985 Mr Crough was first appointed as a consultant to the Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen. As I understand, and in the terms of his appointment which I have cited, that position still exists. In 1987 Mr Crough was one of four people who were on the selection committee which appointed Mr Alan Asher to the Trade Practices Commission. The answer that I received in this place to my original question was that there had been extensive advertising and interviewing for this job. In fact, there had been two applicants after what I would describe as a rather limited advertising program. I think it is important to draw the attention of the Senate to this matter for the simple reason that very often we hear this Government talked about in fairly benign terms. I think it important that people be alerted to the hidden and second agenda.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report for 1986-87 of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) comes at a time when the Service is under review by the current Government. Consequently, the interest that people might have in the report really tends to focus on the issues that are being discussed by the Department of Transport and Communications in the preparation of a review to be presented to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) rather more perhaps than on the issues that are set out in the report itself.

It is interesting to note first of all that there has been a change in the management of SBS in the last year. We find that the new head of SBS is to be Mr Brian Johns who, of course, is well known in Australian Labor Party circles. I understand he has worked for the Australian Labor Party in various fields. Consequently, his appointment comes as no great surprise, given the history of Labor in recent times. We know however that Mr Johns has a background in the literary field; he was the former head of Penguin Books. It is perhaps interesting to note that by leaving that organisation he created a vacancy that was immediately filled by the appointment of former Senator Susan Ryan.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the logic of that?

—I just make the point. The Special Broadcasting Service is currently, as I said, up for review. There are a number of matters that require attention by government-and primarily there is, of course, the fundamental question of funding. We know that the SBS provides a service par excellence for those people who listen to radio and who can understand very little English. Consequently, the foreign language broadcasts are of great importance to them. We salute the SBS for its continuing attempts to ensure that it has the widest possible coverage throughout Australia for those people who require that kind of service.

SPEECH.PARA: As regards the television operations of SBS, we know that they are, of course, substantially hampered by a lack of funds. However, generally speaking, it does provide a very good service. It is interesting to note that many of its programs are watched by large numbers of people who of course have what might be described as non-ethnic backgrounds. Programs such as the international news and international soccer broadcasts have a very high reputation. Those sorts of programs no doubt are substantially adding value to the Australian community generally. They also run in harness with other television programs which might be described as highbrow subjects. We often hear opera and see ballet and other material of cultural value on SBS. We commend SBS for that. However, there does seem to be something of a diminishing emphasis on multicultural television on SBS and we wonder whether the Government in its review is considering winding down that aspect of the Special Broadcasting Service. No doubt that will emerge in the course of the review currently being undertaken by the Minister.

Finally I raise the vexed question of the merger of the SBS and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which was proposed by the Government about a year ago. That, of course, was knocked on the head by the combined efforts of the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats in the Senate. I understand that that matter is still on the Government's agenda and no doubt will surface again in the course of the current review being undertaken by the Minister. We will watch that development with a great deal of interest.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) is, to say the very least, in crisis. There is absolutely no doubt that the Government has so mishandled the operations of the Tribunal-I will come to an example of that in a moment-as to have created a crisis of morale and conscience within the organisation to the point where one wonders whether the Tribunal is, in fact, carrying out its proper duties or, indeed, is able to carry out its proper duties. I instance the example of the Government's mishandling last September of the proposal, as announced in the Budget, to call for tenders for new radio licences from those people seeking to establish new radio stations. Of course this was done totally without consultation with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Obviously, it cut right across the operations of the Tribunal in such a way as to render its processes absolutely irrelevant. As I say, this was done without any consultation with the Tribunal. It has produced a crisis within the Tribunal. The Chairman has made public statements. The implication of those statements is that the Tribunal's processes and the very existence of the Tribunal need to be questioned. We know the Tribunal performs many valuable duties in examining the material which is broadcast on commercial television and radio. It makes sure that certain standards are maintained. We believe that those processes are worth keeping, but we do note that the processes are in great need of reform and streamlining. The time taken for the hearings of new licences, such as Perth's third licence, is, clearly, outrageous. It took something like 18 months to have the processes completed. Those issues have indicated that the Tribunal is in need of a great deal of change. We know that the Expenditure Review Committee is currently examining the Tribunal. We look forward to its report and to its suggestions as to what might be done to alter the direction of the Tribunal and how it might operate more effectively. Certainly, we have some suggestions which will be made known in proper time as we approach the next election and as we release our policies with regard to communications generally.

I believe it is time for a major review and rethink of the Tribunal and its operations and direction. It is too costly to operate. It is too costly to business and to the broadcasting industry generally in the way it ties up very expensive legal counsel for days, weeks and months on end for what appears to be very minute results. That is something which should touch the hearts of Ministers in the Government such as Senator Walsh who are very concerned about efficiency and where Government expenditure is going.

Finally, the Tribunal report we are discussing today is full of information which we will be examining in detail in the next few months. We will use that as the basis for the preparation of our own policy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN LOCAL GOVERNMENT GRANTS COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am very pleased to see the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) in the chamber. I know she is a busy lady. I hope she takes note of some of the comments I will make. Page 14 of the report is interesting. I happened to be glancing through it and noticed that the Local Government Grants Commission in Western Australia made similar comments to those made by the Grants Commission in Tasmania. The Government has been saying-it may be true-that its level of funding to local government in real terms has not changed. The report states:

For both years the inflation rate was higher than the increase of general purpose payments to the States. For 1987/88 the CPI increase for the year ended March 1988 was 8%, whereas the increase of general purpose payments to the States was 2.38%.
It continues:
The Western Australian entitlement as specified by the Act is-
1986/87 9.3028% of total fund
1987/88 9.2407% of total fund
1988/89 9.1788% of total fund
The last year shows a reduction in the State's share.

That follows from some comments made by the Grants Commission in Tasmania that in real terms Tasmania has had a reduction of 5 per cent in general purpose grants from the Federal Government this year and is looking at another 5 per cent reduction next year. Western Australia will also receive reduced grants. This obviously leads us to believe that other States in Australia will receive more. I have difficulty in accepting this and what the Minister had to say in answer to questions on one or two occasions when she said that the new system of making grants available was on a more equitable basis. It seems that States such as Tasmania and Western Australia which are further away from the so-called centre of government are treated less favourably.

TALK.START.PARA: —We get left out all the time, don't we?

—They are getting left out all the time, Senator. On top of that we find in the report of the Cameron Independent Committee of Inquiry into the Distribution of Federal Road Grants that road funding has decreased by over 40 per cent in real terms in the last four years without any consultation with local government.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Senate to take these matters on board. Mr Hawke was in Hobart two or three weeks ago and addressed some representatives of local government. I, Senator Tate and a few other members of the Australian Labor Party were there. Mr Hawke made a great point about how sympathetic he and the Government were to local government. He commented that he had a special place in his heart for local government. I just wish the rest of Cabinet shared that view because it seems to me on these figures and the comments made by States Grants Commissions and the Cameron report that local government has been hoodwinked into believing that it is receiving increased funding when there are records and reports to show quite the opposite.

I agree with the Labor member for Denison, Duncan Kerr, who called on the Government to come up with a more equitable grant payment structure. I disagree with what the Minister has been saying for some time now that this new system is a more equitable way of distributing funds to local government because two States are, quite obviously, receiving less. If that is not inequitable, I do not know what is.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a few remarks to indicate that I was disappointed with one aspect of this annual report of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I shall mention only that matter in my comments this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year when I was discussing the Corporation's annual report for 1985-86, I made specific reference to one section of the Board's report to the Minister. A copy of that report was reproduced at the beginning of the annual report. In this report the Board commented on its accountability and referred to the then Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. It implied that the Committee should not have pursued a particular inquiry because it was interfering with the independence of the ABC. The inquiry mentioned was into the adequacy of the ABC's radio racing service in Queensland. I noted last year that this chamber by that time had resolved that the Corporation had acted wrongly in frustrating the efforts of a committee established by a House of the Federal Parliament. Last year I concluded my remarks on this matter by saying that I expected that, in its next annual report, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would report factually on what occurred after it refused to co-operate with the Senate Committee. I should have known better. The only reference in the ABC's 1986-87 annual report was on page 66, which said:

The year also saw the curtain lowered on two issues of dispute between Parliament and the ABC: the Queensland radio racing inquiry (before the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts) and the long-running Cotton matter (before the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs).

I am sorry that the ABC did not see fit to put in its report the way that this inquiry ended because, when the Senate had examined this matter, it resolved that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was correct in what it had done. It requested that Committee to reconsider, in the light of its own evidence and the answers subsequently given by the ABC to the Senate Estimates Committee, whether further investigation was required. The Committee decided to do this and the investigation was carried out. This should have been mentioned in the report. Apparently the ABC likes to dish it out, but when the ABC is found to be in error it is not willing to admit it.
