DEBATE.TITLE: ESSENTIAL SERVICES IN NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its concern about the breakdowns to essential services in New South Wales associated with the policies of the Unsworth Government, and calls on the New South Wales Labor Government to use Commonwealth grants to the State to the advantage and benefit of all the citizens of that State.

The motion relates to the sorry state in which the people of the State of New South Wales find themselves today. After 11 years of Labor Government, my State finds itself in a position of disarray and disorder. It finds its essential services worse than they were last year, worse than they were 10 years ago and worse than they were year by year. The State finds these services getting worse all the time. This is well known, and I shall now document just part of the disorder and disarray. Some of my colleagues from the State of New South Wales will add other areas and other detail to what is a sorry and continuing story of what has happened in the potentially great State of New South Wales.

This motion is about the breakdown of essential New South Wales Government services like law enforcement, health, transport, education, housing and planning. It is about wrong priorities, corrupt decisions within government, and about ineffective and inefficient management. It is about the inadequate delivery by both the Wran and Unsworth governments, by all the Labor governments over a decade, of the basic services which State governments are supposed to provide. Overall it is about a government that has favoured the rich.

As the Government has allowed its public services to deteriorate it has been only the rich who have been able to afford to pay for private services to replace them. Most citizens who rely on public services have seen these running down and less able to serve them. Labor's policies have lowered the living standards and quality of life of people who use public hospitals, public schools and public transport, and who rely upon public housing in the State of New South Wales-in other words, the vast majority of the citizens of my State, the vast majority of New South Wales people.

Let us look first at the question of law enforcement. There is an old political maxim: the politician who seeks to take credit for the rain must also take the blame for the flood. The New South Wales Labor Party has sought to take much credit for what it has done in the area of law enforcement. It sought to take credit for its efforts in law enforcement, so let us examine the record and see what it is. A police report released last September indicated that the New South Wales crime rate had increased dramatically in just one year. Offences against the person had risen by 20 per cent in one year; fraud was up by 13 per cent in one year; home burglaries had risen by 12 per cent in one year; vandalism was up by 9 per cent in one year; and car theft rose by 6 per cent in one year. That means that in the State of New South Wales, the premier State of Australia, a crime is reported every 76 seconds; a car theft occurs every 8 minutes; a burglary occurs every 9 minutes; and an assault occurs every 30 minutes.

Even the figures released very recently with desperation by the Australian Labor Party (ALP), released just last Monday I believe, show only a small blip in what is an ever-increasing crime rate. The figures show that there were over 198,000 crimes reported in New South Wales in the past six months, that offences against the person, including assault and armed robbery, had again risen, this time by 17.5 per cent. Since a Labor government came to power in New South Wales in 1976, crime has flourished. Total reported crime is up by 170 per cent; car theft is up eight times; vandalism is up four times; and property theft is up by 130 per cent.

Because the numbers of police in my State of New South Wales have not been increased appropriately to deal with this crime wave, it has meant, in effect, that the police workload has doubled. The police of New South Wales have been unable to do what they are technically capable of doing if only they were given the persons and the resources. Finally and recently the Government has decided to pinch, to steal, some of the Opposition policies in relation to the police force in New South Wales. But the public knows whose policies they were and the public knows the origins of the policies to which Labor is now turning.

A Greiner government will address the problem of crime and will address it effectively. It has released detailed policies on police numbers, and detailed policies on its approach to charging, on its approach to sentencing and on corrective services, and those policies will work.

I turn to health. The record of the Labor Government in New South Wales since 1976 in the field of health has been no better. When the ALP was elected in 1976, New South Wales had one of the best hospital systems in the world. Having worked in a teaching hospital in New South Wales until 1974, I know just how good they were, and just how good our hospital system had been and how proud one could be to be associated with any part of the hospital system in New South Wales. However, since then the course has been steadily and rapidly downhill. By starving the hospital system of funds, by politicising the boards of hospitals, by allowing the reduction of total hospital beds, by pretending that they were increasing hospital beds, we have reached the situation where people in my State cannot get hospital care as easily as they could. The so-called `beds to the west' program was, in fact, a bed reduction program. More hospital beds were closed in some areas of my city of Sydney than were opened in the western suburbs. The result was a net loss of beds. Dispute after dispute with the doctors of New South Wales-most of the disputes unnecessary, most of them provoked by the Government-have merely been one other way in which services have been reduced and made more difficult to obtain. By slamming the door on the development and opening of new private hospitals, the situation has been aggravated even further.

Today the New South Wales public hospital system is in crisis. There are waiting lists of more than 30,000 patients who face waiting times of up to 2 1/2 years to get beds for surgery. Some of the surgery for which they are waiting involves things like the removal of cataracts-curable if they can get services-hip replacement to relieve the pain of an osteoarthritic hip, and so on. More than 2,000 public hospital beds have been closed, doctor and nurse training has been jeopardised, and there has been, as I say, a ban on private hospital expansion. Budget cuts have forced many other services in our public hospitals to be abandoned. This means more trouble, more pain, more waiting, more suffering and more inconvenience for New South Wales citizens.

It has been caused by Labor policies over a decade, by Labor governments which have had clear majorities throughout the Parliament of New South Wales, which have returned several times and which have had ample opportunity to demonstrate and put into effect the policies which they advocate. We have seen money available to New South Wales put into projects-circuses I think I could call them-such as the Darling Harbour project. The money for that project has been taken out of that available for essential services such as hospitals with results that are now evident to every citizen of New South Wales.

Another key indicator of the sickness of the hospital system is that nurses are refusing to work in hospitals; they are refusing to stay; they are withdrawing from the work force. One of the reasons why so many beds are closed is that nurses will not work in the system, they will not stay there to service the beds. Their conditions are bad and their morale has been lowered, it is so bad they they have voted with their feet against the system. Labor's response has been one of pretence. We saw those appalling advertisements that appeared in newspapers and on television screens in the last few weeks which set out a situation which did not exist. The costs of those advertisements represented the salaries of not inconsiderable numbers of health workers who could have been in the system had the money been applied where it should have been, to the service of people of New South Wales.

Let us not forget that Senator Richardson talked about the period during which Labor had ruled New South Wales. `Ruled' is the word the Labor Party uses. Its rule-if that is the word it wants to use-has been characterised by an ever-diminishing level of service in the health area. The same applies in education. The education system has been the subject of constant criticism, most recently by Labor's former President, John Ducker, who as Chairman of the Public Service Board of New South Wales found `serious deficiencies' in the education system. He cited-and I am quoting nobody other than the former Labor heavy-the high number of consultants in the education system as being totally inconsistent with the so-called back to basics approach to which the Premier said he was committed. Labor's own man, John Ducker, said that the education system had failed his efficiency audit from the Public Service Board of New South Wales.

Three tests are being applied by the people of New South Wales. First, the employers and the general citizenry have a sense that the education system is not delivering what they want. Too many children are leaving the system with no credentials. Too many employers are finding it impossible to employ entrants who have the adequate levels of literacy and numeracy for the jobs which they want to be done. The second test which we can apply is to examine parent satisfaction with the school system. The rush to take children from the public school system into the non-government school system is a matter of record. I think I am not the only senator who was present at a meeting that we held in the Sydney Town Hall in 1983 when not only was the Town Hall full but also the Town Hall surrounds were full of parents who were concerned about their children's education. The third way in which we can measure dissatisfaction in the education system is from the children. There is alienation to an unprecedented degree in New South Wales. There are too many children trying to burn down their schools as their expression of what they think about what is going on in the State. Education is in disarray because standards have not been maintained, because students are not being encouraged to master basic subjects such as maths, spelling and English. I merely report that it is not now permitted for teachers to teach grammar as a discipline in the high schools of New South Wales.

New South Wales has the lowest retention rate to year 12 of any mainland State. That is the legacy of the Labor government that we have had for over a decade. The education system has failed among other things because all the specialist schools which have contributed so much in special areas have been closed and there is less choice for students with special talents, special needs or special problems.

The discipline in our schools has lessened and the parents will attest to this. I recently had a parent telling me about the maths class in which her child was enrolled in which the teacher sat and read a newspaper because he had some discipline problems and therefore decided he would not teach mathematics to the children. That is a breach of faith. The principal of the school should deal with the discipline problems among the students and require the teacher to do the job for which he is drawing a public salary. Drugs, vandalism and violence have become all too prevalent in our schools in New South Wales, particularly in the last few years. The school system has run down and Nick Greiner and the Liberal Party are prepared to overcome some of the problems. Nick Greiner has already released policies to strengthen the public school system. He has released policies which will reverse the flow of students from public to private schools. He has released policies to allow parents to have a greater say in education in New South Wales and he has released policies which will restore confidence and standards in education.

I will move just briefly over a couple of other areas. In transport, the railways system has become so inefficient and ineffective that the Labor Party has in fact redefined what the phrase `running on time' means for our trains. The redefinition is that a train is on time if it is no more than five minutes late. But recent statistics have shown that even under that redefinition that a train is on time if it is less than five minutes late, only three-quarters of trains run `on time'. In addition, it is well known in New South Wales that lawlessness on trains has become so frequent that it is a worry to allow one's women folk or children to ride unaccompanied on public transport, particularly trains in New South Wales, late at night.

In housing, the level of homelessness and need in New South Wales has been of great concern to Nick Greiner. He gave a major address to the State Council of the Liberal Party about a week ago in which he stressed the problem of homelessness. He made the point that providing shelter for all the people of New South Wales was one of his priorities and would be one of the priorities of an incoming Greiner Liberal government. It has not been a priority of the Labor Party. What we have seen is the provision of the most inappropriate kind of public housing. Only recently we saw the purchase, development and letting of some of the most expensive waterfront land in Elizabeth Bay for a public housing project. That same money, reapplied in a less grandiose way in other parts of Sydney and other parts of New South Wales, could have provided many more housing units. There are 60,000 people on the public housing waiting lists in New South Wales. There is a shortage of housing land for the citizens of my State. New South Wales has the highest property prices in Australia so it is harder to get a home there. There are 10,000 homeless people in Sydney. We have the highest rents in Australia and we have the lowest vacancy rates.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I could go on. I could point out the failures in planning, the ways in which the Labor Government of New South Wales has moved to sack any council which has not fitted in with its plan for unrestricted development, the way in which it has passed Acts of parliament to take planning decisions out of the hands of democratically elected local councils. We have seen the way in which it has planned and executed the Darling Harbour project, the monorail, the Eastgate development, the harbour tunnel, the Leura development and many other activities, all of them at the expense of local government and at the expense of the environment and planning regulations and conditions which apply to ordinary citizens in New South Wales.

The people of New South Wales are sick of the Labor Government. They are sick of Mr Unsworth. The people of New South Wales do not like him and they want a change. The Premier has even decided as a strategy that he will try to present himself as the carefully packaged and presented underdog in the election. Some underdog! Barrie Unsworth is the Premier. He is the incumbent. He is not the challenger, as Nick Greiner is. Barrie Unsworth has a gerrymander operating to his advantage, not against him, as Nick Greiner does. Labor can hold office in New South Wales with just 48 per cent of the two party preferred vote. Nick Greiner needs 52 per cent of the two party preferred vote to gain government. Barrie Unsworth as the underdog? How ridiculous! He is the Premier who has managed to represent his Rockdale seat from the leafy glades of Turramurra, where he was a constituent of Nick Greiner's, and did not even deign to live among his own constituents until latterly. He has scuttled back to Rockdale in the last few weeks for the purpose of the election and for the duration of the election period. He has no right to present himself as anything other than the incumbent Premier, with patronage at his disposal and protected by a substantial majority and a substantial gerrymander.

We are sick of the Labor Party and its Government in New South Wales. The Premier must call the election which by rights we should have had last December. The people of New South Wales will determine the issue as soon as the election is called. Labor today is up against a clean, young, dynamic, vigorous, determined and tough Opposition under a first rate leader in Nick Greiner; an Opposition which is ready for Government and ready to govern. It is time for change in New South Wales-a change for the better in every way. The people of New South Wales are sick of patronage, cronyism, Labor's Tammany Hall Government and factional dictatorship. They are fed up with the corruption that sticks around the Labor Government, now coming to its end. With Nick Greiner, we look forward to new arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States to benefit the whole community. It will be clean and straightforward government, eager and ready to achieve. All that Nick Greiner needs now is the date of the election. Whenever the contest arrives Nick Greiner and the Liberal Party will win. When he wins, the people of New South Wales will win as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Peter Baume and stress again that this motion concerns the breakdown of essential services in New South Wales due to the decadent policies of the Unsworth Government and the misuse of Federal funds on the priorities allocated by this Parliament. Senator Baume stressed three important areas; areas which reflect the essence of what has happened in New South Wales-law and order, education and health.

SPEECH.PARA: I choose to speak first on health because a report has become available today from the Southern Metropolitan Regional Office of the New South Wales Department of Health, under the signature of its Regional Director, Mr J. D. Campbell. It is dated 4 December 1987 and concerns the capital works program of expenditure in that region on hospitals. It refers to a backlog of expenditure on capital works of $400m. It refers to two major high rise buildings that have walls supported by scaffolding and chicken wire. Several central energy plants are well past their economic life and could fail Department of Industrial Relations safety regulations at any time. Roofs are leaking, listed heritage buildings are decaying and Telecom Australia has advised that it will not service many of the hospitals' PABX telephone systems after December 1988. Clinical diagnostic and treatment equipment is breaking down due to age faster than it can be replaced. This region includes hospitals such as the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital and major teaching hospitals. It is a disgraceful litany of the rundown and the mis-allocation of funds in New South Wales concerning health. I seek leave to incorporate this report into Hansard.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows-

Enclosed please find this Region's Forward Works submission for consideration for inclusion in the Draft Capital Works Programme for 1988-1992. Following discussion with Mr Bland, the value of projects has been based at June 1988 prices, as in previous years, rather than at December 1987 prices as requested.

Your attention is drawn to the fact that the backlog of capital project in this Region now exceeds $400 million and the state of major plant equipment and building stock in many hospitals is extremely poor. It is the belief of many of the Area and Regional personnel that disasters have only been averted by ``good luck''.

Two major high-rise buildings, have walls supported by scaffolding and chicken wire, several central energy plants are well past their economic life and could fail D.I.R. safety inspections at any time; roofs are leaking; listed heritage buildings are decaying; Telecom has advised they will not service many of the hospitals' P.A.B.X. Telephone Systems after December 1988 and clinical diagnostic and treatment equipment is breaking down due to age faster than it can be replaced.

It is requested that this state of affairs be drawn to the attention of the Capital Works Committee and to Treasury rather than continuing the process whereby only one or two new projects are put forward from each Region each year to meet predetermined capital allocations which are grossly inadequate.

It is noted that several projects which have only recently been drawn to my attention have not been included in the Forward Works Programme at this time, pending receipt of further detailed information.
These projects include:

(i) two hundred additional beds at St George Hospital, a suggestion raised by the Minister for Health in discussion with the Area Chief Executive Officer. As demographic studies do not support the need for increased beds in this area, engineering services are not adequate and land is not available, this item has been held in abeyance.

(ii) redevelopment of Karitane Mothercraft Society on its existing site, put forward by the Eastern Area Health Service. It is understood that this project may be in conflict with proposals being developed by the Benevolent Society and further advise is awaited.
(iii) redevelopment of Langton Clinic, on its existing site. No developed proposals have been received from the Eastern Area Health Service.
In relation to the component parts of the Programme, the following comments are made:
Major Works Over $3 Million

Estimates of costs of works shown in this category should be regarded as broad based estimates only at this time and the refinement of budgets will be dependent on pre planning approvals being given and funds being made available. The estimates shown for St. Vincent's Redevelopment and Prince of Wales Redevelopment is a guesstimate and can only be refined following the preparation of Master Development Control Plans at hospital/or area level.
The estimates of ongoing development programmes at R.P.A.H., R.A.H.C. and St George Hospitals have been extracted from Master Development Control Plans previously prepared by the Department.
Works Under $3 Million

The number of outstanding works required in this category continues to increase, reflecting the fact that only two such projects have been funded in this Region in the last seven years. Projects of this value are outside the Region's capacity to pay, but would result in significant improvements in clinical services at hospitals' minimal cost, should they proceed.

The Department is urged to consider seeking to increase the number of small scale projects in this category on the 1988/92 programmes. The lead time for planning projects of this size is reasonably short and if pre planning funds were made available to take the projects up to the end of the tender documentation stage, these would be able to be rapidly brought on to the capital works programme at any time, to utilize under expenditure during the year, if such a proposal was accepted by Treasury.
Major Plant and Equipment
The section has again been included in the Programme to alert you to the poor state of the plant in this Region, which has at least 10 hospitals more than 100 years old.

The current R.M.R. (operating) fund allocation is barely sufficient to cover maintenance contract costs on sophisticated medical/technical equipment, let alone replace or refurbish major engineering plant and equipment.
There are considerable operating savings to be made in some of the projects scheduled, but ``up front'' capital allocations are required to enable such saving to be made.
Attention is drawn to the fact that if some funds are not allocated to this area in the near future, emergency allocations may well be required when plant fails.
Fire Protection Projects

This Region has a significant backlog of projects in this area because of the age of its buildings. As previously advised, the T.A.S.S. proposal that all funds allocated should be devoted to the installation of early warning systems because this is a broad based recommendation of the Board of Fire Commissioners, is not supported. The Region has some instances where fire separation and egress is of greater importance.
This year's proposed allocation to the Region of $200,000 is grossly inadequate based on the current need and the size, age and number of institutions and the increasing Code Requirements.
Making Health More Caring

The extension of the initial 3 year programme to four years in the last year without prior warnings, when many projects had already reached tender documentation state, or were under construction, caused significant problems to this Region.
If the programme is to be extended, a defined Regional allocation is requested for each financial year so that finite plans can be made.
Community Health-Capital
The Darlinghurst Police Station was handed over to the Department of Health this year, on the agreement of the Premier.

The renovation of this facility has been the Region's Number 1 priority in this category for the last four years. It is essential that funds be obtained in 1988/89 or the majority of the building will be left idle in the face of major community health demands. This would also be reprehensible when several other Government Departments made strong bids to secure the building for other essential services.
Land Acquisition of Sites Vote
General and Community Health

The funds provided in this vote in recent years have been inadequate and a larger allocation is required if the Region is to continue its programme of site consolidation both to enable hospital redevelopment and to reduce the need for high cost rent of facilities.
Asbestos Removal

The Region has now conducted detailed asbestos identification studies on most hospital sites. As a result, all capital works asbestos funds allocated to this Region are utilized for actual removal of asbestos.
Attention is again drawn to the age and state of the building stock in this Region and the resultant heavy volume of asbestos to be removed.

An increase in funding in this area would be of great assistance in enabling ``high activity/high risk'' asbestos areas to be cleared in all 40 hospitals, and reduce the potential risks and possible industrial action.
Nuclear Medicine, Radiology, Ultrasound and Radiotherapy
Cardiac Monitoring
Pathology
These programmes have only been minimally upgraded from last year, reflecting the inadequate allocations in these areas.
General Issues

This Office would be pleased to provide updated or more detailed information, particularly relative to budget estimates and cash flow figures, during the period when the Department is negotiating on specific projects with Treasury, rather than waiting until the Draft Capital Works Programme is issued.
Members of the Facilities Planning and Construction Management Section would be pleased to meet with you to discuss any matters relative to programme.

Regional Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I compare the statement of the backlog of some $400m of expenditure with the sort of expenditure that we have seen on advertising paid for by taxpayers' dollars in the lead-up to this phony election campaign. Admitted to figures-out of the departmental budget-include the following: the Neighbourhood Watch advertisement has been allocated $877,000, and the school discipline advertisement $269,000. Imagine a government that takes out advertising to say that children in schools will be subject to discipline! Imagine even more the fact that these advertisements are run at lunch-time, in the middle of the day when, quite properly, the school children will be at school. No points for guessing at whom those advertisements are truly aimed!

SPEECH.PARA: What about the Tangara train advertisement? Somebody on talkback radio said this morning that it had been designed to look like Barrie Unsworth's face and that every time the train came in the station people would be reminded of his happy, smiling visage. It has been admitted that those advertisements cost a minimum of $364,000. We have seen Healthline advertisements on television which tell us that if we are sick we can get into a public hospital. There has to be something fundamentally wrong with a system which has to purport to advertise that people can get into a hospital if they are sick. That is why we have governments; that is why we have public sector hospitals. That little budget involved $784,000. How many beds could we have opened up for that? In the so-called re-allocation and new strategy for opening of beds in the west, New South Wales has lost 2,000 public hospital beds. It cost $784,000 to tell us that if we are sick we can get into a hospital. The only trouble is that people know they cannot. That applies whether one has a physical or mental illness.

Last Saturday morning I attended a seminar in Parramatta concerning disabled people, including disabled ethnic people. When it was thrown open to the attendees to put their point of view, one after another the parents and those people affected attacked the Richmond report. In a very emotional statement an Italian gentleman speaking through an interpreter explained how his daughter, living in a hospital and under medication, had managed to maintain a rather normal life. But as a result of the implementation of the Richmond report, in his words they had kicked her out. She is schizophrenic and there is no way that this man and his wife can enforce the taking of the medication that lets their daughter live a normal life. His words were, `Kick out the Ministers who kicked out my daughter'. We saw advertisements from the Water Board telling us that it is doing what it ought to be doing-that is, keeping our beaches clean. Those advertisements cost $447,000.

If we add up all these admitted expenditures then it comes to a total of $2,741,000, and that is the conservative estimate. The reality is that it is somewhere in the vicinity of $8m of taxpayers' money. Compare that with what we could have got for that sort of money. We can build a new primary school for just under $1m. We can build a secondary school for just over $1m. We can certainly open hospital beds. We can certainly staff the new houses that are being set up in order to take some of the people who are living successfully outside hospitals under the Richmond scheme. That alternative accommodation is not open for the very simple reason that the money is not being made available. It is the problem with the allocation of priorities that has led to this rundown of essential services in New South Wales.

I turn to education. Today I read a report in the Daily Telegraph that tells me, to my amazement, that the State's 22,000 primary school teachers are to be told that their students must learn to read widely, spell accurately, write grammatically and solve mathematical problems.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate rose for dinner I had just begun to speak on the question of education and the breakdown of services in education in New South Wales as part of that fundamental breakdown of delivery of service under the Unsworth Labor Government. I was referring to an article in this morning's Daily Telegraph, which reported upon a new document which is being issued to schools. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The State's 22,000 primary school teachers are to be told-
future tense-
their students must learn to read widely, spell accurately, write grammatically and solve mathematical problems.

According to the report these instructions are contained in a 30 page handbook called The Primary Purpose which is currently being distributed to the 1,670 New South Wales government primary schools. What an astonishing thing to say. In 1988, our bicentennial year, after great hardship and great effort we have established Australia, which we are proud to call home, but the New South Wales Government is only now saying that children are to read widely, spell accurately, write grammatically and solve mathematical problems. One wonders what on earth the New South Wales Department of Education has been doing in the interim.
The report goes on to say:
The booklet prepared by the Education Department, tells teachers all children must be taught six `major learning areas'.
These are: language; mathematics; science and technology; human society and its environment; creative and practical arts; and health, physical education and personal development.

It is absolutely essential that every student in every primary school in NSW be provided with significant opportunities for learning in all of the six areas in every year as he or she progresses through the primary school . . .

If it has taken until 1988 for the State Education Department to say that this must be taught in the public sector, is it any wonder that 27 per cent of school children in New South Wales are now in the private sector? Is it any wonder that the waiting lists for the private sector are as long as my arm? Is it any wonder that parents are seeking a proper education for their children as distinct from the one that is made available?

What a curious thing it is, when we have Minister Dawkins calling for a competitive society, that we have education ministers in Labor governments saying that competition is not good for children. If children are to grow into strong, competing adults, surely competition is something which has to be experienced at the school level. Kids are not to be fooled. The kids know what competition is all about. The kids themselves have a term for subjects which they consider to be of no merit-and the `in' term is `vegie subjects'. The kids cannot be fooled and yet they are being denied, and have been denied prior to this brand new statement-which just happens to coincide with an election-what it is that they are meant to achieve.

Last year our household experienced the Higher School Certificate in New South Wales and we experienced the unknowns and the indeterminate standards of the so-called scaling system which has been introduced. I have yet to meet one person who understands what scaling is. In our case we were fortunate because the particular child was able to get into the course that she wanted to do, and I am also pleased to say that it is mathematics, physics, chemistry and biology. The advice that was available, and the understanding or the myths and legends that surrounded the information given about education, was that perhaps we ought not to bother with the three units in mathematics, because two units would probably do. But we were not told that all two-unit subjects were then scaled and that three-unit subjects got their own mark. So the knowledge that there was reward for effort, or that there was indeed some sort of acknowledgment of rigour, was kept quiet because that was about, surely, competition.

It is very worrying to me to see a statement such as this coming out of the New South Wales Education Department, under Minister Cavalier, who is a man fighting to save his own seat. He has suddenly discovered that children in primary school need to read widely, spell accurately, write grammatically and solve mathematical problems. What a revelation!

I would now like to turn to the area of law and order. Senator Peter Baume touched on this area in his speech; indeed, he dealt with it at great length. He gave some quite startling figures. He talked about the increase in crime and the increase of loss of safety to the citizens of New South Wales. An interesting statistic that he did not give on this occasion, but which perhaps is useful for us to have, is that although New South Wales has one-third of the population of Australia it also has one-half of drug related crime. When we look at the question of drug related crime it is very relevant to look at it in two parts. Firstly, there is the rather public aspect of crime. That is the problem of, firstly, the police treatment of criminals. Police ought not be utilised in doing the sort of public relations (PR) exercise presently in effect in New South Wales. Policemen are being put into schools and those schools are supposed to treat them as some sort of PR entity. Indeed there was a letter released by the Labor Party Government in New South Wales asking that policemen collect statistics that could be politically useful to the Government. That has got nothing to do with fighting crime or arresting criminals. The question of the utilisation of the police force, as well as the question of the expansion of the police force, is particularly relevant.

The second question in this area is that of bail. Almost daily we can pick up our newspapers and read items about people who are out on bail and who are committing serious, fresh offences. Indeed, perhaps the most notorious case is the so-called `Fatal Attraction Case', which, of course, in turn has been picked up from the Oscar award movie Fatal Attraction, where there was some sort of triangle but where the person who committed the alleged crime was on bail and has now absconded.

Thirdly, there is the question of the prisons themselves. In New South Wales prisons we have an enormous problem with drug usage and, of course, the problem of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, AIDS. Any person who lives in a humane society is going to be of the view that when someone goes to gaol he is there to serve a penalty, to atone for the crime that was committed against society. He certainly does not go in there to become a drug addict, to be raped or to be infected with AIDS. Yet that is the situation we presently have in New South Wales gaols. The current incumbent Government will simply not implement a regime whereby all contact visits with prisoners are subject to searching. The Police Minister, Mr Paciullo, states that it would not be satisfactory for contact visits to be searched because they might be subject to some indelicacies. If there are some indelicacies associated with the searching of contact visits in prisons, which will stop the proliferation of drugs and the spread of AIDS, I do not think it is an option, it is a necessity.

The fourth question that is relevant in the public area of law and order is the question of sentencing. Many victims and their families feel a sense of injustice that people who are sentenced do not get a punishment that fits the crime, that they are given a sentence which is never followed through to the literal meaning of that sentence. Under a Greiner government there would be a policy of truth in sentencing. The ordinary person could assume that if somebody were sentenced to X number of years imprisonment that is what he would get, and that if the parole period were set at somewhat less than the remissions and the like that are given under the current system, it would not come off the parole period but only off the head sentence. Truth in sentencing is something that the people of New South Wales have demanded. Again, this goes to the very essence of essential services in our State.

The second aspect of law and order is more personal, the one that deals with how an individual lifestyle is debilitated by the fact that no adequate system of law and order operates. Senator Baume mentioned the fear many people have for their children travelling on trains. Our public transport system is eating up taxpayers' money at an enormous rate yet we have a system on which it is not safe for teenagers and even young adults to travel alone. There is the fear of the elderly who are virtual prisoners in their own homes, frightened to go out lest they be mugged.

Then there is the loss of the family car. I put it that way rather than talk about the great number of automobile thefts which is somehow impersonal and which in many people's minds seems to relate to insurance companies. What I am talking about is the personal sense of violation, when an individual finds that his car, on which he has lavished love and which he has saved very hard to own, has been stolen. An important aspect of a person's life has been broken into. The seats and the radio have been ripped out. The people that I serve in the western suburbs, the area of Sydney where my electorate is situated, are dependent on the private car because public transport is so inadequate. The violation of the vehicles of people who do not have easy access to public transport is even greater.

The issues of law and order are on two levels. There are the grand, bold figures on the amount of crime that is committed. There are the grand, bold figures of insurance valuations. But what one cannot count, what one cannot put into figures, is the personal violation and anguish suffered by people who have saved, who value their possessions and who have planned. These are very much quality of life issues.

The issues that I have touched on-health, law and order, and education-are issues that relate to all of us. They are the issues on which the people of New South Wales will base their decision. I said in the early part of my speech that we were going into an election where the people of New South Wales are being treated cynically by the Government. I pointed out that there had been expenditures of taxpayers' funds to achieve free publicity through a phoney election period to try to dissuade the people of New South Wales from making a sensible decision.

Another important point Senator Peter Baume raised relates to the gerrymander and Barrie Unsworth trying to make out that he is the underdog. Since I have been a member of this chamber I have heard lots of rhetoric coming from the Government benches about the gerrymander in Queensland. But at least it is up front. It is a bit like barriers to trade. If one is to have a barrier to trade let it be a tariff. Let us see it. Let us not have non-tariff barriers which are hidden and difficult to find. In Queensland the gerrymander is pretty obvious. One can see it. But in New South Wales it is very much more subtle. In New South Wales we, too, have a gerrymander, but it has been achieved not by zones or by declaring that the country vote or the semi-rural vote should have a bias; it has been achieved by utilising projected population figures for 1988. The basis for the fixing of those figures is not available.

Incredibly, when the people who live on the north coast of New South Wales, which is experiencing a huge growth in population of about 20 per cent a year, go to the polls the electorates will be over quota. Safe Labor seats will be under quota. The balance of those populations will have been redistributed into marginal seats. If that is what the Labor Party means by a clever marginal seat strategy, I understand what it is talking about. It is truly a gerrymander.

Gerrymander or not, whether we in the Liberal Party require more than 53 per cent of the vote to win government we will do it. The reasons we will do it were set out in the matter of public importance yesterday afternoon. The Labor Party has lost touch with the people. It does not understand the hopes and aspirations of the people. It believed that, in a cynical way, by advertising and manipulation, it could confuse the people sufficiently to believe that it was worthy of another go.

Neville Wran made many statements while he was Premier. Perhaps the most meaningful statement was this: No government that has been in power for 11 years deserves another try. Neville Wran said that in 1976. What the electorate has come to know and understand is that time is up. What the Labor Party is asking for in New South Wales is 16 years in government because, with four-year terms, if it is returned at the next election that is the term of office it will be seeking from the electorate.

Neville Wran said that no government that has been in power for 11 years deserves another try. He was right. New South Wales deserves a change for the better. New South Wales deserves good, honest government that will come in the personage of Nick Greiner. New South Wales deserves a good health system, a fine education system, a decent system of law and order, a housing policy that puts people before cynicism, the completion of a road system abandoned in 1976, a public transport system that again serves the needs of the people but, more particularly, a government that acknowledges that it is the people who have toiled the hardest who are threatened with superannuation tax changes, who have been threatened by timed telephone calls, who are threatened by the bad policies of the malappropriation of money in New South Wales, who know that the time has come. They will not be used and abused any more. Neville Wran got it right. Eleven years is enough. It is time for a change for the better. The time for the Labor Government in New South Wales is up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to enter the debate tonight until I spied Senator Michael Baume come into the chamber. The thought of having to sit here for half an hour on chamber duty and listen was too much for me. I do not know whether the few notes that I have jotted down could possibly be stretched out for 30 minutes and, realising that the debate finishes about one minute past nine and that Senator Michael Baume can never get into his stride inside 15 minutes, I may have to curtail my speech just a little. All we have heard so far in the debate, as in the discussion on the matter of public importance yesterday, has been five or six New South Wales policy speeches.
—What about New South Wales Labor?

—We have not heard five different speeches. We have heard the same speech five times over. We are about to hear a speech from one failed House of Representatives candidate while another interjects against an Australian Labor Party member who also failed to win a House of Representatives seat in 1969. At least I have never thrown away a House of Representatives seat. But for a small 9.1 per cent swing I would have been in the House of Representatives in 1969. But the person who interjected and the next person to speak already have a history of throwing away a Federal seat and being rejected by the people.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before, we have heard the same speech delivered five times. What a pity it is that former Senator Misha Lajovic is not here. I had a great admiration for the loyalty he showed to New South Wales and to the Liberal Party when he was here. It did not matter how badly the Liberals were going; he was here to fight for them when they were going at their worst. He never once deviated in his defence of them. In the 1984 election campaign I really enjoyed, as I am sure Senator Childs did, his vigorous defence of the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party in those days.

Of course, we will have a lot to say about the New South Wales election over the next few weeks, until whenever it is held. We will say it in the belief that we are about to change the tide one way or the other. We will all sprout thousands of words here. At times it will get heated. We will all think that we are having an influence over the New South Wales election. But when I look around this chamber I see only about three New South Wales voters, unless anyone at the table lives in Queanbeyan, and I have a rough idea which way they will vote. So I find it rather pointless that they are lecturing each other about the issues in the New South Wales election when they have already made up their mind which way they will vote.

In one way I am pleased with the New South Wales Liberal Party. It has finally got over its shell shock from Neville Wran. I have never said this publicly before but I remember very well in 1981 going into the tally room in New South Wales. I do not know whether my senatorial colleagues from New South Wales were present then; Senator Childs might have been there. The tally room was on about the fifth floor. Of course, Wran had won in a landslide in 1978 and everyone expected the big swing to come back. That night I really understood the Liberals' attitude to Neville Wran. Mr Carlton and quite a few of the leading lights in the Liberal Party were there. No one knew who I was. When Mr Wran came into the tally room, a big flood of reporters came in and I was edged into the Liberal camp. I was physically pushed across into the Liberal camp. I listened to all the comments from the New South Wales Liberals at that time. I heard how they hated Neville Wran. The comments went on for five minutes until one of them really put his foot in it when he said, `Oh, no, if only he were a Liberal. If only he had led the Liberal Party'. I suggested to the person making the comment that as the window was open and we were on the fifth floor, he should end it all right then. Nevertheless, he did not do that.

Neville Wran had a major effect on the New South Wales Liberal Party. I think we would all concede that it was a very depressing effect. He was a consummate politician. He was able to dominate the proceedings of the New South Wales Parliament with his intellectual vigour. He also had an ability that I have never seen in any other politician-to mix with all levels of society.

TALK.START.PARA: —He jumped out of the window.
—Senator Tambling interjects that he jumped out of the window.
—After 10 years!

—As Senator Collins says, after 10 years! The man ruled the State for 10 years. Wran's great strength, which I think was underestimated by the Liberal Party, was his ability to move in all sections of society and discuss a variety of subjects with them. He was always at ease. We have seen many other great political leaders, such as Gough Whitlam and Malcolm Fraser. They were never at ease with the public, be it at a garden party, doing a pub crawl or anything else. One always had a sense that they were not at ease and not relating smoothly to the rest of the voting public. That was the great ability that Neville Wran brought to politics, as well as his intellectual vigour and absolute domination. I suppose that is why he wiped out so many Liberal leaders in a 10-year period. There were about six or seven of them. Five of the seven were wiped out of the Parliament itself. That is not a bad track record in politics.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move on from that point. A point has been raised about the gerrymander in New South Wales. Of course, there is a clear distinction between gerrymandering and malapportionment. It is very easy to measure malapportionment. It does not exist at a Federal level. It hardly exists in any of the States. It does exist in Queensland. It exists in Western Australia, although that has been modified recently. Basically, a definition of malapportionment is where the distribution of seats results in many seats being out of kilter with others. That is easily defined. The Gini index or anything else can measure malapportionment very easily. But the word `gerrymander' implies something different. I think this is what Senator Bishop was trying to allude to. There can be a gerrymander even though every seat is of equal enrolment. Basically, a gerrymander results from a government trying to concentrate the votes of its opposition in one seat, leaving a majority-but only a bare majority-in the marginal seats and not having enormous majorities in the seats that it holds. That is gerrymandering.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could also have it without equal enrolment.
—I am just trying to draw the academic distinction. I have not gone into the politics of the matter yet.
—That is a euphemism.

—No, it is not a euphemism. In terms of political studies, there is a distinct difference between malapportionment and gerrymandering. Malapportionment may well be regarded as one element of gerrymandering. What I am trying to draw to Senator Bishop's attention has yet to deflect from the points she has made, so I do not know why she is interrupting.
—You are pitching the argument too high.

—I think I am. She may well be able to use the distinction I am using to make her point more validly in future. But I am pointing out the distinction, which too many people do not recognise, between malapportionment and gerrymandering. I was going on to say that with equal electorates there can still be gerrymandering. In other words, if the New South Wales lower House electorates all averaged 30,000 electors, there could still be a gerrymander. Gerrymandering is drawing the boundaries to maximise one's position. Malapportionment is not an essential element of that but is quite often associated with it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are difficulties in determining what a gerrymander is. Those difficulties come because there is no scientific measure; it is a subjective judgment. Again I say to Senator Bishop that none of this deflects from the points she has made, so she should just listen. There is no politically scientific method of measuring a gerrymander. An intentional gerrymander of the sort I am describing can be avoided with independent commissioners. Basically, that is what we have done at a national level. By having independent commissioners one tends to avoid that. But, of course, inadvertent gerrymanders occur. Historically, the classic example is Melbourne. Anyone who knows Melbourne knows that Labor is excessively strong in the west, very strong in the middle and the central suburbs and very strong in the north. Throughout the 1950s and 1960s there were massive Labor majorities in seats such as Melbourne Ports, Melbourne, Gellibrand, et cetera. Even if all the boundaries had been equal, Labor would have been disproportionately represented in the national Parliament because of this massive concentration of majorities in one area.

What has happened in Melbourne and may not have happened in Sydney-it may be the case in Sydney-is that the patterns have changed. Many of the working class members of society in Melbourne and lower middle class members have moved to the outer ring, to eastern suburbs, to seats such as La Trobe, Casey and Holt. They all moved out there. Consequently, many of the middle class members have moved to the inner city area because they can afford the higher property prices and, therefore, are charged lower transport costs. The gentrification of the inner city, as I understand it, is the same in Sydney as it is in Melbourne.

At present, we are at the halfway point of the tide; that is, Labor still has enough strength in the inner city areas with its traditional supporters to absorb the incoming middle class whether they are doctors, architects or whatever. That is very much one of the reasons why the Labor Party has been successful in the 1970s and 1980s. It would be a matter of concern and worry-not to the Opposition but to Labor-that once the tide or the graph intersects and goes past a certain point many of those inner city seats that were once Labor Party strongholds will become marginal Liberal seats and maybe eventually strong, true blue Liberal seats.

Against that background honourable senators have heard the accusation that the New South Wales boundaries are gerrymandered. The evidence of that may well be true; they may be gerrymandered. The Opposition has to prove whether that is an inadvertent gerrymander, like the one I have described in Melbourne, or a real one. The Opposition has failed to do that tonight. It has not mentioned or has not had the intestinal fortitude to name one commissioner who was crooked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Several commissioners in New South Wales have drawn up those boundaries under a rigid variation level set. The Opposition, to make and prove its point that the New South Wales Government had anything to do with rigging electoral boundaries, has to say in the open that the electoral commissioners are crooks. It will not because it knows that is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: The real riggers of electoral boundaries in New South Wales were those who got loose after 1965. When the boys from George Street and Ash Street got loose there was a majority in the Parliament. That is when there was a redistribution after every election. That is when there was not only gerrymandering but also malapportionment and I will say that the commissioners and those who redistributed after 1965 were no more than Liberal stooges. There was no independence about them. They had it down to an absolute art form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not have to deal with it.

—Again tonight we had the hypocrisy of Senator Bishop, who criticised New South Wales boundaries. If I have any evidence that they are crook, I will criticise them, but I am consistent. I criticised the Western Australian boundaries that are a legacy of Senator Panizza's Party. Recently a seat had 2,000 electors in it up until the last redistribution, and there were 38,000 and 40,000 in other seats. Did Senator Panizza, Senator Baume or Senator Messner ever criticise these sorts of boundaries? Never once have any honourable senators opposite bothered to get up and criticise the boundaries.

SPEECH.PARA: I will say one thing, though, Mr Innes, the new Queensland Liberal Party Leader, is the first leader of the Liberal Party with an ounce of backbone. He has condemned the Queensland boundaries. That is the first time ever, while the rest of the gutless wonders in the Opposition do and say nothing. They are very quick to criticise any Labor Party members who breach the electoral laws. They are very quick to do so; they will put out judgments and Press releases. Only the other day a National Party scrutineer was convicted in the courts for filling out ballot papers. Not one Press release or mention was made by members of the Opposition. When Mr Hinton, MLA, was convicted of bodgie enrolments, not one Press release or criticism emanated from the Opposition side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Nunawading?

—I will say this about Nunawading: no-one was convicted in Nunawading. All we have ever had from the Liberal Party is whinges about electoral systems that are badly based. It is always the electoral system that has robbed the Liberal Party. It sounds like the Labor Party of the 1960s. All Labor members used to whinge then but at least we have matured to recognise that a party must win 50 per cent of the vote and must win the hearts and minds of the people. Whingeing about the system will get the Liberal Party absolutely nowhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop raised some serious issues tonight when she mentioned education, law and order, and similar issues. I would be the last one to say that there are no problems in any one of those issues in any Australian State. The judgment we have to exercise-not I, because I am not a voter in New South Wales-is: who is best placed to solve those issues? When I first looked at the New South Wales Liberal Party I noticed Nick Greiner, the Leader, and then of course there is Mr Murray, the Leader of the National Party. I wonder which tail will wag the dog. The Liberal Party may even be able to make out a case that it is a credible alternative government. However, what will happen when it has to go into coalition with the National Party of New South Wales with all the old, boring rednecks?

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty per cent of the coalition are in the National Party.

—I thank Senator Childs for that intervention; 40 per cent of the coalition is the National Party. It will get back to its old pork-barrelling tricks-the Liberals free marketing will have to go out the door and the Liberal Party will be dictated to by the National Party of New South Wales. Then the Liberals will go to their State branches and councils and say, `The imperfection of this so-called Liberal State government is really our country cousins, the hicks from the bush, who will not let us get on with ruling the State'.

SPEECH.PARA: We put up with that in Victoria during the 1920s, the 1930s and the 1940s and I feel sorry for the Liberal Party because it will have to reduce the few standards it has to accommodate the National Party. It was so bad in Victoria in the early 1950s that some Liberal leaders had to say, `No more coalition with the National Party.' Victoria actually had a Country Party Government for eight years. In the end, after eight years of rule, the Country Party Government had built five high schools. When it left office, Melbourne, which I think had 55 per cent of the population, was left with four high schools and the country areas had 20. Those are the sorts of priorities of a country party, and the sorts of priorities it will put on any potential Liberal government.

Mr Greiner, therefore, might deliver a policy speech in one, two, or three weeks time, but he cannot guarantee any promises will be kept because he knows that Mr Murray and the redneck boys from the Country Party and National Party will put their oars in any spare money that is around. They will slosh it into all the useless dams they can find around the State and all the useless National Party causes that have blighted the nation for the past 20, 30, or 50 years. If ever a tribunal were established to try people in this country for failed contributions to politics, one would start with Earle Page and work through every National Party leader to Bjelke-Petersen. It would not be hard to get the jury of 12 to agree on their lack of contribution to Australian politics.

One has only to go back to 1971 when John McEwen stood over McMahon over the devaluation-revaluation issue, which was one of the most shameful aspects in Australian politics. Four years before that Jack McEwen vetoed the best qualified-maybe not the best leader-Liberal Party candidate for the leadership when he said that Bill McMahon could not become Prime Minister of this country.

One has only to go back to the 1950s to look at the efforts of the Faddens of the world and how they debauched Budgets in this country. One can go all the way back to Earle Page and his destabilisation around the start of the Second World War when internecine faction warfare between the Liberal and National or Country parties of the time was regarded as more important than the defence of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!

—I am watching Senator Schacht and I know how proudly he feels at the role he played in South Australia in reducing the Country Party to one member in that State. Even that, as Senator McKiernan says, is too many. South Australia has a stable government because the Country Party was wiped out. I see that Senator Crichton-Browne has come into the chamber. He played a major role in trying to destroy the Country Party in Western Australia. Through his manipulations he managed to split the Country Party in Western Australia, first into two parties and then into three parties. They have only just recently reunited. I am certain that Senator Crichton-Browne would be worried for the future, because he knows that the National Party is making a slight resurgence in Western Australia. Even if that party were ever given the slightest glimmer of hope of returning to power in that State, again there would be the problem of the National Party trying to dictate to it and to its leader, who is-I am sorry; I am fairly well read in Australian politics but I have no idea who the leader is--
—Barry MacKinnon.

—It is MacKinnon now, is it? What happened to Bill Hassell; what happened to Rocky O'Connor? They have all gone? I think that I may have been wrong in giving all the credit to Neville Wran for destroying Liberal leaders. Apparently the biggest club in Australia is the ex-Liberal State leader club. The only State that cannot get its act together in this regard is Victoria. In Victoria we have Mr Kennett leading. The last three challenges to his leadership have emanated at the time of the last three spring racing carnivals. Every spring carnival the plutocrats in Victoria come down and say to the Liberal State members, `You have got to get rid of that Kennett'. They all have a run at him and they all want to get rid of him, but they all want to take his place so they will not vote for each other. There is this terrible Mexican stand-off situation in which there are 50 State Liberal members; 40 want to get rid of Kennett but as soon as they are eliminated in a ballot they vote for the other bloke to give themselves a chance next time. Maybe we will have another challenge next spring carnival. Perhaps the Liberals will break with tradition and take him on during the autumn racing carnival-the Australia Cup-Newmarket double. I will be very interested to see what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: I am tending to stray a little from the subject of New South Wales. However, I am tempted to move an amendment to the Opposition motion to insert the words `Tasmania and Queensland' and remove any reference to New South Wales, because I think that is far more appropriate. We have only to look at the Australian economy to see which two States have the highest unemployment in Australia-Queensland and Tasmania. Nearly all the economic indicators show that Labor-run States have a far more vibrant and growing economy than any of the Liberal States. For example, the New South Wales unemployment figure is down to 7.5 per cent and it is continuing to fall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plugs for the election; that is all.

—Senator Newman has arrived at last. I just cannot wait for the Tasmanian election. If honourable senators think that these sorts of pathetic debates concerning New South Wales elections are important, let me say that they will be intensified once the State election in Tasmania comes up. That is the big game. This is only the reserves match in terms of State elections. When the Tasmanian election comes up we will be plagued with speakers because there will not be one Tasmanian who will not stand up and speak in one of these debates. Senator Bishop must have been reading the newspapers because she made reference to how Labor has lost touch with the people. What a penetrating piece of analysis that is! She must have had to sit and think for a long time to think up that line.
—No, it is on everybody's lips.

—Senator Bishop ought to know. I will not say what else is probably on the lips of a lot of Liberal Party people in New South Wales. I will not be so cruel to suggest what might be on their lips. However, under the leadership of Barrie Unsworth the New South Wales Government, in my view, is certainly the best qualified to run the State of New South Wales. In terms of depth of ability it is far in advance of the New South Wales Liberal Party. Who are the New South Wales shadow Ministers? Who are the faceless men of the New South Wales Liberal Party? We have never heard of them in the national capital. We have never heard of these people who aspire to be Treasurers, transport Ministers and health Ministers. Of course, they have no experience.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I thought Senator Bishop made one good point, and one worth considering. She quoted Neville Wran, who said that 11 years was enough. Then for dramatic effect Senator Bishop said it again. She then said it again. I think it was Marx who said that history repeats itself-the first time is a farce, the second time is a tragedy. However, we had a triple-bunger. I invite Senator Bishop, on that basis, to go up to Queensland at the next State election, where they have had 30 years of government, and tell them that 11 years is enough and that they should get out. Will Senator Bishop do that? Of course she will not. Did Senator Bishop trip off down to Victoria when the Liberals ruled from 1955 to 1982? Here is the crucial question: Did Senator Bishop vote Labor in 1976 on the basis that the Liberal Party had been there for 11 years and had had enough? Of course she did not vote for the Labor Party. She probably forgot to vote. She was too busy putting right wing uglies into the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. That is probably the case. This point about 11 years--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to the reflection cast by the Minister on Senator Bishop and ask you to rule, under standing order 418, that the Minister withdraw.
—Specifically what?
—Senator Messner, what specifically are you objecting to?
—I am referring to the statement about Senator Bishop and her activities in reference to `uglies'.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: The word `uglies' in the New South Wales Liberal Party context means right wing apparatchiks of certain political views; it does not refer to physical aspects.
—It is not only that, it is the reference to stacking the branches with people of that kind.
—I might use truth as a defence, I am not sure. However, I will let the Acting Deputy President rule.
—I consider that there is no point of order.

—If it has given offence to Senator Bishop, I will withdraw. Senator Bishop probably did vote in the 1976 election. Certainly she would have voted Liberal. I would not expect anything else. What we have seen here tonight about what we would call the 11-year rule, concept or syndrome is just a sort of farcical proposition put forward by somebody trying to support the troops back home. That is fair enough. However, it really does not stand up, as I have said. Senator Bishop will not be proceeding up to Queensland and lecturing the Queensland National Party that, in fact, it has had 30 years in government and it is time to go. Nor would she do it anywhere else, because she is a conservative loyalist. Nevertheless, I think that we have dealt with that particular point. In summary, because I would hate to eat into Senator Michael Baume's time, I would just say--
—I will do it tomorrow-on air.

—I am sure we will hear it all again tomorrow, even if I do not block Senator Baume tonight. We are going to hear it tomorrow anyway. That is a terribly false threat. There is no way we could stop Senator Baume doing it tomorrow, so I ask him not to threaten me.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, this is, if one likes, the second act of about a 15-act play that we will have over the next few weeks in which everyone gets very earnest about New South Wales. Some honourable senators probably will not get the same quaver in their voice as Senator Bishop, some will not have the concerned fluency of Senator Peter Baume and some will not have the waspish enthusiasm of Senator Puplick. Nevertheless, it will all flow forward, all against the pathetic backdrop that probably it will not influence one voter out there.

What we really should be concentrating on doing here is getting on with the legislation and getting on with debating national issues about which honourable senators opposite might get some publicity and have some effect. Really, I suppose that is what this is about. What honourable senators opposite are really saying by raising these issues time and time again is that this is a no confidence motion against Nick Greiner. Apparently he needs help. I ask honourable senators opposite why they do not just let him do his own job. Why do they have to keep running up to Canberra and, behind the wall of privilege, try to put forward propositions for Nick Greiner? Deep in their heart of hearts honourable senators opposite know that Nick Greiner is not good enough. They know they have to help him out; they have to prop him up. I just wonder about that. The only value Canberra has ever been to Nick Greiner was when he sloshed the $3,900,000 through the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Liberal Party to avoid disclosure. That is the only value Canberra has ever been to Nick Greiner. It is the only value it will be this time. Those opposite criticise us for disclosure when in the last election in 1984, $3,900,000 passed from the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Liberal Party to the New South Wales branch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) did fulfil his threat and speak for half an hour and I think I detected at most five minutes of that time that had anything to do with New South Wales. I congratulate him on his relevance which was minimal. I also note that his expectations about New South Wales are equally off the beam. If he wishes to engage in comments about the former Premier of New South Wales and what an impact he had, then I feel that I should recount to him an incident that occurred when I spoke to Mr Rex Jackson a couple of years ago. I have not recounted this before, but I will now. It relates, of course, to Mr Neville Wran. I was in the company of a very distinguished person who can act as a witness if anyone in this chamber is concerned about it. When I saw Mr Jackson outside the Commonwealth office block I said to him, `Rex, how will you go with all your troubles?'. He said, `I will be sweet, mate. If they get me they will need a new Premier of New South Wales within a week'. What interested me about that conversation is that exactly one week before Mr Rex Jackson went up for trial there was a new Premier of New South Wales. I just wonder whether Mr Jackson's comment was a prescient one and I just wonder why, after 10 allegedly highly successful years, the Premier of New South Wales decided to step down.
—Or jump out the window.

—Or jump out the political window. I note also that shortly after that the Hooker-Harrah consortium deal seemed to blow up too. I frankly have no idea what prompted Mr Wran to depart. All I have done is narrate to the Senate a most curious conversation-at least curious in the terms of what subsequently happened. As I said, it is a conversation the veracity of which can be established very simply by a witness of impeccable status.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Minister was happily berating us I noticed he started off talking about me as a failed House of Representatives candidate. In fact, I was a successful candidate. I won the seat of Macarthur from the Australian Labor Party. I beat Mr John Kerin, now a Minister in this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many times?

—I thank my cousin, Senator Peter Baume. I beat him twice. On the criteria used by the Minister in an endeavour to belittle me Mr Kerin is a twice defeated candidate and yet does the Minister say that Mr Kerin is a man of no status or someone who should not be taken any notice of? I am certain Mr Kerin would be most interested to be aware of the good senator's apparent opinion of him. Because the Minister has used this phrase quite often, I might mention to him that after I won the seat in 1975-I held it again in 1977 with around about the same narrow majority as befits a swinging seat-in 1980 when there was something like a three and a half per cent swing against the Liberal Party throughout Australia, I doubled my majority and instead of being theoretically ninth on the pendulum to go, I held the seat very comfortably indeed which is obviously not fitting in, unfortunately, with the Minister's categorisation. The Minister is ultimately right-I was defeated, not as a candidate but as a member. I was defeated after a Mr Bob Hawke-he must be a man of integrity because he keeps telling us he is-came to the Dapto showground four days before the election and before a crowd of miners and steel workers who were concerned about their employment future. He said to them, `Under a Labor Government there will be no sackings in the steel industry. There will be no retrenchments in the coal industry'. Eight thousand job losses later the man of integrity is not a regular visitor to Dapto. It strikes me as quaint that a man like the Minister should hold me up as a failed candidate when, in fact, I lost because of a disgraceful, dishonest and corrupt promise which that man as Leader of the Opposition at that time had no intention or capacity to fulfil, which was part of a pattern of promises which were corrupt.
—Who was this blackguard?

—This is the man who tells us that he is a man of integrity. He keeps saying it over and over again. It is the Prime Minister. He is the only person who says it, but the Prime Minister of this country came to Dapto and held out these intolerable, improper promises that were incapable of being achieved. After I had been defeated as a result of these promises members of the Labor Party then destroyed my seat for me by cutting it like gall into three. I must say that they had some gall.
—We didn't do it. The commissioners did it.
—I am glad the Minister then said that the commissioners did it because he claimed that Senator Bishop had alleged that the commissioners in New South Wales had been corrupt.
—I didn't.

—That is right. Senator Bishop said no such thing. What she said was that the guidelines under which the commissioners had to work and the factual input that they received from the Federal material which they had to work with was such that the outcome of that redistribution is a nonsense. The commissioners had to work by rigid rules.
—From an undisclosed source.
—Yes. The whole issue was that they were obliged to establish what the future population was likely to be of these electorates in a certain number of years.
—By 1988, as Senator Bishop says. We never found out what the criterion was which was used to establish what the future population would be.
—The commissioners always identify growth.

—We were never told the criteria under which these fanciful figures were created. As a result, the Opposition parties in New South Wales will have to win something like 53 per cent of the vote because of the honest, upright and proper way the criteria was set for these commissioners by the corrupt Labor Party in New South Wales. So we have a situation where the Minister said, `Yes, it is true'. I must say that he beat me to the punch. He said, `Back in the 1960s the Labor Party kept whingeing'. It kept whingeing because it had to get 51 per cent of the vote to win and yet we are somehow disgraceful for bringing to the Parliament's attention that in New South Wales we have to get 53 per cent of the vote to win. I think the Minister has a set of double standards which are immensely appropriate because they are the double standards that exist throughout this Ministry and this Government. They are the double standards that have brought this Government into contempt with the people of Australia, as is evidenced by the by-election result in Adelaide and as will be evidenced as the tide at last turns against people who are outstanding at promising and abysmal at performing. I now want to examine their style of gerrymander. We have heard a fanciful and semantic debate from the Minister about what a gerrymander really means. I say this: a gerrymander is in fact what this Government has done with the Aboriginal Commission-only this one is a `gerryhander', because there it has even greater variations between the numbers involved in providing one representative than it has even in Queensland. Now with that kind of `gerryhander', I can say only that the Government has learnt well, because in those instances where it can get away with doing it openly, it does it openly; and in those situations where it has to do it in a covert way, as in New South Wales, it will do it covertly. The Labor Party is a horses for courses party; there is no doubt about it.
