—Order! The time allotted to General Business has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1987INCOME TAX (OFFSHORE BANKING UNITS) (WITHHOLDING TAX RECOUPMENT) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1987
This Bill will amend various taxation laws to give effect to a range of policy decisions of the Government.
The more important amendments to be made relate to provisions of the income tax law.
They include measures to encourage the development of off-shore banking in Australia through a withholding tax exemption for interest paid to non-residents by off-shore banking units.
Capital gains tax roll-over relief is being given for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts.
Amendments to correct certain deficiencies in the taxation of lump sum superannuation and similar payments are also proposed.
The Bill will remove special concessional treatment for expenditure on buildings for scientific research or other research or development purposes and on the development of certain computer software.

Other amendments include further concessions to permit shelf companies to satisfy `common ownership' tests contained in the income tax law, modifications to thin capitalisation provisions and measures to extend the coverage of the income tax law to a range of activities in off-shore areas and external territories.
A number of technical amendments will correct anomalies and deficiencies in the taxation laws.
I will now further outline the more significant measures contained in the Bill.
Offshore Banking Units

This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision, announced on 1 July 1986 and expanded on 9 April 1987, to provide an interest withholding tax exemption to facilitate offshore banking in Australia, primarily for dealings in foreign currencies with non-residents.

Exemption will be confined to banks that are subject to the Banking Act, State banks and other financial institutions authorised to deal in foreign exchange which are gazetted by the Treasurer to be off-shore banking units.
An offshore banking unit may be a separate department of a bank or other financial institution, keeping separate accounts, or a separately incorporated body.
The Bill will exempt from interest withholding tax interest and amounts in the nature of interest paid by offshore banking units on specified borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986.

The scheme of the legislation allows an offshore banking unit to borrow or accept deposits of foreign currency funds either overseas or on the domestic market or of Australian currency from non-residents.

It is basically intended that they deal with these funds only in three ways: by on-lending them to non-residents, depositing them with another offshore banking unit, or in purchasing foreign securities.

To preserve Australia's withholding tax base, and in recognition of the practicalities of tracing and monitoring the application of particular borrowings, any misapplication of funds that attract the concession provided are to bear a special income tax at a penal rate.
This tax will be declared and imposed by an associated Bill about which I will speak shortly.

Consistent with the basic concept of separate dealings by offshore banking units in foreign currency transactions, any foreign income tax losses incurred by offshore banking units from outside banking business may be offset only against subsequent profits from that business.

There will be similar quarantining of offshore banking income for foreign tax credit purposes, precluding the transfer of excess foreign tax credits within a company group of which the offshore banking unit is a member.
This measure is estimated to have a direct revenue cost of $2m annually which may be offset by higher company tax collections on offshore banking business profits.
Capital Gains Roll-Over Relief

Effect is being given to the proposal announced on 29 September 1987 to extend roll-over relief (that is, deferral of liability) from tax on capital gains for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts.

Roll-over relief will be given where a resident company is interposed between a unit trust and its unit holders who dispose of their units to the company in exchange solely for non-redeemable shares in the company.
Such a reorganisation will qualify for the relief where it is entered into, or commenced, after 9 December 1987.
The reorganisation must be carried out by a direct exchange of units for shares or by redemption or cancellation of the units and separate issue of the shares.
The interposed company will be required to elect that the roll over provisions apply and declare that eligibility conditions have been met.
Unit holders will separately elect for roll-over.

They will thereby be able to choose, for capital gains tax purposes, between having their units treated as disposed of at the time of the reorganisation or to defer any capital gains liability until they later dispose of the exchange shares.
Shares received in exchange for units acquired before 20 September 1985 will also be taken to have been acquired before that date.

For the company, an effect of its election may be to have an appropriate proportion of the units taken as having been acquired before 20 September 1985 and therefore not subject to the capital gains and capital losses provisions on a later disposal-the proportion to be determined by reference to the net value of assets of the unit trust that were acquired before that date.

For the remainder of units taken to have been acquired on or after 20 September 1985, cost bases will be determined by reference to the cost bases of the assets of the unit trust that were acquired on or after that date reduced by any liabilities of the trust attributable to those assets.
The nature of this proposal is such that a reliable estimation of the potential revenue effect cannot be made.
Eligible Termination Payments

The Bill also contains measures, announced on 12 January 1987, that will amend the law relating to the taxation of lump sum superannuation and kindred payments. The amendments remedy shortcomings in the law that have been exploited so as to defeat the Government's objectives in the retirement incomes area.

First, the Bill will ensure that a lump sum payment made after 12 January 1987 on the death of a superannuation fund member will be taxed as an eligible termination payment if the payment is made as an alternative to a superannuation pension or annuity.

This is consistent with a policy of discouraging the conversion of retirement incomes into tax free lump sums, and will overcome arrangements by which some superannuation funds dress up as tax free lump sums payments that are in substance a commutation of a pension or annuity.
The Bill will also close a loophole that allowed persons who are not dependants to receive superannuation and other termination payments tax free on the death of a taxpayer.
Death benefits paid after 12 January 1987 will be exempt from tax only if paid to dependants.

A range of measures is being introduced to ensure that annuities purchased with rolled-over eligible termination payments do not qualify for tax concessions unless they provide genuine retirement incomes for the taxpayer and the taxpayer's dependants.
The concessions are the deferment of tax on the eligible termination payment and tax exemption for the income derived by the annuity issuer from that business.
The first of the new requirements is that the annuity contract must provide for the annuity to commence to be payable by the annuitant's sixty-fifth birthday.
Another measure will limit the class of persons who may be nominated under a roll-over annuity contract to receive residual benefits on the purchaser's death.
It will exclude adult children who are not financially dependent on the purchaser.

By a further amendment only the spouse of a deceased annuitant will be allowed to roll over an eligible termination payment received as the residual capital value or commutation of a roll-over annuity.
The other rules being introduced for roll-over annuities are aimed at securing timely release of an annuitant's income entitlements once age 65 is reached.
Those rules are in two groups.
One will set upper limits on any capital payments permitted under the contract on termination of the annuity after age 65.
Under the other group of rules the Commissioner of Taxation will look to whether the annuity contract permits unreasonable deferral of any annuity income payable after 65.

Together the rules reflect a policy that tax exemption for issuers of roll-over annuities cannot be justified beyond the normal retirement age if the tax payable on the relevant annuity income continues to be deferred.
The Bill sets out matters that the Commissioner will have regard to in applying the rules.
For example, the guaranteed component of an annuity and any bonus (or supplementary) component are required to be considered separately and according to different principles.
More detailed explanations can be found in the explanatory memorandum.

Another amendment will exempt from the eligible termination payment taxing provisions the residual capital value of a deferred roll-over annuity paid to a dependant on the death of the purchaser during the deferment period.
This will bring the tax treatment of those payments into line with payments to dependants of deceased superannuation fund members and approved deposit fund depositors.
The various amendments affecting roll-over annuities are to apply to annuities purchased after 12 January 1987, the date of announcement of the measures.

As a complementary measure, immediate annuities not purchased wholly with rolled-over eligible termination payments are to be required to satisfy conditions similar to those for roll-over annuities if the earnings of annuity issuers from that business are to be tax free. The conditions are to apply from the time of purchase, rather than at age 65 and apply to relevant annuities purchased after 9 December 1987.
A further measure will treat de facto spouses on the same basis as legal spouses for the purposes of the lump sum payments taxing provisions.

The Bill will also clarify two matters: firstly, that a roll-over payment to a personal or self-employed person's superannuation fund does not qualify as a tax deductible contribution to the fund; and secondly, that an annuity is regarded for these purposes as being presently payable-and therefore, an immediate annuity-at all times after the commencement of the first payment period.
This package of measures is expected to result in a net revenue gain of $4m in 1986-87 and $30m in a full year.
Research and Development Activities
The Bill implements two changes announced on 20 November 1987 to the concessions for expenditure on scientific research and other qualifying research and development activities.

The three year write-off for expenditure on the construction or acquisition of buildings used exclusively in these activities will be removed, except where the taxpayers who incur the expenditure had committed themselves to the construction or acquisition before 21 November 1987.
This change will ensure more efficient use of the revenue available for research and development activities by focusing upon more productive, and innovative, investments.

The second change is an anti-avoidance measure to deny deductibility as `research and development activities' for expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987 on the development of computer software not intended for multiple application by persons not associated with the developer.
Other changes arising from the Government's review of the research and development tax concession which were also announced on 20 November 1987 are proposed to be introduced in this sittings.
The changes included in the Bill under this heading are estimated to save $5m in a full year.
`Shelf' Companies

The Bill includes measures complementary to those introduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 4) 1987 to permit a newly-incorporated company, commonly referred to as a `shelf' company, to be eligible for various company grouping provisions of the income tax law.
One change will backdate shelf company eligibility to the income year in which each of the relevant grouping provisions was first made available.
Another change will extend the operation of the grouping concessions to shelf companies acquired by the mechanism of issuing new shares and redeeming the subscriber shares in the shelf company.
Other Matters
The remaining measures contained in the Bill are not matters of major significance and I shall not take up the time of the Senate by dwelling on them.
Detailed explanations are set out in the explanatory memorandum.
For immediate purposes I note that they deal with the following subjects.

First, some technical redefinition of offshore areas is being made, the main change being to amend Australia's taxing rights over certain sea installations used for tourism, recreation, business or transport activities.

Unintended consequences of the imputation system legislation are being remedied so that non-resident life assurance companies are freed of divided withholding tax on any unfranked dividend income attributable to superannuation and certain life assurance policies derived through their Australian branches on or after 1 July 1987.

More generous transitional rules are being given to some companies with substituted accounting periods to enable them to rearrange their debt/equity ratios to comply with the thin capitalisation measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 4) 1987.

The income tax rebate for taxable bonuses received under short-term life assurance policies is being extended under an agreement with the Western Australian Government to policies issued by the State Government Insurance Corporation of that State.

Finally, a minor technical amendment is being made to the quarterly provisional tax system's legislation; a redundant machinery provision is being removed from the sales tax law; and full effect is being given to the abolition of stamp duty and tax on transfers of debentures in the Australian Capital Territory.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (OFFSHORE BANKING UNITS) (WITHHOLDING TAX RECOUPMENT) BILL 1987

This Bill will formally declare and impose an income tax, the liability for which may arise under one of the measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987, about which I have just spoken.

That liability may arise in respect of certain dealings by banks and other financial institutions which are declared to be offshore banking units in accordance with provisions being inserted in the Income Tax Assessment Act by that Bill.

Those provisions are part of measures designed to provide an interest withholding tax exemption for offshore borrowings by such units in order to facilitate the conduct of offshore banking in Australia, primarily for dealings in foreign currencies with non-residents.

Liability for an income tax, at a penal rate, could apply if an offshore banking unit misapplies borrowings that qualify for the withholding tax exemption, for example, by on-lending to residents of Australia.
The income tax is to be based on a formula contained in the relevant provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The tax is a sanction against the use of the funds that have been exempted from withholding tax otherwise than, broadly, for offshore banking business, but may be subject to remission in appropriate circumstances.
This Bill imposes that income tax and declares the rate of the tax to be 300 per cent of the formula amount.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the concluding moments I have, I shall refer to parts IV to VII of the Bill, which seek to give jurisdiction to the Family Court on a range of matters-income tax appeals, bankruptcy proceedings, and matters relating to the Trade Practices Act. Of course, while there may be some merit in the suggestion of the Jackson Committee that the family law division of the Federal Court provide for dual commissions for family law judges to also sit in the general divisions, in my view the transfer of unrelated jurisdiction to the Family Court will not, as is suggested by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), help to enhance its standing in any real way. In fact, such a proposal also goes against the views expressed by the Family Law Council in its 1986-87 annual report. In appendix 4 of that report, the council said that it would view with some concern any attempt `to graft on to the existing structure of family law jurisdictions which have little or no relevance to family law'. I truly fail to see how, in the Attorney-General's words, by broadening the jurisdiction of the Family Court judges this way, appointments to the Family Court will be more attractive. That is clearly the intention; but obviously the method being used will have absolutely no compelling appeal-quite the contrary.

SPEECH.PARA: Such an ad hoc addition to the Court's jurisdictions can only, I suspect, heighten the professional condescension and worsen the community's perception, more so than it already is, of the Family Court, as it must imply inevitably providing the court with real work and consequently creating real judges. Of course, I recognise the efforts of the Attorney-General in attempting to raise the status and the self-esteem of the Family Court and perhaps the self-perception of the Family Court and its practitioners. Unfortunately, it is quite plain that the message contained in this Bill will not achieve those ends, admirable as they may be.

As the Liberal Party says in its policy, for most Australians family law is the most important single field of the law. This flows inevitably, to quote Mr Justice Kirby, from the fact that marriage still forms the basic economic and social unit within Australia's society for the vast majority. The importance of this statement must be reflected in appropriate and responsible legislation.

There are many matters of controversy, both in this Bill and in the Jackson Committee report, which require full debate and determination and, in my view, these matters ought, quite properly, not be rushed now, through this piece of legislation, and cobbled together in an ad hoc way, but, rather, examined with some considerable care and deliberation by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again in this second reading debate to state the Opposition's views in relation to the amendment to the motion for the second reading, which amendment Senator Macklin moved before the lunch break. That is, he proposes that at the end of the motion, That the Bill be read a second time, the following words be added:

SPEECH.PARA: ``, but the Senate considers-

(a) that the salaries and conditions of service of Family Court judges should more closely approximate those of Federal Court judges, as, in its opinion, the expertise, workload and status of the judges in each court are equivalent; and
(b) that the passage of this Bill should be seen as just one step in a process leading to the possible amalgamation of the Family and Federal Courts.

When I opened the debate on the second reading motion earlier today, I had not had notice of that amendment. I only learnt of it by an earlier draft. I do not know whether it was circulated, but it was certainly discussed during the early stages of the debate, but after I had spoken. Now, after discussions that the Democrats have had with the Minister at the table and with me, they have modified their original proposal, and just before lunch Senator Macklin moved the modified amendment which I have just read. The Opposition is not opposed to the sentiments that are contained in the proposed amendment. We certainly are prepared to support it in general terms, though I might say they have become more general as a result of the discussions that I have referred to as we could not have supported the amendment in its original form, which was too specific about the salaries of Family Court judges and the progressing of the Family Court's amalgamation with the Federal Court.

I want to explain the views of the Opposition in relation to these proposals. In the first place, the whole question of the future of the Family Court, which has been the subject of a good deal of comment in the course of the second reading debate, should have been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Before the end of the Budget session last December when the Government agreed to separate the consideration of a Bill amending the Family Law Act from consideration of another major amendment to the Family Law Act, which the Opposition was happy to accommodate for an early passage before Christmas, we moved that the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987 should be referred to the Senate Committee for consideration of the very difficult questions which this Bill partly, but not completely, addresses.

The salaries of judges and the possible future amalgamation of the Family Court with the Federal Court would have been appropriately considered by the Senate Committee. It would have assisted this debate today and made it more productive had we had the benefit of the more detailed consideration of these matters by a Senate committee. It could have taken evidence from numbers of experts in this field and although its report may not have been ready for this week it could have been completed in a fairly short time. It would have been of great assistance to the Senate and we would have made a more valuable contribution to the solution of this very difficult problem about the jurisdiction and the future of the Family Court if we had such help from a Senate committee report.

However, the Australian Democrats, for some reasons best known to themselves, declined to support that reference to a Senate committee last December and we are now considering this Bill today with the need to come up with some amendments of our own, which I have referred to in my previous speech on the Bill, which we will deal with in committee. I might say that it would have been much more satisfactory as well for the Government, which has now discovered it needs to make a great number of amendments to its own Bill, as introduced into the Parliament at the end of October last year and which it sought to rush through the Parliament before the end of the Budget session last year, to make it adequate. The Government first gave notice of its committee stage amendments this morning. That is another good reason why this Bill should have been given further consideration than it has been, very suitably by the Senate Committee. The two propositions in the amendment proposed by the Democrats to the motion for the second reading of the Bill-not as amendments to the Bill-could have been more satisfactorily dealt with in a committee consideration. However, they have both been the subject of a good deal of debate in the second reading stage. They are the status of the Family Court in the eyes of the community and of the professions that are concerned with its operations and the future of the Family Court.

The first matter-namely, the question of salaries of judges of the Family Court-is a subject with which I was very closely associated through my years as Attorney-General. The views of the Government of which I was Attorney-General were that the Family Court judges should be paid salaries commensurate with their status as judges of a superior court, as the Act established the Court to be, and that their salaries should certainly be close to, if not equal to, but in the range of salaries paid to Federal Court judges. The present Government has followed the policy that the salaries of judges, along with those of so many other office holders, should be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. In our view the appropriate body to determine the salaries of Family Court judges is the Remuneration Tribunal and not the Parliament.

It is true that the Democrats have not sought an amendment to this Bill which would in any way require the Remuneration Tribunal to determine whether Family Court judges' salaries should be equal to Federal Court judges' salaries or whether they should be a specific percentage of the Federal Court judges' salaries or in any way restrict the discretion of the Remuneration Tribunal. Therefore, the first limb of the amendment we interpret as simply indicating that in the view of the Senate the Remuneration Tribunal ought to determine the salaries of Family Court judges at much the same level as we suggested to the Tribunal on several occasions when we were in government. I do not know whether the present Government has put forward views on this question to the Remuneration Tribunal. I hope the Minister at the table, Senator Tate, who is unfortunately engaged in a conversation with somebody else at the moment, will be able to tell us what the Government's attitude has been towards the salaries of Family Court judges when he responds shortly.

On that basis, the Opposition has no difficulty with the sentiment expressed in limb (a) of the Democrats' amendment. The second limb of the Democrats' amendment says that we should be seeing changes, amendments and extensions of jurisdiction of the Family Court contained in this Bill as a process leading to the possible amalgamation of the Family Court and the Federal Court. We are also not opposed to that. However, we think it does need some qualification in the sense that this is only one of the various solutions to the future of the Family Court. The Opposition has not determined any definite position at this stage about the future of the Family Court. I expressed the view when I spoke during the second reading debate that this option was the most practical solution for the Family Court in the long run.

However, there are other options which I understand the Government has already pursued and may well want to keep open for the future. The Opposition would like to keep open some other options. In particular, we would want to keep open the option of the creation of State family courts in each State, along the lines of the Western Australian State Family Court. I made brief reference to this at the end of my speech earlier today. I ran out of time and so did not sufficiently develop that option-and I do not propose to develop it at any great length now-but in view of the fact that the Australian Democrats have raised this question of the future of the Family Court in this specific way, rather than just commenting on it during the course of a speech I think it is desirable for me to outline this other option.

As I said, when the Family Court proposal was first canvassed, the then Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs considered the original Family Law Bill. I think Senator Reid read from Senator Murphy's original speech introducing that Bill. He pointed out that that original Bill did not contain a proposal for a Family Court. That idea was being developed at that stage by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, which had been given a reference on the initiative of Senator Murphy. It had been moving towards the idea of recommending a Family Court. When it reported on Senator Murphy's Bill it recommended that a Family Court should be established. My recollection is that that report also recommended-although it may have been raised in a later debate; I am not quite sure-that the Family Law Act, in establishing a Family Court of Australia, should give States the option of establishing State family courts. That was certainly a view which I strongly supported. Senator Chaney reminded me this morning when I was speaking in the debate that it was very much an initiative put forward by the Opposition. The end result was that the Family Law Act enabled these arrangements to be made if the States wished to take them up.

In view of the attitudes that State governments and parliaments were taking to the growing centralism of those days, I thought that they would be anxious to take up that option that the Parliament was giving them. It was a most desirable option from the point of view of more efficient administration. It is far more efficient to have courts administered at the State level than at the Federal level. It largely overcame the jurisdictional conflicts in the Federal system relating to family law. Those jurisdictional conflicts, of course, have emerged in an unfortunate way over the last 12 years of the life of the Family Court. Hopefully, they have now been largely resolved by the reference of power by some States and the cross-vesting proposals that this Parliament passed last year.

Undoubtedly the establishment of State family courts, which are able to be invested with the full Federal and State jurisdiction in relation to various matters, such as ex-nuptial children, adoptions and the maintenance of a testator's family. There are a range of matters which impinge on the family which are not necessarily covered entirely by the powers of the Commonwealth Parliament and are certainly not covered by the Family Law Act, and by and large cannot be as the High Court has unfortunately held on a number of occasions over the last 12 years. It would have been far better if the States had taken up this option. We could still have had a national court of appeal in family law-a small expert court. I think it would have greatly assisted in establishing the prestige and standing of the Court if the Federal element of it had been of that kind, in the same way as the Federal Court has rapidly established that reputation. Although it has grown a lot in recent times, it was established as a small and expert court. It was able to establish its reputation in the community very quickly. I think that would have provided a far more efficient administration.

The problems that beset the Family Court would have been more easily solved at the State level if States other than Western Australia had taken up that option. I think the experience of the Western Australian State Family Court proves the point, because all commentators, in my experience, have praised the efficiency, standing and competence of the Western Australian State Family Court. As I said, it has been able to be invested with the full Federal jurisdiction as well as the State jurisdiction. I still hope that the States see the wisdom of proceeding in that way. Certainly there was some interest in doing that from at least one State. It may be worth while attempting to persuade others of the wisdom of that course.

The Opposition is prepared to support the second limb. Certainly, if the State family Court option does not succeed, it seems to me almost inevitable that the Family Court will be amalgamated in some way or other with the Federal Court in due course. I still want to be assured that this is workable. As I said earlier, I believe this Bill is an experiment and we should see how it works. I hope that the Government takes the same attitude to it. I would like to hear Senator Tate's view on that. Certainly we do not want to close off the option in the way in which the Democrats amendment may suggest. We acknowledge that it is a possible and very likely option, but we do not want to close off other options. Therefore, although we support the Democrats amendment, we do so with the reservations and qualifications which I have indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on this most important Bill, the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. In doing so I say that I believe we are dealing with a jurisdiction which obviously is very burdensome to those who undertake judicial office and who discharge the responsibilities conferred on them by the statutes of this Parliament in regard to family law.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become apparent, as has been mentioned by many of the contributors to the second reading debate, that the scope of the work which is entrusted to judges of the Family Court of Australia is perhaps not as challenging and as extensive as their judicial office should allow and that, given the talent of the personnel that one wants to attract to the jurisdiction of the Family Court, their talents could be well used also in dealing with other matters within the Federal jurisdiction. So the narrowness of jurisdiction which has characterised the ambit of the work of the Family Court judges is, by this Bill, to be extended but in a way which, it has to be emphasised, will be done in consultation with the Chief Judge of the Family Court and the Federal Court. Those consultations will, of course, make it happen that only those judges within the Family Court system who may be appropriately versed in law, such that they can deal with income tax appeals, consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act, some Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act matters, bankruptcy and so on, do actually deal with them. So I am sure that this particular addition of Federal jurisdiction to some of the judges of the Family Court will be most welcome and indeed, as I understand it, the chamber is supporting that particular proposition.

It is also intended to allow the Family Court judges to concentrate on the more complex, difficult and contentious matters that come before them. In that regard the delegation of certain jurisdictions and powers to judicial registrars is, I think, to be welcomed. In so far as we have experience of some similar office-that of masters of Supreme Courts-I think we have a model which is well understood, and I believe it will work very well in this instance. It will leave the judges freer to concentrate, as I said, on the more important matters.

It is quite clear that the most contentious area of this legislation is the proposal to give jurisdiction to courts of summary jurisdiction in respect of undefended applications for dissolution where the parties, for their own convenience, request the application to be dealt with in such courts. We have an amendment which allows them to file direct in such courts of summary jurisdiction. That has, of course, caused some debate in the community and we have listened to that debate. With the benefit of the summer break, more of that discussion took place and was taken into account. But in the end the Government does not believe that the assumption of that jurisdiction at the request of the parties will trivialise the institution of marriage, as is sometimes asserted. The trauma and real hurt of the decision to separate initially is where the great drama of divorce, if you like, takes place. It has to be recalled that this legal act of recognition of that traumatic and dramatic event when the parties separated occurs at least 12 months later, and it is this legal recognition of that dramatic event which we are talking about in relation to divorce. If the parties themselves request that it be dealt with in this particular jurisdiction, I think that ought to be permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the children?

—The children mostly will already have been dealt with. As I say, the actual traumatic separation of the parties and the need therefore to decide on custody applications and so on will have occurred very probably in the 12 months preceding the actual divorce matter itself. If the matter comes before a magistrate and, as Senator Walters quite rightly pointed out in her second reading contribution, the custody of children is at stake and the magistrate has to exercise a jurisdiction there, he exercises that jurisdiction in exactly the same way as a Family Court judge does now. He gets all the same papers and all the same information in order to make any decision that is required at that stage.
—That is ridiculous, and you know it.
—I am sorry, but that is the actual fact. I understand that there will be a full Committee stage debate on that and, no doubt, that will be teased out when we come to clauses 15 and 16.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also intended that in relation to property matters the monetary limit on the jurisdiction of those courts of summary jurisdiction be increased but not in the way that was originally proposed in the Bill. It is true that over the summer months there has been time for reflection and consideration of submissions, including those from the Law Institute of Victoria, which was against the transfer of this jurisdiction to Magistrates Courts in any case, but pointed out quite soundly that the monetary limit in property matters should not vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. Recognising that, the Government proposes that the upper limit be changed to some $20,000, and that seems to be a uniform and sensible amount of money which will cover most cases of furnishings and perhaps a car and so on-the property matters. We also make it very clear that the way of assessing the $20,000 is done by looking at the gross value of the property, disregarding any mortgage, lien, charge or other security over the property. I think that could work very well, and I commend to honourable senators that particular change in the Bill before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is money the appropriate measure, Senator Tate?

—In regard to property matters, yes, I think that is a fair way to approach the matter. In regard to the amendment moved by Senator Macklin, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, to the second reading motion, the Government supports both limbs. The first part reads:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate considers-

(a) that the salaries and conditions of service of Family Court judges should more closely approximate those of Federal Court judges, as, in its opinion, the expertise workload and status of the judges in each court are equivalent . . .

The Government supported applications by Family Court judges to the Remuneration Tribunal and, of course, the Family Court judges have been pressing for that greater approximation to the salaries of Federal Court judges, but to date those submissions have not found favour with the Tribunal. But the Government believes that the Tribunal remains the correct forum within which to make these decisions as to salaries, and it intends to approach the Tribunal further on the level of salaries to get some alignment with Federal Court salaries and to reduce the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you made a specific proposal that they should be equal to or--

—I am advised that we have made submissions for equality. As I say, the submissions will, one hopes, find sufficient favour with the Tribunal to reduce differences over a period of time between the salaries of Family Court and Federal Court judges.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the amendment is properly worded. I think in one early draft it said something like it should equal those of Federal Court judges. On discussion that was thought to be too firm in its expression of the Senate's opinion, and I believe it is much more usefully worded now. The second part of the amendment moved by Senator Macklin to the second reading motion was:
(b) that the passage of this bill should be seen as just one step in a process leading to the possible amalgamation of the Family and Federal Courts.

Senator Durack has quite rightly pointed to the fact that the amalgamation of the Federal and Family Courts is a long way off, if it is to happen at all, and may not even be-certainly if reports of the Western Australian experience are to be believed-the most desirable course. There is no doubt that the Western Australian Family Court has been eminently successful in its exercise of jurisdiction. Mr Justice Barblett is the Chief Judge in that Court. I am not surprised, therefore, that it is operating as well as reports tell us.

TALK.START.PARA: —He may now use his new position to persuade the rest of his colleagues.

—Yes, indeed. He is now in a more influential position. The Government has also made submissions to the Judicial Committee of the Constitutional Commission which, in its discussion paper, originally spoke of amalgamation of the Family and Federal Courts. The Government took the opportunity to outline the proposals which have now found expression in this Bill. As I understand it, the Committee of the Commission on that basis did not proceed with its earlier recommendation about amalgamation. It recognised that this was, as the second reading amendment now speaks of it, just a step which could lead to possible amalgamation. But we would certainly have to look at this experience before considering further that question. The Bill in principle deserves the support of the chamber. The second reading amendment moved by Senator Macklin is acceptable to the Government. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2 (Commencement).
Amendment (by Senator Tate) agreed to.
(1) Page 1, clause 2, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:
``(1a) Paragraphs 8a (a) and (d) commence on 1 January 1990.''.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 6-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 4 provides for consultation between the Chief Judge of the Federal Court of Australia and the Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia. It says that they may consult each other in relation to the transfer of proceedings, et cetera, whether generally or in relation to the transfer of particular proceedings. Will the Minister enlighten us a little further about this matter? It is one of the key features of the new jurisdiction. It is very important to the potential litigants of matters in the Federal Court, whether they be trade practice matters, tax matters or whatever but, in particular, those areas where there is a good deal of concern about what sort of cases will be transferred to the Family Court. I would like the Minister to tell us whether any guidelines have been developed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obviously not contemplated that rules of court will be made in relation to these questions. I would like the Minister to expand somewhat on the way in which the judges will discuss these matters-whether it will be purely on a case by case basis, whether there will be some policy in relation to it and whether those policies have been or will be reduced to written guidelines. If there are or will be such guidelines I hope that they will be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the clause, it enables the Chief Judge of the Federal Court of Australia and the Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia to consult. As to the difference between general and particular matters, whilst some general principles will emerge in those discussions about the types of cases generally that may be transferred, I am advised that there may be instances on which a transfer agreement could be reached, such as on a more complex tax matter that normally would not fall within the general range of those matters which it had been agreed could usefully be transferred to Family Court judges. Such a situation could arise in Townsville where there is only a Family Court judge. Even though such cases would fall outside of the general policy developed, in those particular instances an agreement to transfer the matter would be reached. As to whether the consultations will lead to certain guidelines being reduced to writing, I would be astonished if that were not the case. I do not think that they will have the formal status of rules of court, but I would be astonished if they were not made public and therefore available for scrutiny and the enlightenment of legal advisers and the general community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from the Minister's answer that he does not really know at this stage whether any guidelines have been brought into existence; perhaps none have been. It seems rather strange that the Minister cannot tell us whether such an important feature of this Bill has been finalised, or when it will be finalised. Perhaps he could find that out, if not tonight at least for when we resume debate on this Bill, which I understand will not be until next week. I found the answer that he was able to give unsatisfactory. Clearly there can be consultation on specific cases. I understand the instance that he mentioned. Because of the inability of the Federal Court to deal with a particular case, even though it may be a very complex case, the parties may be happy for it to be referred to the Family Court even though it would otherwise not be sent there.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the Minister, he did not really make it clear what type of case, say, in the area of tax or trade practices, would be transferred to the Family Court. By way of example, there is enormous variation in the complexity of work covered under the Trade Practices Act. However, one can draw a broad distinction between part IV of the Act, which deals with traditional restrictive trade practices matters, and part V, which deals with misleading statements and which is generally referred to as the consumer protection side of the Act. Under part V, many very simple cases of fact can arise; very few or no legal questions arise. Is there to be some distinction of that kind?

We have been told that there have been lots of discussions about this Bill and about different options, and that this is the one that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) ultimately came up with after considering others. The matter has certainly involved discussion over a great deal of time. I would have thought that by this stage we could have some more specific indication from the Minister of what sorts of cases the chief judges of the courts are likely to transfer and what tests will be applied for the transfer of such cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that Chief Judge Bowen and the new Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia, Mr Justice Nicholson, will, as I understand it, carry out those consultations. The new Chief Judge of the Family Court has only just been appointed. The fact is that these judges will consult and will come to some understanding and agreement on those matters which may be transferred. I do not think it would be a static situation; it would be somewhat ambulatory. As the tentative nature of the transfer becomes more accepted, those guidelines will change. But it will all depend on the consultation between, and the good sense of, the Chief Judge and the Chief Judge of the Family Court.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the Trade Practices Act, which Senator Durack raised specifically, the jurisdiction that may be transferred would relate only to part V, the consumer protection provisions. Indeed, if in defence of a part V prosecution a part IV issue arises, the Federal Court would be the proper forum; that is made clear in the Bill. There are already some guidelines in the Bill. Common sense dictates that any guidelines that may emerge from those consultations will be made public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 9 inserts proposed new sections 26a and 26b. Proposed new section 26b (6) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Judicial Registrars shall have, in addition to the powers delegated to them under subsection (1), such other powers (if any) as are conferred on them by this Act, the regulations and the Rules of Court.

I know that the proposed new section does not say `or the Rules of Court' but I wonder why those words are there because either the powers are conferred by the Act on the judicial registrars or they are not. If they are conferred on them by the Act, presumably regulations are then made to delineate those powers. The amendment then says `and the Rules of Court'. I am not sure why those words are necessary in there. The reason I raise this matter is that I believe certain functions should be the preserve of the judges.

The concern that I have expressed on a number of occasions in this chamber is that not enough emphasis is given to reconciliation counselling and to advice to the marriage partners when they come before the Court or make enquiries of court officials on this important aspect of reconciliation counselling. I refer honourable senators to section 14 (3) of the Family Law Act where it makes it perfectly clear that reconciliation counselling should form a very important part of this whole system. Unfortunately, as everyone in the chamber knows, very little attention is given to the question of reconciliation counselling by court officers or the judges of the Family Court.

By and large, almost all of the counselling done in the Family Court is divorce counselling. That is not the spirit of the legislation. I said in my speech in the second reading debate that it is difficult to blame the judges of the Court for the administration of what is essentially an unjust law. Of course, many people regard this law as unjust because it deals with separation in a manner that makes no distinction concerning the conduct of the particular party who may have caused the separation. Of course that leaves a great sense of frustration and injustice on the part of the person affected-for example, a woman who may have children and whose husband has just up and left her, but a year later bobs up and wants a divorce.

I feel that it is important that we know what the judicial registrars are. I think it is important for the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to give us an indication of the Government's view of reconciliation counselling, and there is a need for court officers and judges to remember the emphasis given by those who rise in debate in this chamber and in the other place to reconciliation counselling. Therefore, I would like the Minister to let the chamber know what he envisages are to be the functions of the judicial registrars and why clause 26B (6) is in the Bill at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 26B (6), which deals with the powers of judicial registrars, refers to such powers conferred on them by the Act, the regulations and the rules of court. I think that that clause is just a simple recognition of that fact. As Senator Harradine said, the regulations must be made in order to carry out the provisions of the Act. That is fairly clear. Section 123 of the principal Act provides for the making of rules of court. Of course, they deal with the practice and procedures to be followed in the Family Court. Almost the whole alphabet is set out under section 123 (1), concerning the making of the rules of court. There is a recognition in clause 26B (6) that the powers that may be conferred on the judicial registrars simply can be either directly imposed or granted by the statute itself, or can be conferred by the regulations made under the statute and by a majority of the judges making rules of court for the practice and procedures of the Court. I think it is fairly straightforward in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of reconciliation counselling, it is true, and ought to be emphasised more often, that under section 14 of the Family Law Act it is the duty of the judge to give consideration from time to time to the possibility of the reconciliation of the parties. It is known that there are instances of course in which a judge will, having come to some assessment of the parties, make an observation or a suggestion to that effect. However, I think it would be only realistic to acknowledge that by the time the parties get before the judge in a contested matter, it is extremely unlikely that the invitation to consider the possibility of reconciliation will be taken up. It is important therefore that as early as possible in the approach of the parties to the Court they be made aware of marriage counselling organisations. Senator Harradine quite rightly in his speech on the second reading debate pointed to the importance of the role of marriage guidance and counselling organisations which obviously will more commonly have a role which is, on the approach of the parties, more likely to result in the reconciliation of them than will be the conciliation counselling processes undertaken within the Family Court structure where the parties have already come to with a view to gaining legal recognition of their separation.

Whilst reconciliation counselling obviously requires much more emphasis in the community-I am assured that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has a very real interest in strengthening those reconciliation counselling organisations-it must be an important consideration in the overall pattern of the Family Law Act and, indeed, in relation to the whole question of families in Australia. However, insofar as powers of judicial registrars are concerned, I do not think I can say any more in regard to the structure of clause 26 (b). I now move Government amendment No. (5), as follows:
(5) Page 3, clause 9, at the end of proposed section 26c add the following subsection:
`` `(3) The Court may, on the application of a party or of its own motion, refer an application under subsection (1) to a Full Court of the Court.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have already heard in this discussion, clause 9 proposes to establish the new office of judicial registrar. Clause 9 is an extensive clause which, of course, sets out all the matters required to be done in establishing such an office. It sets out the powers, the qualifications for appointment, the terms of office, remuneration, termination provisions and so on. As is evident from Senator Harradine's questions, the powers that may be exercised by judicial registrars potentially are quite as extensive as the powers that may be exercised by judges in the Family Court of Australia. We know, of course, that rules of court have to be made. I suppose that we will not know exactly what they are until they are made. However, I assume that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has some views about the role the position of judicial registrar is being created for. I must say that I am now somewhat bemused at the totality of the amendments and why, indeed, there is a proposal for the establishment of judicial registrars at all. I ask these questions because there has been a steady progression in the powers granted to registrars of the Court. I have to refer to the next clause, clause 12, which widens even further the powers of registrars.

SPEECH.PARA: The last of the amendments which relate to registrars was made, I think, in 1985. Section 37a of the Family Law Act provides that judges may make rules of court delegating to registrars all or any of the powers of the Court. Then, without limiting the generality of the foregoing provisions, the Act sets out matters that may be exercised by registrars. The only limit that was then placed upon registrars was under subsection 2, that they could not be delegated the power to make decrees for dissolution, annulment of marriage, declarations as to the validity of marriage or orders approving maintenance agreements under section 87.

Under clause 12, to which I have already referred, that one and only limit on the powers of registrars is to be removed by the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. The Opposition is not opposing that matter. But in view of the development of the role of the registrar in practice and in view of the development and the recognition of the very important work the registrars perform-particularly in the compulsory conferences in property disputes, all the other sundry work of the Court that is done by registrars which is detailed in section 37a and now the further power to be able to deal with principal relief which they will have after this legislation is passed-I find that I do not quite understand why the Government has decided to create the new office of judicial registrar at all.

I have said in the second reading debate and I will say it again that the Opposition supports greater powers of delegation to officials of the Court to relieve judges of as much of the routine type of work as possible and to enable the judges to deal with the difficult contested cases of custody and property. Unless I misunderstood or overlooked something, it would seem to me that all those powers will be able to be exercised by the registrars themselves who indeed have a status, as far as their salary is concerned, equivalent to at least junior magistrates in New South Wales. I suppose that the salary scales are much the same around Australia. I would like some clarification why a new office of judicial registrar is being established at all in light of the matters that I have mentioned regarding the registrar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason why the title is `judicial registrar' is that these registrars are to be distinguished from the present registrars whose domain, obviously, is mainly to do with administration. The idea with the judicial registrar is that he or she will be exercising more clearly traditional judicial powers. For example, they will be able to deal with contested cases probably in minor property and custody matters, with the consent of the parties. But the fact is that, once again, I think we are dependent on the sense of the judges who make the rules of court which will confer this particular range of matters on the judicial registrar. Clause 26b (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Judges, or a majority of them, may make Rules of Court delegating to the Judicial Registrars all or any of the powers of the Court.

I agree it is perhaps unsatisfactory at the moment not to have those rules of court already before us, but I would have thought that one could be reasonably certain that there will be a proper and circumspect delegation of those powers of the Court. It would be such that the conference work would, I imagine, take up a lot of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean that they are going to conduct compulsory conferences the same as the registrars have been doing for 12 years?

—I am advised that perhaps I overemphasised the conference work that they might be involved in. They will be dealing with interlocutory work rather than submerging themselves in a tremendous amount of conference work, but we are dependent on the judges making these rules of court and until they are promulgated we will not know the position. But I believe that the good sense of the judges, particularly in the initial stages, will be evident when those rules of court are promulgated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) presumably is revealing a total poverty of thought on the part of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I am not suggesting that Senator Tate is responsible for this. This idea seems to have been dreamt up by the Attorney-General himself who explained in a general sort of way what the idea of the judicial registrar was. I accepted this at its face value until I looked a little more closely into other amendments in this legislation. Senator Tate has fallen back in answering me on to clause 26b (1) of the Bill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Judges, or a majority of them, may make Rules of Court delegating to the Judicial Registrars all or any of the powers of the Court.

Clearly that means that they can deal with contested cases as well as administration, conferences or whatever and they can deal with dissolution as well as custody and everything else. That is what it means they can do. But I have already referred the Minister, Senator Tate, to a recent amendment of the Family Law Act. In fact, amendment No. 193 of 1985 inserted a new section 37a into the Family Law Act. Section 37a states that the Judges, or a majority of them, may, subject to sub-section (2) make rules of court delegating to the Registrars all or any of the powers of the Court. That is exactly the same wording as contained in this Bill as far as judicial registrars are concerned. Surely the simple wording of these two provisions must be apparent to Senator Tate who is not without some legal ability? The very same wording is used in relation to the powers of judicial registrars as now applies to the potential powers of registrars. In addition to section 37a clause 12 of this Bill removes the one limit on the powers of registrars that has existed, namely, they cannot deal with principal relief because that is removed by clause 12 which we will be dealing with shortly. I am bemused as to why we have an office of judicial registrar when the Government has seen fit to expand greatly the powers of registrars. What is the point of it? Registrars can now be given the power to deal with contested proceedings and, indeed, will be able to deal with contested claims of principal relief after we pass this legislation. Therefore, I really do believe that the Government has some better explanation of why it is complicating this whole question by creating a new office of judicial registrar. I believe that the Senate is entitled to be told why the Government is creating this office in light of other amendments it has made in relation to the registrars themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk tonight about the decision of the Government to take the Aviation College away from Canberra and place it in Launceston. This is a matter that people might think is not of much consequence, and they might wonder whether I am actually arguing with Launceston; I assure honourable senators that I am not. What I am saying, though, is that the Government has shown that it has absolutely no regard for the national capital and what it stands for. It has absolutely no regard for the need to diversify and change the economic face of Canberra and develop our educational expertise; and it has no regard for the confidence that it takes away from the business community when it treats Canberra in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back to remind the Senate that the Public Works Committee went into extensive inquiries last year to determine whereabouts the Aviation College should be placed. The Aviation College has been in Melbourne for a long time, but the Department of Aviation moved to Canberra some time ago and found it was then very costly to run the college in Melbourne and determined that it ought to shift it to the national capital. There were a number of sites in contention and finally the Public Works Committee decided that the cheapest and most efficient place to put it was at Watson High School, which was to close at the end of 1987, and which would enable the college to be functioning by 1989.

Some time after that, for what reason we do not know, somebody decided that to try to get the college down to Launceston would be of some advantage. We are not quite sure who that was, but we have a fair idea. Launceston may need something. That is the only explanation we have been given from the Prime Minister since then: that Launceston needed something. I shall return to that.

It was in November, 1987, that I heard that this back-door wheeling and dealing was going on. I asked a question of the Minister and he prevaricated a bit and then subsequently gave an answer confirming that this was going on; that there was talk-notwithstanding the fact that moneys had been expended in Canberra to get it set up here-that there was some sort of deal was being done to shift it away from Canberra. A week or so ago we got the announcement from the Prime Minister that that was the case and that it would go to Launceston.

As I said, my quarrel is not with that city; it is entitled to be on the march trying to get something, having been done out of cycling, which was sold off from the Institute of Sport a while ago and given to Adelaide. The fact is that Launceston has one of the best velodromes that one will find anywhere, especially in this country. Adelaide does not have a velodrome anything like the standard. I do not agree with the wheeling and dealing that has gone on with sport from the Institute of Sport. In 1984 hockey was given to Perth; in 1985 squash and diving went to Brisbane; and in 1987 cycling and cricket went to Adelaide.

Instead of having an Institute of Sport that the country could be proud of, centrally based in the national capital-where it ought to be so that all elite sports people and those who would benefit from the training they would get from the institute would come to one place and have the benefit of mixing with other athletes and the benefit of being with that splendid sports medicine facility-this Government has embarked on a course of splintering it and having little bits and pieces here and there, where it thinks it will be of some advantage to itself. For some reason that is inexplicable, cycling went to Adelaide and not to Launceston, and everybody knows that Tasmania is the place where cycling has been a sport of very high priority. They have had many champions and, as I said, they have the velodrome that ought to have attracted cycling if it was to be taken away from where it ought to have been. We face the situation of the same people then trying to make it up to Launceston by giving them something down there, by taking the Aviation College away from the national capital and giving it to Launceston. It will be a great deal more costly for it to be based down there, and the taxpayers, either State or Federal, will have to bear the cost of that being the case.

My point is that this shows that the Government treats the national capital with contempt; it shows that it treats the local business entrepreneurs, who are doing their best to bring industry and business to Canberra, with contempt; and it has no regard for trying to develop our economy in a way which will give greater opportunities for young people to get employment here so that we can have an education system that is as broad as is possible and attract people to Canberra in that respect. It is a great shame that this Government bears, having taken this institution from Canberra, having demonstrated to my constituents that anything that is here is up for grabs if somebody else can make a better offer for it. It is a shame.

The Canberra Times wrote a very good editorial on the matter last Saturday and for those who have not read it, I recommend that they do so. The only criticism I would have of that editorial is that it did not bother to point out that there was no reaction from the Labor members in the Australian Capital Territory to this decision. One would have thought there would have been an outcry from them for having embarked on this course; but that was not the case. I believe they, too, bear part of the shame of having let down this electorate and the people of Canberra in allowing the Aviation College to be taken away for some cheap political purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Sunday a memorial service was held in the Wesley Hall, Lonsdale Street, Melbourne for Ted Hill-Edward Fowley Hill. Many people attended: judges past and present, union leaders, academics, surgeons, politicians, public servants, and people who lead and have led great movements. The number of those who attended together with the width of beliefs they represented gave grand testimony to Ted Hill. They made manifest the extraordinary range of his friends and admirers.

SPEECH.PARA: A great number of progressive people were attracted to Ted. This is unremarkable. More remarkable is the great number of those of conservative bent who called him friend. On Tuesday, 2 February 1988, the Sydney Morning Herald headlined its report of Ted Hill's passing with the words, `Leading Communist lawyer dies after illness of 15 years'. This is an accurate though inadequate description of what he was.

Ted Hill was born in 1915 and died on 1 February 1988. He lived more than three score years and ten, and they were filled with great achievements. He was indeed a communist, as the Sydney Morning Herald noted. He adhered faithfully to his beliefs over many years. He was a leading member of the Marxist-Leninist Party at the time of his death. Many who did not share his philosophy admired his willingness to place it ahead of professional self-interest. His career suffered markedly as a result.

During the 1950s, Ted Hill appeared in the Royal Commission into Communism and in the Petrov case. The decade was a crucial one for civil liberties. Ted's advocacy for a cause, subject to fierce hostility from the great and the powerful, vindicated the right to dissent. He promoted the right of free speech by exercising it when most feared to do so. Ted Hill believed in the power of intellectual persuasion. He believed an argument, properly put, will be effective even with those at first thought implacable to it.

Ted lived his life on the basis that its various dimensions were integrated. He was a brilliant lawyer and put many a technical argument with great strength and skill. He was a powerful political theoretician. He had a deep concern with social dynamics, but he saw that significant change in Australia was not based on any one of these alone. Legal argument, infused with social and political beliefs and transformed by a grand vision, can do much. On its own it makes for stagnation. Passionate political and social principles on their own do not provide the machinery to effect that change.

His approach to legal work is compelling evidence of this. Ted Hill demonstrated his ability to combine high legal skill with passionately held political and social beliefs. He combined amazing medical knowledge with superb legal skills to develop a process of advocacy which he and many others used to win compensation for heart attack victims at the Workers Compensation Board.

Ted comprehended and took part in great historic movements. He was friends with a wide range of public figures in Australia. He was welcomed to China by its leadership in the 1950s and 1960s when very few Westerners visited that country.

At the same time, he was a man dedicated to the individual in distress. His approach to injured workers is compelling evidence of this. A proposition that in Victoria he has helped more injured workers in economic and social distress than has anyone else is unlikely to bring a rebuttal. Ted had great intellectual capacity, great dedication to his beliefs, great energy, great empathy with those in need and great willingness to help them. I express my condolences to Ted's wife and children. Ted Hill has left a society much richer for his life.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney gave a valedictory address about Ted Hill, who I think is well known in the labour movement as being a communist. He is well known as the leader, I think, of the Communist Party, Marxist-Leninist and someone with whom I think I would not have any commonality of view on almost any point. But I recognise the great sincerity with which Senator Cooney paid a tribute to the passing of this participant in the wider tapestry of the labour movement and know that Ted Hill certainly did contribute a great deal on the legal side of workers compensation in his role as a Victorian workers compensation lawyer. I acknowledge the remarks that Senator Cooney has made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.42 p.m.
